PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance. That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments. That we express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances for the purpose of food irradiation and disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some Scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendations of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Colston (from 438 citizens) Giles (from 176 citizens) and Jones (from 364 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: that the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia Respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 145 citizens) and McKiernan (from 135 citizens).

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Norfolk Island Act to enable the Norfolk Island Government to appoint its own auditor to audit the public accounts of the Territory of Norfolk Island. At present, the Act requires the accounts to be audited by the Auditor-General for the Commonwealth.

The proposed amendments will enable the Norfolk Island Administrator-on the advice of the Legislative Assembly-to appoint a person or firm to be the Norfolk Island Government Auditor and to set the terms and conditions of the Auditor's employment. Only a person who is, or a firm at least one member of which is, registered as an auditor under Commonwealth or Norfolk Island companies legislation may be appointed as Auditor. The Bill enables the Commonwealth Auditor-General or a State Auditor-General to accept appointment.

The Auditor will audit the accounts of the Norfolk Island Administration and the accounts of Territory authorities, other than authorities for which separate audit requirements exist under Territory legislation.

The Bill imposes appropriate duties on the Auditor and includes provisions designed to ensure the independence of the Auditor and access to relevant documents and information. The Bill also makes provision for the Legislative Assembly to set auditing standards to be complied with by the Auditor. In setting such standards the Assembly will be required to have regard to the auditing standards set by the Commonwealth Auditor-General under the Audit Act and by the relevant professional accounting bodies.

The Auditor will report to the President of the Assembly, who will be required to table the report in the Legislative Assembly. The Auditor will also provide a copy of the report to the Administrator to send to the Commonwealth Minister administering the Norfolk Island Act. This latter provision will ensure that the Minister remains appropriately informed of the financial affairs of the Administration and Territory authorities.

The Norfolk Island Act of 1979 established a framework for self-government in the Territory, including a Legislative Assembly and exercise of executive powers. As foreshadowed in the Act, the self-government powers of the Territory have been extended since the Act was passed. The proposed amendments will further enlarge the Territory's self-government powers in a significant area of responsibility. The proposed amendments have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 3 indicates quite clearly that the principal Act which this legislation is amending is the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. I wish to say something about that apropos what I thought was a particularly significant editorial in the Australian newspaper of 22 March which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, so well-intentioned at the outset, has become an unfortunate emblem of strife between Federal and State governments and between the centralised government and the individual.
The Opposition entirely agrees with that assessment. The editorial continues:

In the case of North Queensland, the Federal Government gave the timber industry a bare six months to stop production-a rate totally inconsistent and unreasonable when compared with its demands upon industries such as motor vehicles and textiles.
The editorial goes on to say:
The Commonwealth, if it proposes to intervene in any area for the sake of heritage, also has a duty of care towards the individuals and industries affected.

That duty includes taking a fuller and more balanced view of the economic and social factors unleashed-in other words to provide some kind of impartial heritage impact statement canvassing both the environmental and economic resource aspects of a proposed listing.

In conclusion I simply say that, to the extent that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 remains on foot and within the ambit of the Commonwealth to take certain actions under, I believe that those words in the editorial of the Australian are germane and that they ought to be more closely understood and adhered to by the Government in its operations. In fact, they ought to be the model by which proceedings under this Act continue in the future.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clause 5 (Identified Property).

TALK.START.PARA: —Can a finding of a Commonwealth inquiry be challenged in Australian courts on the basis of whether a property forms part of the cultural or natural heritage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON

—I take note of the Minister's answer. Is a Commonwealth inquiry a precondition of a Commonwealth World Heritage nomination?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a precondition, no. Certainly it is a possibility; it is not a precondition.
—Can a Commonwealth declaration by regulation be challenged in Australian courts on the basis of whether the declared property forms part of the cultural or natural heritage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is referring to the regulation, yes.
—Unequivocally?
—The Minister has answered the question. He did not add the last part that you added.

—My fourth question is: Does the existing and proposed legislation constitute a sufficient basis for the Commonwealth to impose the land management provisions of World Heritage convention on Australian property?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation does not address that at all, as far as I am aware.
—Could the Minister give further consideration to that question? The Minister's answer was that the Bill does not address the issue of my question?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The regime which is established by clause 5 for the identification of properties is central to the Opposition's objections to the way in which the Government is proceeding. I draw attention to proposed new section 3A (1) (a) (i); that is to say, where a property:

SPEECH.PARA: is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth whose purpose, or one of whose purposes, is to consider whether the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage.
I wish to address a couple of questions to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

I understand from the Minister's answer to Senator Watson that an inquiry is not a necessary prerequisite for proceeding towards nomination, and I accept that that is correct. However, I wish to know a little about the nature of these inquiries which are proposed to be established. In particular, since the inquiry must be established by a law of the Commonwealth, is this to be taken to mean that the inquiry must be a statutory inquiry, or is it capable of being an inquiry established by executive act? In other words, because the Minister has not indicated precisely how the Government will proceed, does each inquiry require an Act of Parliament in the way in which the Lemonthyme inquiry was established; or could an Act be introduced which provides for the setting up of inquiries from time to time for purposes related to this particular matter? In other words, could there be an Act called, for the sake of argument, the World Heritage Properties (Conservation Inquiries) Act which says, `The Minister may from time to time establish inquiries under this Act to consider matters falling within a particular section of the legislation'; or would there have to be a separate inquiry established by statute to look at each of the matters arising as potential World Heritage nominations? In other words, there would have to be a Shark Bay inquiry Act or a Kimberley inquiry Act, or whatever it happened to be, for that purpose. It seems to me that that is an important question for us to have clear in our minds-not the least reason being that the proposed new section as printed refers to inquiries `one of whose purposes' is to look at these various matters.

Does the Minister believe that this requirement would be satisfied if in terms of any inquiry established for alleged environmental purposes he were simply to add to the terms of reference of such an inquiry a term of reference which says, `Whether in relation to the findings of any of the above the Commonwealth should consider placing the respective property before the World Heritage Committee for possible inclusion on the World Heritage List'? In other words, if an inquiry were looking at land use management in the southern part of New South Wales and one simply put in as a minor term of reference paragraph (f) or (g) or something down the list, it would cover consideration of the potential World Heritage value of the area concerned. I believe that this is very important. Unless the procedure involved provides for the establishment of separate specific inquiries for each of the potential World Heritage nominations being considered, we shall find ourselves with an ambit claim operation, an Act of Parliament which will allow the Minister to establish inquiries which may not be public inquiries, and which may be established by executive act without the attention of the Parliament being specifically drawn to each of these on a case by case basis. I am extremely concerned about that matter and believe that it is not the proper way to proceed.

The second area in this clause which I address is the question of timing. As I read the clause there is no requirement that such an inquiry be completed within a specified period. It is certainly true that property is the subject of an inquiry only until the end of 42 days after the report has been given to the Minister and that property ceases to be in the same category seven days after the day on which the Commonwealth has been informed by the World Heritage Committee that the prospective nomination has been dealt with.

There seems to me to be no time limit imposed on the conduct of an inquiry under this part. So we could have a situation in which an inquiry takes 18 months to two years, because there is no statutory limit on the inquiry, and that area is taken within the ambit of the Minister's powers under this Act for the period the inquiry is in progress. Indeed, it seems to me that there is absolutely nothing that prevents another inquiry being set up. As soon as one inquiry has finished and the 42-day period has passed under subclause (2) of clause 3a, or the seven-day period has passed under subclause (3) of clause 3a, another inquiry may be put on foot, perhaps to look at a slightly different aspect of precisely the same property or precisely the same inquiry. I am certainly concerned that not enough attention is being paid to the time limit that ought to be imposed on inquiries of this sort.

I draw attention to some remarks made by His Honour Mr Justice Deane in the High Court of Australia in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry case. It seems to me that two passages of His Honour's judgment are important in this regard, particularly given the answers which have previously been given to Senator Watson on this clause. His Honour says:
When that question-
that is to say, the question of the proper use of the Commonwealth's external affairs power-

is fairly faced, the material before the Court leads inevitably to the conclusion that there has been no real effort made to confine the prohibitions of the overall protective regime, with the overriding of the ordinary rights of citizens and the ordinary jurisdiction of the State of Tasmania which it would involve, to activities which it might reasonably be thought represented some real actual or potential threat to what might properly be seen, for the purposes of the Convention as natural or cultural heritage.
Elsewhere His Honour says this in relation to the area which was being particularly examined:

Insignificant though those areas may be in the overall perspective from Canberra, their owners, few though they may be, are citizens whose lives and property are beyond the reach of the Parliament except to the extent authorized by a relevant grant of Commonwealth legislative power. Yet there was no effort by the Commonwealth to justify the application of the protective regime, with all its stringency, to those privately owned areas of freehold land. Indeed, at times in the argument, it seemed that the Commonwealth had not ascertained what the practical impact of the imposition of the restrictive regime would be on the lives and livelihood of those who own or use land within the protected areas for other than logging purposes.

This is quite central to this whole debate. This is a judge of the High Court of Australia saying, quite clearly, that he has the impression that the attitude of the Commonwealth is summed up in his phrase `insignificant though those areas may be in the overall perspective from Canberra'. Yet, under this regime, we find that the Minister's powers will be attracted, without limitation of time, because there has been established an inquiry which may be established without this Parliament being properly party to its establishment if the Minister proceeds on the basis of having some global and ongoing piece of legislation which will allow him to establish inquiries from time to time. This clause does not sufficiently give an indication as to whether there must be a specific inquiry for a specific area to be evaluated for possible declaration as identified property, nor does it give any protection in terms of the time limit within which that inquiry must be completed. I believe that both of those omissions are serious omissions from this clause. They are matters that need to be addressed, and on this I seek further advice from the Minister as to how he intends to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for the wording `the property is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth' is to ensure that there is parliamentary scrutiny of any inquiry that the Government chooses to institute. Otherwise there would have to be either a separate Act for each inquiry that the Government sought to hold, or a global Act, if you like, for a number of inquiries. Those inquiries would be established by regulation and therefore also subject to parliamentary scrutiny. So, there is certainly no attempt in the Bill to avoid that scrutiny. That would not be possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick asked about time limits. The difficulty there is that one does not know how long an inquiry will take. For example, the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests inquiry will proceed for something like one year. Given the scope of such an inquiry, it would be difficult to include a time limit in the Bill. One simply cannot judge the duration of an inquiry at the commencement of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue the point raised by Senator Puplick and initially responded to by the Minister. I thank the Minister for his comments, but I must say that I find his response to Senator Puplick to be deeply unsatisfactory. To reiterate the point of concern, Senator Puplick drew attention to the provision relating to identified property in proposed section 3a (1) (a) (i) of the Act, if the Bill becomes an Act, which states that identified property will be property which is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth whose purpose, or one of whose purposes, is to consider whether the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage. In response to Senator Puplick's question on that aspect, Senator Richardson said that it would be difficult, because of the uncertainty of the duration of inquiries, to set any time limit upon the period during which an inquiry that has been established-I shall return to the question of how it is established-should run. Although I understand the administrative point, if you like, that the Minister made, and I think it is a perfectly fair point, nevertheless I should hope the Minister would agree that it is deeply unsatisfactory that there should be an open-ended clause of this kind in a Bill of such draconian potential as this. I do not apologise for using the word `draconian', and I emphasise the word `potential'. After all, in recent years in this Parliament we have seen the development of what I think is a very proper practice with many Bills of including sunset clauses that are designed to meet what I think are the perfectly proper concerns of the citizens and of their parliamentary representatives that legislation that might be thought to be good at the time it is introduced must nevertheless be later reviewed by the Parliament. Of course, unless a Bill which contains a sunset clause is extended by further action of the Parliament, the Act terminates and ceases to have effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to Senator Richardson that the Government ought to think again about the open-ended nature of this clause. I will suggest some reasons why that might be so. I hope the Minister will accept that I do not wish to impute any ill motivations either to him or to his potential successors in this matter, but the plain fact of the matter is that when one has a clause of this kind it provides the Minister of the Crown of the day with the most enormous potential to blackmail-I hope that word will not be misunderstood-the people whose properties are involved in the proposal for an inquiry into the potential listing of such properties for World Heritage purposes.

Again, let me be very clear-if I have not already been so-that I am not imputing motivations of that kind to either the drafters of the Bill or the Minister in putting the Bill before the Parliament. What I am saying is that we live in an imperfect world and that there will come a time in the future of this country when this Bill will be used by a future Minister to put what I think in the circumstances-I do not want to use the word `blackmail' again, but I will use a lesser term-would be improper pressure on the people whose livelihoods are affected and whose other considerations, perfectly proper considerations, will be affected by the presence of an inquiry of this kind and by the fact that the inquiry will continue for some time. While such an inquiry is continuing those people are then subject to all the other constraints and possible penalties which the Bill provides, which we will come to when we deal with the clauses concerning those matters.

I have not a specific amendment to suggest. In any case, I would not presume to do so with Senator Puplick sitting beside me. However, I want to say with the deepest earnestness to the Minister that I really believe that this is an area in which the Government ought to show its bona fides by itself putting forward a proposal to limit the duration of any inquiry. Otherwise, as Senator Puplick has very clearly spelled out, we have a situation in which having first of all begun to discuss the possibility of an inquiry there is the possibility, because of the open-ended nature of this clause, to put improper pressure upon those affected by the inquiry not to protest against it, not to begin to call meetings such as we have seen up in Ravenshoe and places such as that in the Queensland tropical rainforests because if they do the Minister or one of his advisers can say, `You know what will happen if you start kicking up a fuss about the matter, don't you? The Minister will simply prolong the inquiry for five years, or 10 years if you want to kick up a real fuss'. We will get that kind of improper pressure brought to bear upon people whose livelihoods are affected. That is the first kind of improper pressure even before, so to speak, the inquiry actually gets under way.

The second kind of improper pressure-I think Senator Puplick already presaged this point in his earlier remarks; therefore I will not go over the point at undue length, it having been made by my colleague-can be brought to bear once the inquiry has been established because if there should be what the Minister or his advisers rightly or wrongly regard as untoward reaction against the inquiry, again of the kind which the Minister would certainly regard as untoward opposition in regard to the events in north Queensland recently, there is opportunity under this clause of the Bill for the Minister to bring improper pressure to bear on the people concerned. It is possible for him to say, `If you are going to behave like this, to protest and to write letters to the newspaper, to call public meetings and to abuse the Government or to do any of those things that I as Minister think you should not be doing'-even though they are perfectly legal and proper activities on the part of citizens in a free country-`it will be open to me to extend the inquiry'. Again, I am not referring to the present Minister or any of his advisers. I am referring to the potential which the Bill creates. There will be opportunity for that Minister or his advisers to say, `All right, you have asked for it. What we are going to do is to extend the inquiry for another period by adding another piece onto it. I am going to put in another term of reference. I will add another two terms of reference'. I see that the Minister is nodding. I am glad to have his assent to the point of principle which I raise. I take it that that is what he is assenting to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the problem.

—I appreciate that. Since the Minister has indicated that he does understand the point being made, I will not detain the Committee any longer. However, I repeat: it is not just a case of understanding the point; it is a case of doing something about it-that is, removing from the Bill the open-ended nature of this provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason the Bill does not provide for the Minister simply to set up an inquiry is to make sure that Parliament has the scrutiny that it would require. I envisaged that if in the future a Minister wanted to set up an inquiry, it would be up to the Parliament, at the time a Bill was presented here for that purpose, to look at that sort of time limit it was thought necessary. If one looks at an inquiry into World Heritage areas that we have now, one could imagine that an inquiry into an area as large as Kakadu could take a very long time and a 12-month time limit might be appropriate. Then again, it might be possible to complete an inquiry into an area such as Lord Howe Island in a very much shorter time. I always envisaged that the Parliament, when it was setting up an inquiry, would look to that question each time it came up.
