—Mr Temporary Chairman, are you putting the gag on the question of the allocation of time?
—The question that the question be now put is the motion before the Chair, and I have to put that motion without debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Gareth Evans is insisting on the gag, pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of standing order 407b be suspended as would prevent the motion being debated without limitation of time and each Senator speaking for the time allocated by Standing Orders.

It is really not surprising that a Bill to establish Richardson's greenshirts should be put through here on the basis of Evans's jackboots. That is precisely what is occurring on this occasion, aided and abetted by those alleged proponents of the democratic process, the Australian Democrats-sitting there as the fourth organised faction of the Australian Labor Party, once again seeking to truncate debate and demonstrating their view, along with Senator Vallentine, another great proponent of peace and harmony and doing things the right way, that this piece of legislation, which is important to the lives of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australian citizens, should be jackbooted through this place without proper opportunity for debate. It is no real wonder, I suppose, given the strife in which the Australian Labor Party finds itself at the moment.

After the `Unslide' in New South Wales we now have Senator Richardson doing his very best to get out of all sorts of trouble. After all, it was Senator Richardson who was responsible in the first place for the execution of the then Minister for Sport, Mr John Brown, who was then responsible for making sure that Mick Young got his, and who was then responsible for making sure that Mr Unsworth did not continue as Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales. We now see on the front page of this morning's Australian, `Richardson warns Hawke to lift his game'. It is certainly true that an awful lot of people around here need to lift their game. Senator Richardson certainly needs to lift his game as far as his attitude towards World Heritage listing is concerned and as far as this piece of legislation is concerned. Senator Evans certainly needs to lift his game around here. He has come in here and not only proposed the guillotine on an important piece of legislation but also sought to have the guillotine arrangements themselves put on the basis of the gag.

I ask the members of the Australian Democrats in particular, regardless of the guillotine motion: When did they welsh formally on their promise not to support gag motions? That is what they have now done. Not only have they supported the guillotine but also they are now supporting a gag motion. They are properly sitting where they actually belong in this chamber-on the other side with Senator Vallentine and all the other ratbags in this Parliament. It is no wonder that heavies such as Senator Reynolds and Senator Zakharov have been sent over there to make sure that they do not move-no wonder at all as far as this matter is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —We just want to cut down the debate.
—Now we even have Senator Collins saying that he is about to go over there and add his substantial weight to the argument.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as debate on this Bill is concerned, it is important to understand that lengthy and significant debate in this chamber is part of the process whereby the people of Australia can be kept informed of precisely what the Government is doing and, in particular, what the Government is doing to them. We had in the case of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill the opportunity to expose, through lengthy debate in this place, all the manifest faults of that piece of legislation, which led to sufficient public interest and pressure being generated for the Government to withdraw that legislation. We have called upon the Government to defer this legislation and to withdraw it. The reason that the Government does not want it debated any further is that it knows that the provisions in the legislation about inspectors, about inquiries and about penalties-$1,000 penalties and 12 months imprisonment penalties-is the sort of information that it does not want clearly on the public record, that it does not want people to know about.

The Government's only urgency in respect of this piece of legislation is that it appears it wants it in the House of Representatives. Today's blue Daily Program for the House of Representatives already refers to the `Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill'. In other words, the House of Representatives Daily Program makes the situation quite clear because it says:
Speaker to read message from the Senate transmitting Bill for concurrence. First reading.
It then goes on:
Second reading, by leave; committee; adoption of report; third reading, by leave.

You know what that means, Mr Temporary Chairman. It means that as soon as this Bill is jackbooted through the Senate, it will be taken across King's Hall and gagged down the throat of the House of Representatives to ensure that it becomes legislation with a minimum amount of public debate and scrutiny. That is the purpose for which Senator Evans has introduced the guillotine motion and moved the gag on the guillotine motion itself.

Senator Evans sits there smiling in the way he does about all these things, in the sure and certain knowledge that with the Australian Democrats in his pocket he has nothing to worry about on this matter. The only occasion on which one sees Senator Evans smiling in this place is when he is absolutely sure that his wholly-owned subsidiaries are behaving the way they should. These $1.50 Democrats-that is what they are; that is the smallest sum that one can get with 30 pieces of silver-have forgotten all their high principles about parliamentary scrutiny and debate and once again they are welshing on their responsibilities in this matter. There is absolutely no reason to do anything other than expose the role of the Australian Democrats in this debate. After all, they are beholden to the Australian Labor Party, not only for their preferences but in Western Australia they also get the ALP to pay for their how-to-vote cards. We know precisely what is being done on this particular occasion.

There is no reason why the gag motion should have been moved on the question of the allocation of time. After all, if we had sought to debate the allocation of time for an hour or more we would simply have been removing that amount of time from the debate on the legislation itself. We would have been depriving ourselves of the time. However, there is a considerable principle as to whether Senator Evans, as Manager of Government Business, will now make a regular habit of the use of the gag motion when he has already secured passage of the declaration of the Bill as an urgent Bill and when he has already quite clearly indicated that he would have the Australian Democrats' support to provide for the 12.45 p.m. cut-off for the remainder of the stages of this debate. There is no need to proceed with the gag motion on this matter unless Senator Evans is signalling to us that that is the way in which he intends to proceed and the Democrats are also signalling that they propose to support gag motions whenever it happens to suit their convenience to close down debate. One thing that has been traditionally said about debates in this place is that, even given the use of the guillotine, the gag has not been a significant feature of the Senate's parliamentary procedure. It is to be clearly indicated that the Australian Democrats have now resiled from that point of view.

It is no wonder that the Government wants to close down this debate. It is in a state of total disarray at the moment. It has not heeded the words of Senator McMullan that ALP members should all stop criticising each other and apportioning blame around the place. A whole series of people in New South Wales will undoubtedly be the next ones on the gravy train, looking for jobs. After all, this piece of legislation allows for the establishment of inspectors. There are about 11 former Ministers in New South Wales and a whole herd of backbenchers who would probably make extremely good inspectors under this legislation. They are certainly not fit to be employed for anything else and they are certainly only fit to be employed in the sorts of tactics that Senator Richardson has put together here.

The gag motion also gives the Government the opportunity to avoid facing up to the substantial problems that it has within its own Party. In this morning's Australian Financial Review is an article headed `Labor at loggerheads on heritage' in which we find that Mr Eaton, apparently the Opposition spokesman on land management and forestry in Queensland and a member of the Australian Labor Party, has been writing to Senator Richardson. Indeed, by the look of it he has been writing to just about anyone capable of reading saying, amongst other things, that the claim made by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) about the widespread consultation on this legislation is absolutely false. Mr Eaton is quoted as saying:
Not once, to my knowledge, did the Federal Government seek advice or opinions from members of the Queensland ALP or Parliamentary Leader or Members of State Parliament . . .

Probably the Government could not find which branch of the Labor Party in Queensland to ask. It certainly did not know that there were enough members of the Labor Party in Queensland to ask; and with the revolving door it probably did not know which leader's name to put on the letter! Mr Eaton questioned the credibility of the Hawke Government's previous claim that it was willing to negotiate with the Bjelke-Petersen Government on the issue of World Heritage listing. He said that if the listing were pushed through, based on the existing boundaries, it would severely embarrass the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation. Mr Eaton went on to urge Senator Richardson to adopt the Queensland Opposition's policy-the Labor Party's policy in Queensland-which is, after all, for controlled logging of the area. Mr Eaton said that the view which the Queensland Labor Party would take on this matter was precisely the same as that which the Opposition parties have been urging on the Government throughout. The article continues:
Mr Eaton's letter, according to political sources, reflects the deep-rooted concern within the State ALP over the impact of Federal policies and issues on the party's fortunes in the north.

I will tell honourable senators something: the Labor Party's fortunes in the north are pretty bleak as far as this matter is concerned. It is absolutely no wonder that across the whole of northern Australian there is a revulsion at the way in which the Australian Labor Party is behaving. That is probably the reason that Senator Jenkins has suddenly found this weird and wonderful idea of establishing another State across the whole of north Australia so that the Government can try to quarantine the problems. But honourable senators opposite will not get away with that any more than they will get away with putting a guillotine motion and then a gag motion in this chamber and then forcing through a piece of legislation which, as I quoted from the judgment of Mr Justice Deane in the High Court, substantially ignores the rights of individuals and which prejudices the livelihood of people not only in north Queensland but also in Tasmania and anybody else threatened by the establishment of the inquiries which are proposed under this legislation. No wonder the Government does not want this matter discussed and debated and no wonder it does not want the draconian provisions of this legislation clearly exposed to public scrutiny. It knows that when this happened with the Bill of Rights it was forced to back off. It was forced to withdraw that legislation because of the public pressure that was placed upon it.

Senator McLean and his colleagues suddenly say that there is no need for lengthy and urgent debate. But when the Australia Card Bill was debated, Senator McLean was as anxious as anybody to keep it going and going for as long as possible and he complained at every attempt by the Government to close down that debate. This selective morality about what should and should not be debated is typical of the way in which these $1.50 Democrats behave in this chamber. It is no wonder that the Government wishes to truncate this debate as quickly as possible; it is no wonder that it wants to get it into the House of Representatives where, once again, brutal force of numbers will be used to ensure that there is not adequate debate on an important piece of legislation. I assure the Minister that, with the contingent notices of motion which are there, if he wants to spend 2 1/2 hours going through all of those, we could do so. We are not going to do that because we will get back to debating the clauses of this Bill that are available. I indicate to the Minister that if he is going to make a habit of the gag motion on these sorts of things, the contingent notices of motion on that Notice Paper will ensure that we will prevent the Government and its lackeys in the Australian Democrats from riding roughshod over the right of the Senate to debate in a proper and coherent fashion significant pieces of legislation that are important to the people of Australia. I am more than--
Government senators-Eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one, zero!

TALK.START.PARA: —Missed again! You see, even on the occasion of its own jackbooting of legislation the Government could not get the numbers right.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —After 10 hours of debate on the second reading of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, after 2 3/4 hours debate already at the committee stage of the Bill, with another 1 3/4 hours still to go at the committee stage of the Bill-if Senator Puplick shuts up and the Opposition does not waste any more time in dividing-and with 1 April as the date on which the Daintree will be decimated unless this Bill is passed through the House of Representatives today-after all those things and bearing those things in mind-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: My point of order is that standing order 407 be applied. That provides that the urgency motion is in two stages. The first motion must be put without debate but the second point, the time allotted for urgency, is debated for one hour with as many speakers as we like having 10 minutes each.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Gareth Evans has moved the closure of the debate, and that is the question I shall put now.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have moved that the question about the allotment of time until 12.45 be now put.

—I wish to raise a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. I seek your ruling as to whether the motion that the question be now put is a competent motion to be put in regard to standing order 407b, which provides that on motions with regard to the allotment of time no debate should be allowed for more than one hour. In other words, there is a presumption that there will be debate on that matter. My point is whether it is within the standing order for the Minister to move the motion that the gag be now put on matters arising under standing order 407b.

—Further to the point of order, I submit clearly that it is an outside time limit and that it is competent for the Senate in the ordinary way for debate on that motion, like any other, to be closed within the time frame involved.

—Further to the point of order, after a careful reading of standing order 407b, I submit that the latter part of it says explicitly that up to a period of one hour shall be allowed for debate on the motion of the Minister. I am surprised that a Minister who has some pretensions to an education in law should so falsify the word of Standing Orders that he should seek to mislead the Senate and the Parliament on such a fundamental and clear issue. The other point that supports my argument arises from standing order 281. It is presumably from that standing order that the Minister is trying to draw some strength or is clutching at straws. But no careful reading of standing order 281 allows an interpretation to be put that overrides the final stages of standing order 407b. I submit, Mr Temporary Chairman, that you have no option but to allow debate for up to one hour if we choose to exercise that right.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not accept that point of order. From custom and practice in the past a precedent has been set on this issue-namely, that the question moved by the Minister be put. I shall put that question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the motion for the allotment of time be agreed to.
—On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman, I formally move dissent from the ruling of the Chair. In speaking to that motion, I am very conscious of the shortage of time--
—Order! There is no ruling from the Chair. The honourable senator cannot move dissent from a ruling of the Chair when there is no ruling from the Chair.

—I understand that there was a question before the Chair, moved by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate, that the motion be put. The Chair accepted that that was a valid motion, against my objections. I am moving dissent from your ruling on that point.

—On the same point of order: It is not in order for a senator, while the Temporary Chairman is in the middle of putting a motion, to take a point of order, which is not actually a point of order, and then move a motion. Any honourable senator who wants to move a motion must be recognised by the Chair. Mr Temporary Chairman, you did not recognise him on the point of moving a motion; you recognised him only on the basis that he was rising on a point of order. That cannot be used by a senator as a device simply to get the attention of the Chair and then to launch off in some other area. Mr Temporary Chairman, you were half-way through putting the question and I suggest that that process, having been begun, has to be completed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: The Chair was putting to the Committee the question that the motion for the limitation of time be agreed to. Senator MacGibbon's point of order is seeking a dissent from a ruling of the Chair, but there is no ruling from the Chair. The matter before the Committee is that the question be agreed to. There is no point of order. The question is that the motion for the limitation of time be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 5 (Identified property).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed new section 3a (1) (a) (i) states:

SPEECH.PARA: the property is subject to an inquiry established by a law of the Commonwealth whose purpose, or one of whose purposes, is to consider whether the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage;

Does that mean the whole of the time of an inquiry before its final report as stated in proposed new section 3a (2) which deals with an inquiry's final report? The Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests, which was instigated by the Government, ordered that certain areas in Tasmania be allowed to be logged because their value was not recognised by that Commission. Does that mean that the area which is presently being logged will no longer be allowed to be logged on request? Proposed new section 3a (2) states:

For the purposes of subparagraph (1) (a) (i), property shall be taken to be subject to an inquiry of the kind referred to in that subparagraph until the end of 42 days after the report, or the final report . . .

Will the area that Mr Helsham allowed to be logged no longer be allowed to be logged while an inquiry is going on-as the Minister said, perhaps for 12 months or more-because a final report has not been presented?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests had been asked to report by a certain date on some aspects of its inquiry. It did so. As I recall it, that included four plots that were within the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests area that were said to be not of sufficient value. I do not have the Commission's precise words with me, obviously. Under this Act, the Government would have 42 days to consider that report and make its intentions known. So protection for these areas would not have continued beyond that time.

—Is the Minister saying that we do not have to wait for the final report in this instance? The Helsham Commission of Inquiry could make an interim report and that report would be considered in the same way as a final report?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct. In the setting up of any future inquiry, should any future inquiry be deemed to be necessary, no doubt that would be made clear in the legislation that set up the inquiry. In other words, if we wanted interim reports on particular parts we could have a time scale put into the Bill to make sure that that problem did not arise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 5 and the amendments to section 3 in the principal Act. Proposed new section 3a (3) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether before or after the commencement of this Act, as suitable for inclusion in the World Heritage List provided for in paragraph 2 of the Article-
that is, Article 11 of the World Heritage Convention-

the property shall be taken to be subject to World Heritage List nomination from the time of its submission until the end of 7 days after the day on which the Committee informs, or first informs, Australia that it has included or decided not to include the whole or any part of the property in the list.

I indicated during my speech in the second reading debate and when we were debating clause 1 yesterday that on three occasions the Minister, by implication, misled an international body in the nomination for the World Heritage listing. The implication is that agreement has been reached between the people who own the land and the Federal Government of Australia. I appreciate that nominations can be made only by the Federal Government, which is called the State by the World Heritage Committee. However, a critical part of World Heritage nomination is the ability to manage. Without the agreement of the Queensland State Government the Federal Government will not be able adequately to manage the property. Yet, on three occasions, the Minister has signed a document which implies that he has reached agreement with the Queensland Government. I have mentioned that there is a good possibility that the World Heritage Committee will come back and say, `We will not agree to it at this stage', because it knows that the thing cannot be managed without agreement. I understand that during the debate yesterday Senator Richardson gave a hint of what he means by that. His words were `a joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Governments is envisaged to assume responsibility for the administration of the property'. First, I should like to ask the Minister why he misled an international organisation? That is an embarrassment to every Australian. Secondly, was the Minister's implication yesterday that he would agree to pay compensation to individuals only if the Queensland Government agreed to what he was doing? In other words, he was using a blackmailing technique on the Queensland Government, which would affect the lives of many individuals in far north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what the last question had to do with proposed section 3a (3). However, to answer it, the question of compensation has nothing to do with blackmail. What I am saying is that it will not be possible to deliver some of the compensation without the cooperation of the Queensland Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall give some examples. If for instance, as part of the package, I was to come up with an idea for greatly increased plantation forestry on the tablelands, it may well be that the Government would need to negotiate with the Queensland Government for crown land for that purpose, or alternatively to purchase private land for that purpose. It would be impossible, for instance, to get an allocation of hoop pine resource to the Ravenshoe mill without the cooperation of the Queensland Government, because the hoop pine resource is owned by the Queensland Government. So, it has nothing to do with blackmail. If I have the money to provide compensation and jobs, it will in some cases, and probably in most cases, require the cooperation of the Queensland Government for me to hand over the money. That is why I said that. It has nothing to do with blackmail; it is a matter of logistics.

With regard to the continuing question of whether I have misled Parliament, the people, and indeed the world, I think we have to consider the actual words I used. I should have thought that the phrase `it is envisaged' does not mean `it has been done'-unless the Oxford English Dictionary has a new meaning of `envisaged' that has not been brought to my attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister is playing with words. He has made an application to an international organisation. Surely he would agree that from his choice of words that organisation would assume that ready agreement has been reached with the Queensland Government. It is clear that that has not happened and that the Minister has not even entered into decent discussions with the Queensland Government-notwithstanding the telex to the Prime Minister of Australia from the Premier of Queensland. An international organisation, on reading the words `it is envisaged', could be excused for thinking that agreement had been reached and the area could be managed. The Minister would have to agree that without the agreement of the Queensland Government, he cannot adequately manage that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Without the agreement of the Queensland Government it may not be possible to do all with management that I would like. However, to say that I could not manage the area is simply not true. With regard to Senator Parer's other comments, it must be remembered that when the Great Barrier Reef was nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List there was no management agreement in place. The Government of the day said that it was envisaged that it would obtain agreement, and it did.

—I should like to correct that. I have in front of me the nomination of the Great Barrier Reef to the World Heritage List. What the Minister said is quite incorrect. Agreement was reached. The Minister should read the management section.
—There was no management plan.

—I am sorry, Senator Richardson, but you are wrong. The relevant section says quite clearly that it will be managed in cooperation with the State Government. I do not have it in front of me, but it is here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not be surprised if the nomination said that it would be managed with the cooperation of the State Government. That is what the Federal Government expected and intended at the time. That is what I expect and intend now.

—I should like the Minister to confirm a number of matters in proposed section 3b. First, will a judge of the Family Court of Australia, being a court created by Parliament, be an eligible judge for the purposes of this section? Secondly, does the Minister propose to write to all members of the judiciary or only selected members of the judiciary to ask whether they will consent in writing to be nominated by the Minister for the purposes of this Act; or will the Minister circularise all judges and ask them to volunteer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet decided on what course of action to take in that respect.

—Will the Minister confirm my understanding that a judge of the Family Court of Australia, if he or she consents in writing to being nominated by the Minister, will be an eligible judge for the purposes of this section?
—Yes.

—Will the Minister say what his preference is? The public servants beside him are shaking their heads and saying that he has not yet decided. Cannot the Minister make the decision as to whether he will invite all judges to be nominated, or only those judges he particularly chooses?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probable that the first action to be taken will be for me to ask the Attorney-General to approach the chief judges of the courts in question.
—Does the Minister mean that the decision rests not with him but with the Attorney-General? That is not really what the legislation says.

—It is a question of obtaining the consent of the judges. I am not in such an exalted legal position that I consider myself to be the best person to go forth and obtain those consents. Consequently, it would be appropriate to use the Minister in charge of such matters, the Attorney-General. He is the logical person for me to approach. I shall discuss with him the best way of approaching the judges and obtaining their consents. Acting on the Attorney's advice, I will proceed. If the Attorney thought it best for him to approach the judges, it would be fine if he did. If he thought it best that I make the approach, I would. If he thought it best that the chief judges of the courts in question should do it, that is what would happen. I shall seek the advice of the Attorney-General. I do not believe there is anything improper or unusual in doing that.

—Will the Minister inform the Senate of the decision that is made: whether he intends to approach all judges, or only those judges he chooses, or whether the Attorney-General will approach all judges?

—As soon as I have had discussions with the Attorney-General I shall inform the Senate. Lest I be accused of misleading the Senate, I should add the rider that I have no doubt that the Attorney-General will wish to consult the chief judges of the courts in question and report back to me. So, I may not reply to the Senate as soon as I have talked to the Attorney-General; rather, as soon as he has completed the inquiries that he considers to be necessary, and reports back to me, then I shall inform the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 6 agreed to.
Clause 7 (Entry and search etc.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have considerable problems with the provisions on entry and search. As the clause stands, an inspector may go onto private property at any time of the day or night. The only restriction that the inspector has is that he cannot enter a person's home. He can stop and search a vehicle; he can walk around a property, take photographs, record occurrences in an eligible place, and examine and measure an eligible thing. Indeed, he can enter and search that property at will. The Minister is well aware that his party has a different philosophy from the Opposition regarding private property. I am quite well aware that he realises this; I am quite well aware that the Opposition realises this. The Opposition believes that the civil liberties of the individual are paramount. The Government believes that the interests of the community far outweigh the civil liberties of the individual. As verification of that, I would like to quote from a speech made by Dr Blewett to the South Australian Labor Party conference in June 1986 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . we shouldn't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.

It is very clear from that what the Labor Party's philosophy is. Notwithstanding that, I say that the Minister is out of touch-as he would agree-with the common people if he believes that at any time of the night or day an inspector, with no special qualifications and no special or necessary training-nothing at all except an identity card or badge given to him by the Minister-can enter and search private property. This person will be able to stop vehicles at any time of the night or day. Most of this inspecting will be done in isolated areas. At any time of the night or day such an inspector can, if he believes there is justification for his doing so carry out such investigations, even without a warrant. I believe that the Minister has overstepped the mark. I would like the Minister to explain to me why it is that he proposes to allow a stranger to enter private property without the knowledge or consent of its owner; why he would allow a stranger to wave down and stop a vehicle and demand to search that vehicle. What justification can the Minister possibly have for allowing such things to take place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will raise some of the same points raised by Senator Walters in the course of my contribution; so the Minister might find it convenient to reply at the one time to all of those points. Clause 7 of the Bill provides, in fact, for quite distinct and separate issues. Proposed new section 17 deals with compensation, section 17A with the power of inspectors, section 17B with penalties and section 17C with confidentiality. I will refer briefly to compensation and make two points about that. My first point relates to remarks made by Senator Collins in an earlier debate on 18 March. Having looked at Senator Collins's interpretation of compensation apropos the Northern Territory I must say that I would certainly want to qualify my earlier remarks about compensation arrangements in the Northern Territory. I think in fact that Senator Collins is correct in his comments about compensation in the Northern Territory in regard to acquisition. To that extent I stand corrected by Senator Collins in regard to that particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the issue of compensation is broader than one of simple acquisition. It goes very much to the question of what I think lawyers call injurious affection in terms of the value of property which, in fact, is affected by the whole procedure when it is not actually acquired. I believe that the Minister ought to explain whether the Commonwealth accepts any liability for any potential loss which arises, in terms of the value of properties, as a result of World Heritage listing in cases where, in fact, they are not actually acquired. That is the first point.

My second point is whether the Minister can explain why it has been thought necessary to provide such large maximum penalties under section 17B, namely, a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months or both. It really seems to me that if the Minister is serious about attempting only to gather information and not attempting to frighten people he would not be introducing such draconian legislation. A penalty as high as $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months or both is absolutely outrageous, even if it is a stated maximum penalty. In that respect I draw the Minister's attention to representations, which I think he will have already received, from the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties, which deal with the question of penalties. I think that the Minister would certainly accept the Council as an organisation which has been quite fearless whether in dealing with the Federal Government or the Queensland Government. The Council in its representations has stated that those fines and penalties are excessive and should be reduced. In fact, it suggests a much lower penalty regime.

The third area on which I seek the Minister's comments relates to the confidentiality provisions of section 17c. I would like to know whether section 17c (2) is to be read as meaning, in effect, that the Secretary to the Department may in fact authorise the disclosure of information to any officer of the Department or, indeed, whether it goes beyond the disclosure of information just to people in his Department. For instance, I would like to know whether the Secretary would be able to authorise the disclosure of information to, for example, an officer of the Attorney-General's Department or whether the disclosure is limited only to officers of the Department for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

Finally, I come to the search and entry matters raised by Senator Walters. If one were simply to take this part of the Bill on face value one would perhaps be drawn to the conclusion that there was some protection offered in this matter, namely, that an inspector would have to have reasonable grounds and, indeed, a warrant for search and entry. Of course, that is not the case. Section 17a (4) (c) (ii) provides that:

The entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant issued under subsection (5).

It really seems to me that what the Government has attempted to do here is to pad around an open-ended right of nominated inspectors to enter and do the various things which are nominated in section 17a (2)-that is, to `enter and search', `take photographs and record occurrences', `inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing'. In fact, at the end of the day that clause is totally open-ended. For all of the padding about reasonable grounds and all of the padding about warrants there lies in the centre of that particular arrangement the right of an inspector to enter a dwelling, even without reasonable grounds, if he believes the matter is of such seriousness and urgency as to require him to do certain things, without warrant or, more to the point, without the consent of the person concerned.

Again, I draw the Minister's attention to the representations he has received from the Council for Civil Liberties which have called for stricter safeguards in regard to these new search powers, which say that there should be a ground of reasonable necessity, that there ought to be a time limit on a warrant of no more than one month and that warrants exercised at night should be sought only where absolutely necessary and on rare occasions and that inspectors should be required to tape-record any relevant conversations. It goes on to demonstrate the extent to which, in a civil liberties sense, this is an outrage. The other day I spoke about the balance between the rights of individuals and the rights of a government to take the steps it believes are necessary for the protection of the natural environment. There is a quintessential point about all this because it says that at the end of the day, it is the power of an individual in everything except his own home. The clause does not say `his own home'; it says `a dwelling house'. It does not say anything else. It does not say that an inspector cannot enter a caravan or a structure which is not a dwelling house. It is quite specific. It does not say `a dwelling' or `a place of residence'; it says, `a dwelling house'. Presumably, that means something in law. A house, presumably, means precisely that. There are certain dwelling places which are not houses. For instance, if a timber worker lives in a shack in the bush, is that shack classed as a dwelling house?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—The Minister says that it is a dwelling house. If a person lives in a tent, is that a dwelling house?
—Probably.

—The Minister says, `Probably'. I am afraid, Minister, that `probably' is not good enough. The clause could easily have said `a dwelling' but, no, it is specific; it says `a dwelling house'. Presumably, that has a particular meaning and a particular purpose. If it does not, the word `house' should be taken out, leaving the clause with the word `dwelling'. At least that would increase marginally the right of some people.
—What about Aboriginals and their residences?

—My colleague Senator Tambling is quite correct in drawing my attention to this, prompting me to ask-undoubtedly Senator Collins would be able to tell us about this-are all places in which Aboriginals reside dwelling houses, or would we not use the term `house' for some of the accommodation in which Aboriginal people dwell and reside on a permanent basis?
—What about caravans?

—Senator Walters asks whether a caravan is a dwelling house for the purpose of this proposed section. The Minister has a responsibility to address those matters, in particular whether the whole thing is as open-ended as the legislation, on its face, clearly indicates that it is; whether a `dwelling house' has the meaning which I have ascribed to it, and whether the officers of the Department are officers of the Department only for which the Minister is responsible or whether there are other officers in other departments to whom information can be given. Presumably, they would have to be given access to the information if prosecutions were to be launched under this proposed section. Perhaps the Minister will explain to me whether, if a prosecution is to be launched, it means that the material in the possession of the Secretary to his Department, gathered as a result of the work of the inspectors, is not to be made available to the Director of Public Prosecutions or the Attorney-General's Department for the purpose of advising on the question of a prosecution. If that is so, it is an absolute nonsense. But that is what sub-section (2) of proposed section 17c says. Having raised those matters, I shall await the Minister's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to pursue one or two of the points which have been made already by Senator Walters and Senator Puplick. In doing so, I refer the Minister to the extraordinarily wide manner in which the Bill is drawn in the area which the Committee is discussing. The power of the corps of inspectors-I think that they are to be called Richardson's greenshirts-are defined under the entry and search provisions of this clause of the Bill. I note that, under what will be section 17a (2) of the amended Act, an inspector may, for an eligible purpose-I emphasise the words `eligible purpose'-do a number of things. He may:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) enter and search an eligible place;
(b) take photographs and record occurrences in an eligible place; and-
the occurrences are completely undefined-
(c) inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing.
Again, I emphasise the words `eligible thing'. Later, under sub-section (10) of what will be section 17a of the amended Act, the terms `eligible purpose' and `eligible thing' are defined. It says:
`eligible purpose' means the purpose of:
(b) obtaining information that may be relevant to the making of a Proclamation, or a regulation, under this Act;

The words `that may be relevant' are extraordinarily wide. Yet, for the purpose of obtaining information that may be relevant, an inspector appointed under the amended Act will have extremely wide powers to enter and search, to take photographs and record occurrences and to inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing. `Eligible thing'-the other term defined in sub-section 10 of proposed section 17a-means anything prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of the definition.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very common.

—It may be a very common way of describing these things, but the point is that it does not ordinarily occur within the context of an Act which appoints a corps of inspectors who will have these extraordinarily wide and draconian powers to enter upon people's property-not their dwelling house; however that may be defined-and to search, enter, take photographs, examine, measure, et cetera. That is the point. Of course it is a drafting provision. What I point out is that it is a drafting provision in a particular context. I hope that Senator Collins was not suggesting, by way of interjection, that people in the Northern Territory will be in any way relaxed about the possible consequences of this provision for people operating there who may be affected by it.
—People in the Territory can have their things seized under about 20 Acts now.
—Of course they can.

—I am interested to hear that Senator Collins and the Minister imply, by way of interjection-I do not want to put it more strongly than that-that they are perfectly relaxed about the way in which such powers will be open to abuse by inspectors appointed under the Act.
—I am not saying that.

—I hope that he is not saying that. I would be surprised if he were. What I am saying to the Minister is that, given the extremely wide drafting and the context in which that drafting occurs, such powers will be available. As the committee is perfectly well aware, once those powers are available they are open to be used and almost certainly will be used. That is a matter of very serious concern. I will not dwell further on that point because I can seen that the Minister will not shift his position, notwithstanding that I predict that this Bill will bring more opprobrium on the Minister's own head and on that of this Government than any other piece of legislation which has been introduced, even by this Government, in the last five years. The Minister may or may not want to react to that comment. I am not seeking a reaction; I am simply stating a view.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I turn to the provisions in the Bill about confidentiality; not because I object to the provisions about confidentiality-on the contrary, I strongly support those provisions-but because they flag and highlight, again, the extraordinarily intrusive powers which the Bill will provide to an inspectorate appointed by a political person-a Minister of the Crown. I make it clear that I am not referring, as I did in my earlier intervention before we were placed under the guillotine, to the present Minister; I am referring to a Minister of the Crown, at some time or other, who will have, because of the powers accorded to him by the Bill, should it be enacted, powers which will enable his inspectors to seek and obtain information from persons or corporations affected by the Bill and who will then, notwithstanding the confidentiality provisions of the Bill, be empowered to provide that information to the Minister. What the Minister then does with it is up to the Minister.

We saw in the House of Representatives only yesterday the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) making use of information for personnel files from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to blacken the name of an ex-ambassador of Australia who has had the temerity to write a book in which he criticises the Minister. I do not have any brief for the particular ex-Foreign Affairs official concerned-Dr James Cumes. In my previous capacity I happen to have disagreed on many occasions with Dr Cumes's views on foreign economic policy issues. But I believe that the action of the Minister in having his minions provide him, from the recesses of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade personnel section, with intimate details relating to what was said about the career of Dr Cumes by a particular selection committee which sat upon an application that Dr Cumes was making for a job and which the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come back to the Bill.

—I will come back to the clause. But I am making a point in relation to this clause of the Bill which sets down the kind of abuse of process which we saw in the House of Representatives yesterday in the case that I have just cited and which will be open to any future Minister, including this one. The process can be employed in this instance and information can be gathered by Richardson's greenshirts and conveyed to the Minister without any fear of punishment, as a result of the indemnification given to them by this clause of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in respect of the compensation clause. Many sawmilling companies in north Queensland that will be forced to close down within the next two or three weeks, or maybe within a month or so-and I ask the Minister to give me his attention because this is a fairly significant problem that will have to be faced by the sawmillers-will have to pay off their staff. They will have to meet their obligations in respect of holiday pay, long service pay, sick pay and all sorts of other payments. This is going to place many of the sawmills in a financially embarrassing position. They will have to seek either accommodation from their banks or some other type of funding arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the Minister will be paying compensation to the sawmills. But, before compensation comes through, quite an amount of money will be required to meet the sawmillers' commitments to pay the workers out. I understand from inquiries that I have had from north Queensland that some type of fund needs to be set up by the Minister from which sawmillers can draw money to meet their commitments to their workers as they lose their jobs. Will the Minister's Government provide money for a compensation fund from which the sawmill proprietors can meet their commitments before they are compensated by the Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I want to raise a couple of matters with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). Senator Puplick has referred to the penalties under this Bill. As I indicated earlier, one of the Minister's greenshirts in an isolated area could be told that he should hand in his identity card because, perhaps, he has committed some offence. An inspector who does not hand in his ID card will be liable, under this legislation, to a penalty of only $100. Let us suppose that an inspector has accosted a woman and has not handed in his card. On a lonely road at 2 a.m.-I drew this analogy during my speech in the second reading debate-he may demand entry to a vehicle which is being driven by a woman. If the woman does not open the door of her car she is liable to be fined a maximum of $1,000. Meanwhile, the inspector is subject to a maximum penalty of only $100. How does the Minister equate these two penalties? The whole thing is ridiculous.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other brief comment I would make relates to the clause on confidentiality which was debated by Senator Stone and Senator Puplick. This Government does not have a clue about privacy. Indeed, it believes that privacy is a bourgeois right. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, said that we should not get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy in many ways is a bourgeois right which is associated with the right to private property. They do not know what privacy means. On four separate occasions Minister Blewett's Department has been caught giving out private information on individual doctors. I ask Senator Richardson whether the buck will stop with him as regards confidentiality in this Bill. It certainly does not stop with the Minister for Community Services and Health. Will Senator Richardson take responsibility for any breach by his Department of the confidentiality clause of this Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are quite a number of things to answer. I hope that I get to all of them. I am sure that honourable senators opposite will remind me if I do not. A number of honourable senators have raised the question of draconian power. I thought that I had covered this yesterday. I thought that I had put into perspective yesterday how little power in fact inspectors under this legislation get in comparison with the powers given under an enormous number of other pieces of legislation-not only Commonwealth legislation but, more importantly, legislation in a number of States.

SPEECH.PARA: I referred yesterday, but I want to mention it again, to the Queensland Government's National Parks and Wildlife Act. Section 56 of that Act gives the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, his officers and employees, the power to enter any land or waters at any time, without previous notice, without warrant, to inspect forest products or for any national park purpose. This Bill goes nowhere near the sort of power that the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service has already.

I mentioned yesterday in regard to the beloved Tasmania of Senator Walters just how much further Tasmanian Acts go than the legislation before us. In particular, the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Act gives authorised officers the power to seize anything-that is what it says in the Act-on reasonable grounds suspected of being taken contrary to the provisions of the Act. It gives them the power to search any premises, including private homes and vehicles. As I mentioned, it gives them the power of arrest without warrant even for failure to give full name and address. That is what I call draconian legislation. I wonder just how often Senator Walters has attempted to undo that legislation in her home State? I suspect never, because she could not care less. But when she comes here, she stands up and screams about the legislation.

When I spoke yesterday I referred to a number of Acts. I mentioned bananas in relation to Western Australia. I want to go further than bananas today. I want to go through chooks and move on to artificial breeding. This is important stuff. If one looks at the powers of veterinary surgeons of the State Department of Agriculture in Western Australia, one sees that they are able to enter and inspect licensed premises at any time. Let me read these deep and meaningful words to honourable senators:
They can enter and inspect any licensed premises and examine any semen or ova found on the premises.
That is a bit of a worry, but that sort of act is commonplace around the country.

As far as this `reasonable time' argument is concerned, let us look at chooks in Western Australia. Under the Poultry Industry (Trust Fund) Act 1948, they must make entry at a reasonable time. That is the only place where I could find this provision, but that is all right because in the premises where chooks are kept, the lights are on all day. Time does not mean a lot to the chooks; they do not know when night and day have come and gone.

The references to these Acts, not to mention the Carnarvon Banana Industry (Compensation Trust Fund) Act 1961, to which I referred yesterday, suggest that there are literally hundreds of such Acts right around the country which give inspectors of all kinds much more power than this Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 would ever dream of doing. In fact, I can assure Senator Walters that the next time a badge-flashing person accosts her in her vehicle in a remote place it will not be one of Richardson's greenshirts; it will be any one of a number of officers who have been given such powers by the Tasmanian authorities. In fact, as I understand it, they are dressed in brown shirts, which I cannot really object to although there may be a matter of aesthetics involved. I would have thought that Senator Walters might have complained before this about the truly draconian powers that those people have-powers which I have not sought for inspectors in this Bill.

I try to stay away from draconian powers and that has always been the Australian Labor Party's position. In fact, this Bill is a classic example of just how far I have gone to make sure that draconian powers are not placed in legislation. There is nothing unusual about giving inspectors the power to have a look. In this case if they do not have a warrant and do not have consent to have a look, then any act that they take as a matter of judgment is obviously testable in a court. I have no doubt that there are many who would test it in a court if they thought an inspector was being unreasonable. One might ask: `Why should they have a look at all?'. We are attempting to ensure that `eligible things' are not being removed from premises, but that will be pretty hard to do if an inspector does not have the power to have a look and make sure that he or she knows what is on the premises. This is not draconian; it is entirely reasonable.

As honourable senators will be aware, logging can sometimes be difficult to detect from the air. If it was going on and was against the Act, then the difficulty would be that there could be any number of access routes into a forest area. It will be pretty hard to check on the timber once it has gone and so it may well be necessary for an inspector to go to a mill and have a look to see if there is any identifiable material. Often under a licence in those forests-Senator Boswell is the expert on this-there are marked trees and it will not be too hard to identify an area. If those markings are not there, then perhaps the Commonwealth will have some reason to act.

We have heard a lot about the penalties. The $1,000 and 12-month imprisonment penalties are standard across the whole welter and gamut of Commonwealth and State legislation. There is nothing at all unusual in them. I have not noticed complaints about them in the past. These penalties are included in the Sea Installation Act and the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act, but they have created no furore or discussion in this place. No one seems to complain when these provisions are placed in other Acts, yet in this legislation they are regarded as draconian and terrible. The reality is that they are normal provisions.

Senator Boswell and Senator Puplick asked some questions about compensation. Before these amendments the Commonwealth had no legal liability for the compensation of the people to whom Senator Boswell referred and it does not have it now. And yet the Commonwealth provided considerable compensation to Tasmania in the Franklin Dam case. I am about to present to the Cabinet a submission for compensation for north Queensland. Obviously I am not in a position to go through what is in that submission now; that will have to wait until I have been to Cabinet. I will then announce it quickly, not only to Senator Boswell but also to the people of north Queensland. Details will be known within the next few weeks so there will not be a long wait. I will be delighted once it is announced because it is something that we have been working hard on for a long time. The terms under which compensation will be given in the Act only refer to times when the actions of the Commonwealth amount to acquisition. Hopefully we will not see too much of that. We have not yet attempted, and I am not in the process of attempting, to do anything of that nature. Nonetheless, if it does occur, the Act greatly simplifies the procedures and makes it easier for anyone so affected. So I do not think that section is a problem.

Senator Puplick raised an interesting point about `dwelling house'. Obviously, the Government intends to treat `dwelling house' and `dwelling' in the same way. One would imagine that that could be done administratively. I do not see that it is necessary to put it in the Bill. It is a term that has been used in other legislation; this is not the only legislation that uses it. The Oxford Dictionary refers to a dwelling house as something used as a residence, not an office. That does not necessarily help us with the question of tents and caravans and when dealing with it administratively we will have to make sure that those questions are dealt with properly. They are not questions which will be greatly discussed in the coming months. There are probably matters of greater importance with which we must deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate very long. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) skipped over the question of compensation very quickly. He told us that there would be special compensation for Queensland. However, as I pointed out last night in this chamber, I am worried that the Shark Bay area and the Kimberleys are on the hit list. It will not be long before the people in those areas are asked to move. The Minister skipped over that very conveniently.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick asked about the viability of properties that were partly taken over. I point out that if the Government pays the market values for these properties the owners will have to move. They may find that there are no other suitable places on the market to which they can move. People will not take the market price if they are being shifted so that the Government can take over their properties. There are a lot of problems associated with this. If a pastoralist has to move to a completely new area, he has to learn about that area. That could be five or 10 years down the track. I ask the Minister to look at those questions because he very conveniently skipped over them. Unfortunately, by moving to gag us the Australian Democrats did not help us to bring all this out. They will answer for that in due course when we come to an election. That is all I want to say. I shall let Senator Puplick have the rest of the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want an answer from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) about transfer of information to public servants other than those in his own Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as transfer of information is concerned, I did not answer that question before and I apologise. I was not trying to duck the question. I had a number of things to answer and I forgot.

SPEECH.PARA: At the present time this legislation will provide penalties for an inspector who publishes information-in the true sense of the word `publish'-to anyone apart from me, the Secretary to the Department or officers of the Department. I should say `the Minister'; it might not be me. Things do change in this world.

Proposed new section 17c (3) of the legislation will provide that the Minister, Secretary or the officers can only pass on information for the purposes of the Act. One would imagine that if one is passing on information for the purposes of the Act it would be to the Attorney-General's Department for a prosecution. That is certainly not prevented. That is the only circumstance when I can pass on that information. I hope that answers Senator Puplick's question.

I want to say a couple of things about Senator Panizza's remarks. It is not a matter of carefully or quickly skipping over any discussion of compensation. The reason I am not going into a long discussion on compensation is that it has nothing whatever to do with the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill. This is the Bill we are addressing; this is the Bill we are trying to get through. The questions the honourable senator is asking do not go to it. I thought I had explained reasonably clearly where this Bill refers to compensation and why. I did not skip over that. Senator Panizza is asking questions way outside the ambit of the Bill.

The other point, which I know has been made by honourable senators in the second reading debate and in the two-hour debate on clause 1 last night, is this so-called hit list, all these areas that are supposedly lining up for inclusion on the World Heritage List. At the present time only two areas are under any sort of active consideration. One is Shark Bay in Western Australia. So far as I am aware, the active consideration has meant a meeting with the Western Australian Minister at which he said the Western Australian Government at that point in time had not been able to resolve the question of pastoral leases and therefore it did not want me to proceed with the nomination at this point. I have not done so. In fact, I await that Government's advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —One law for your mates in the west and another law for your mates in Queensland.

—The difference with the people in that Government in Western Australia is that they are prepared to talk about these things. That is the big difference. The Government is not looking at any proposal for the Kimberleys-none whatsoever. There is a suggestion that Bungle Bungle might be an appropriate area. It is no more than a suggestion at the moment; it is not under active consideration. The only other possibility in the country that I have been requested to look at is an alpine park that would straddle New South Wales and Victoria, to see whether such a park would be suitable for inclusion on the list. I have already said that that would have to be carefully looked at because I am not certain yet that the area is of sufficient quality. There just is not a hit list beyond that.
—The ACF's hit list.

—That is not mine; it is not the Government's. I cannot stop any citizen from wanting the whole of Australia put on the World Heritage List; some do. However, that is not my agenda. I have just told the honourable senator honestly what the Government's agenda is. If that agenda changes, I am more than happy to make it public because there is no way we will be creeping up on anyone with a World Heritage nomination. Honourable senators will all hear about it long before it happens.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 8 and 9-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just make it clear in relation to clause 7 that I did not divide the Committee but the Opposition voted against, and wants it known that it voted against, that clause.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall speak very briefly on clauses 8 and 9 because I want to spend some time on clauses 10 and 11. We believe clauses 8 and 9 are indicative of the Government seeking to do two things: firstly, to give retrospective justification to acts it has undertaken which perhaps it should not have undertaken without the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 being strictly followed on all matters the Commonwealth has undertaken. In effect, the Commonwealth is asserting that that Act did not ever apply to World Heritage listed properties. No evidence has been put forward which would in any sense justify that assertion.

The second thing I say about clauses 8 and 9 is that they clearly free the Government from an obligation to act in accordance with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. So, for instance, if Senator Richardson's unlamented predecessor, Mr Brown, had wanted to go ahead with the monorail at Ayers Rock, he would not have had to conform with the procedures laid down under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act for a proper evaluation of that because he would have had the power to act as Minister and to act unilaterally. I think the insertion of clauses 8 and 9 into this legislation-which again I formally notify the Committee the Opposition will vote against but will not take to a division because of time restraints-is just an indication of how the Government is prepared to play fast and loose with its own environmental legislation when it suits ministerial purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). I ask the Minister again when he will provide the Senate with the $300,000 worth of environmental impact studies? We have been waiting for this for some time. Could the Minister explain why he is not prepared to present to Parliament the $300,000 worth of environmental impact studies paid for by the taxpayer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This may be the seventh or eighth time I have answered this question. The Government has those reports under consideration and they will be released very shortly. There is no problem with that. I have been saying that for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: This amending Bill will not prevent the Minister from ordering an inquiry into the environmental effects of a monorail at Ayers Rock. I would not be a party to any attempt to preclude that being done.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not always going to have a person of your sensitivity, are we?

—I shall not comment on that. Modesty forbids and prevents. It is the case that it should not be thought that to achieve the environmental protection of an area, which the Government does by activating the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, that the other Act should be enacted as well. This simply clears that up. The Commonwealth will always live up to its obligations to protect the environment. In fact, listing for World Heritage is perhaps the ultimate test of protecting our environment. That is what one does when one acts under that Bill. In the case of the monorail at Uluru, and indeed the other one from Darwin down to Cooinda which I have also heard recently, I do not think there would be much doubt that there would be an environmental impact study.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 10 and 11-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a perfect opportunity to draw attention to the way in which the Government has proceeded in regard to north Queensland. It appears that the Labor Government, like everything else it touches, is determined to corrupt even the processes of World Heritage listing and the scientific principles upon which such listing is supposed to proceed after proper evaluation of the nominations in question. Evidence from the Australian Mission to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) raises two fundamentally disturbing questions relating to World Heritage listing of both Kakadu Stage 2 and the north Queensland wet tropical rainforests. A telex from UNESCO Ambassador Mott to Senator Richardson blows the whistle on the Federal Labor Government. In his telex of December 1987, Ambassador Mott admits-and I quote from the telex:

SPEECH.PARA: IUCN in fact has never visited Kakadu officially, not even in 1981 when Stage I was listed and certainly not for Stage II . . .

The procedures for World Heritage listing are supposed to include an evaluation of proposed nominations by either the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) in the case of nominated natural sites, or the International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS) when the nomination involves built areas. Such an evaluation by the relevant `expert' group attached to the World Heritage Committee and UNESCO is supposed to be presented to the World Heritage Bureau in committee before the site is accepted for inscription on the World Heritage List. The formal operational guidelines for the implementation of the World Heritage Convention issued by the World Heritage Committee in January 1987 provide in what are called `Guidelines for the Evaluation and Examination of Nominations' that-and I quote clause 47 (b):
. . . the manner of the professional evaluation carried out by ICOMOS and IUCN should be fully described when each nomination is presented.

The guidelines also require the IUCN to comment on such matters as `the integrity and future management of each property recommended' for possible inclusion. That is a quotation from section 47(d). It is clear that this procedure is not followed in relation to Kakadu Stage I. Mott's telex states:
There was . . . no IUCN report on Kakadu, a fact which the Americans, the only delegation on the Committee unhelpful to our cause, pursued at length in questioning . . .

I find it amazing that Ambassador Mott describes the American delegation-one of the most genuinely environmentally conscious national delegations-as unhelpful. The reason that it was was that the nomination in question was not accompanied by the required scientific data in support of it, nor were the proper and normal procedures being followed by the Australian Government and its delegation. It appears that the Government is anxious to avoid repetition of this saga, so it is putting in place a scheme designed to fix the umpire. Mr James Thorsell of Canada is expected to lead an IUCN team to Australia later this year to evaluate the north Queensland wet tropical rainforests nomination. Thorsell is a respected figure in the international conservation movement and is quite capable of making up his own mind on the subject objectively. However, Mott's telex advises Senator Richardson:
For Queensland it is desirable that Thorsell visit and he be well looked after.
What exactly does that `well looked after' mean? By whom and for what purpose? Mott's telex goes on:
It would also help if Canberra Ambassadors of World Heritage Committee member states could be taken to the forests and shown around.

In other words, Ambassador Mott urges the Minister to provide junkets to the Queensland forests to convince foreign ambassadors to lean on their World Heritage Committee representatives to support the Government's nomination for reasons which have nothing to do with the processes of scientific evaluation, which is what the World Heritage listing is supposed to be all about. So not only is the umpire to be fixed but the race jury, if I can extend the metaphor, is also to be nobbled. As if this were enough in itself, Mott's telex reveals two other significant matters about which the Federal Labor Government is being quite deceitful. The UNESCO Ambassador reports that the World Heritage Committee:
Secretariat would like to use Australia as `a motor'-
those are the Committee's words-
to promote World Heritage work in Asia, a region that is below par in the field . . .

The Opposition rejects entirely the idea of our country being used as `a motor' to put pressure on others. World Heritage matters are for us to determine according to what is good for Australia-not for anybody else's agenda or purposes, least of all UNESCO. Finally, the Mott telex admits that in relation to Kakadu, the nomination proceeded without proper consultations with the Government of the Northern Territory `despite the existence of procedures for this purpose'. Mott admits that Australia is progressively coming to be seen by the World Heritage Committee as `a one-issue country' and that:
if anything can be done to improve the system this would help . . .

The way in which the Government has gone about this whole process has been flawed from the outset because it has clearly determined on a course of action in regard to north Queensland; it has clearly pursued that without giving the new Government of Queensland the opportunity to engage in consultation over this matter.

It is an interesting admission by Senator Richardson that, in relation to Shark Bay, the Government of Western Australia asked him not to proceed, and he agreed not to proceed, because they are discussing the matter. Yet when the Queensland Government, the Ahern Government, makes an offer to Senator Richardson to talk, he says, `Fine, but nevertheless I intend to proceed'. In other words, it is one law for the Labor Party State Government in Western Australia, because it is disconcerted with the public reaction which is evident in Western Australia over the proposed nomination of Shark Bay. This Government's view is that to get its mates off the hook in Western Australia, it will allow them to say to the Government, `Please don't proceed'. Here is the expose of the hypocrisy of the argument that somehow the Opposition has caved in to a State veto. What Senator Richardson has said today in this debate about Shark Bay is simply this, `I had discussions with the Western Australian Minister and the Western Australian Minister asked me not to proceed. I agreed not to proceed'-for no other reason than that the Western Australian State Labor administration was able to get a deal out of Senator Richardson, a deal which he is not prepared to give to the Government of Queensland. I think that this is quite typical of the way in which the Government has proceeded in this matter. I would like to spend a considerable amount of time on these two clauses, but there are colleagues of mine from Queensland who, in the few remaining minutes which the Government has allocated for debate on this legislation, undoubtedly would like to make some contribution. Therefore, I shall afford them the opportunity to do so.
