SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on matters of public interest to express my concern about the public questioning in Tasmania of the integrity of the trade union movement because of occurrences late last year with regard to the election within the State branch of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. The election was for a number of positions, but particularly the State secretaryship and State presidency of the organisation-both full time positions in Tasmania. The Returning Officer, a Mr Bob Ridley, announced the result of the ballot. The result was that the encumbents, a Mr Maurie Hill, the State President, and Mr Geoff Adams were both defeated in that election. I might add that some surprise was expressed by people both within the membership of that organisation and within the trade union movement generally that such a result had occurred, because they were particularly competent and very popular officials of that organisation. It is also of interest that the election was run by the organisation itself and that the Returning Officer was Mr Ridley, a previous Secretary of the organisation who, it just so happens, was defeated at the last election-some four years ago-by Mr Adams, who was defeated in this election.

SPEECH.PARA: The two people concerned, Mr Hill and Mr Adams, had it drawn to their notice following the declaration of the ballot that there were some rather strange circumstances surrounding the election. They then found it necessary to notify the Federal Court of Australia of their concerns about these matters. An investigation was carried out by the Industrial Registrar and, as a result of those investigations, the matter was referred by the Industrial Registrar to the Federal Court of Australia.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard four documents relating to the matter. The first is a report to the Federal Court by the Industrial Registrar. The second document is an annexure B, which is a memorandum of interview with Mr Ridley, a Mr Asher and a Mr P. Herrod, officers of the Industrial Registrar's Office. That interview took place on 19 and 20 January. The third document is an annexure C, short notes of a discussion on 11 February between Mr Riseley, Branch Secretary of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, and Ms R. Yaxley and Ms M. Watson, printers at Tastech Print. The fourth document records another interview, between Mr Ridley and Mr D. Small, who is the Deputy Returning Officer, and officers of the Industrial Registrar's Office, which took place on 11 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the incorporation of these four documents?
—We would like the courtesy of having a look at the documents before agreeing to the incorporations. If Senator Devereux can show them to me I will cast my eye over them.
—The question of incorporation is deferred until the Opposition has seen the documents.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The Industrial Registrar, in his report to the Federal Court, noted a number of discrepancies in the election. I will read through some of those matters. He listed them as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) It was apparent that a number of ballot papers (at least 144) had identification marks consistent with ballot papers having been filled in one on top of another.

(ii) Having regard to the layout of the ballot paper, indentations on many of those papers were clearly consistent with having been caused as a result of another ballot paper being marked to indicate a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn O'Neill or Meagher. (See copy of ballot paper-Annexure I).
(iii) All ballot papers on which such indentation marks were evident, indicated on their face, a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neil and Meagher.
(iv) All of such ballot papers with indentations appeared to have been made out in the same hand.

(v) A large number of additional papers (at least 240) also appeared to have been made out by the same, or a similar, hand and also showed on their face, a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neill and Meagher.

(vi) Of the 384 ballot papers identified above, 223 clearly exhibited evidence of what we believe to be electrostatic solution used in the printing process. Evidence of that solution was found on only 11 of the remaining 1348 ballot papers returned from voters and on only 28 of 1375 unused ballot papers. The significance of the existence of electrostatic solution on many of those papers will become evident later in this report when details of the printing of the ballot papers are discussed.
The Industrial Registrar went on to say:

It is open to conclusion, based on these discoveries, that some person or persons unknown, fraudulently obtained, completed and introduced into the ballot an indeterminable number (but in all likelihood not less than 384) of ballot papers, ballot paper envelopes and Business Reply envelopes.

I refer at this stage to the Returning Officer's responsibilities, particularly in relation to ballot papers. The rules of the organisation say that two envelopes are to be sent out and that the Returning Officer may declare papers invalid if the voting paper is not enclosed in two separate envelopes, one inside the other, when it is returned. There is an important question there in that 82 ballot papers were not placed inside the second envelope and were declared informal by the Returning Officer when he counted the ballot. I want to refer to those ballot papers a little later, because they have some importance with regard to this matter.

The Returning Officer, in the conduct of such ballots, and particularly under the Commonwealth Electoral Act, also has a responsibility to ensure when he gets ballot papers printed that he has a certificate from the printer saying that he received a certain number of papers, and at the end of the ballot it is his responsibility to ensure that he has an accurate record, which he can verify, of how many papers were sent out and how many were not used. All that has to be documented. The Industrial Registrar went on to say in his report that a certificate was issued, and Mr Ridley, the Returning Officer, quite clearly had a certificate, but the interesting part reads as follows:

The `certificate' prepared by Tastech Print for the Returning Officer, and dated 11 December 1987, some six weeks after the job was completed, is in my opinion of no more value than a simple acknowledgment of a job done. The ballot papers were not physically counted and I was informed that the mechanical counter used on the machine is only accurate to about 1%.

He went on to say that more than the 5,000 ballot papers claimed on the certificate could have been printed. He then went on to talk about the electrostatic solution that may have spoiled some papers. He said:

Bearing in mind that because of the position of the electrostatic solution on the spoiled sheets only one ballot paper on each sheet is affected, the large number of ballot papers in existence which show evidence of that solution (i.e. 262 out of 3107 examined) is in my opinion inconsistent with the concept of the printing operator culling such imperfect sheets, unless of course those sheets were somehow later included for use in the ballot.

Having regard to the available facts and particularly noting the lack of information available concerning the number of such extra sheets produced, I have been unable to satisfy myself that these sheets could not have been included in the ballot.
From what he was saying there and from records of interviews, it became clear that there could have been anything up to 6,000 sheets actually printed, rather than the 5,000 shown on the certificate.

I move now to the matter of the 82 papers that I spoke of. I believe that they have some significance in the whole issue. The Industrial Registrar talked about the possible effects of some of the irregularities that he found. He spoke of the margin, and went on to say:
The margin in votes between candidates in the ballot is as follows:-
State President-majority for Luttrell over Hill...279
State President, majority for Finn over Adams...389
An examination of the 82 informal ballot papers referred to in the above revealed the following voting preferences-
for the presidency-
Luttrell...34
Hill...47
Informal...1
and for the secretaryship-
Adams...48
Finn...34

I make that comparison because the result of the count of the 82 papers that were declared informal was completely different from the count of the full ballot. I have had, as I guess some others in the Senate have had, some experience at scrutineering. Quite clearly, these 82 papers would be regarded as random papers from varying places that members just did not place in the right envelope. I think anyone who has scrutineered would agree that, if one took 80 to 100-odd papers at random, on about 98 per cent of occasions that would reflect fairly closely the overall end result of the ballot. Quite strangely in this case, the two defeated candidates won quite overwhelmingly out of the 82 votes referred to, yet were soundly defeated in the full ballot.

I now draw attention to the fact that the Returning Officer, in an interview on 19 and 20 January, said that the ballot papers were in his possession at all times, that only about 5,000 had been printed and that no-one else had access to those papers at any stage. It was very interesting that, in a subsequent interview, the people who printed the papers said that they had no recollection of any of this physical counting going on and admitted that the number of papers was a guesstimate and that possibly anything up to 6,000 papers could have been printed rather than the 5,000 stated on the certificate. On 11 February, after that information was conveyed to Mr Ridley in a second interview by officers in the Industrial Registrar's Office, Mr Ridley would make no comment as to who may have had access to ballot papers.

What all that adds up to is that, quite obviously, and in the opinion of the Industrial Registrar, there was some interference. It is very apparent there was interference in that ballot by person or persons unknown. It seems to me that this is very important from the point of view of the trade union movement, about which we often hear stories of rigged ballots and the like. I think those stories are quite false but they are peddled around in the community from time to time. When an instance such as this arises I think it is very important in the public interest that it is completely cleared up. In concluding my remarks here today, for the overall good and reputation of the trade union movement I make a public call for a complete police inquiry into this matter. It is essential that it be cleared up in a proper manner so that the reputations of all the people who took part in that ballot can be cleared or otherwise. I think it is very important that that occurs. Mr Deputy President, I sought to incorporate some papers in Hansard. I do not know whether Senator Puplick has now looked at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted to incorporate the documents?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
INDUSTRIAL REGISTRAR
Report on Investigation (for the purposes of S. 160) into Election in the Tasmanian Branch of The Amalgamated Metal Workers' Union (R Nos. 305 of 1987 and 5 of 1988)
A. Details of Applications

1. Applications, made under s. 159 of the Act, were filed in the Tasmanian District Registry by Geoffrey David Adams and Maurice Kenneth Hill on 24 December 1987 and 11 January 1988, respectively. The applications were made in the prescribed form, were accompanied by a (Commonwealth) Statutory Declaration and were filed within six months of the completion of the subject election.
2. The applicants alleged irregularities in the conduct of the election for State President and State Secretary in the Tasmanian Branch of the Amalgamated Metal Workers' Union.

3. A copy of the particulars of alleged irregularities and facts relied on (which are similar for both applications) is attached to this report (ANNEXURE ``C''). In addition a number of other matters were raised during the course of the investigation.
B. Manner of Inquiry
Action under s. 160 (3a) commenced on 19 January 1988 and for the purposes of such inquiry the applications were treated as being joined.

Mr G. Adams was interviewed on 19 January. He was accompanied by his solicitor Mr J. Green, the other applicant Mr M. Hill, and Mr D. Price the scrutineer for Mr Hill. After general discussion it was agreed that only Mr Adams need be formally interviewed. The memorandum of interview is ANNEXURE ``A'' to this report.

Mr R. Ridley (Branch Returning Officer) was initially interviewed on 19 and 20 January 1988. He was accompanied by the Assistant Returning Officer Mr D. Small. The memorandum of interview is ANNEXURE ``B'' to this report. Further discussions took place with Mr Ridley on 11 February 1988 and notes of this meeting constitute ANNEXURE ``H''.
Persons involved in the printing of the ballot papers used in the election were interviewed on 11 February 1988 and notes of those discussions constitute ANNEXURE ``G'' to this report.

Using powers granted under s.s. 160 (3a) (d) of the Act, I took possession of the voting rolls, returned Business Reply envelopes and ballot papers to facilitate close examination and to ensure the security of that material.
C. Findings re: alleged irregularities, facts relied on, and other relevant matters
1. Allegation-``The ballot papers were not signed or initialled by the State Returning Officer, the said Robert Ridley.''

There appears to be no basis for this claim. The rules of the organization [Part ``B'' sub-rule 7 (g)] require that the Returning Officer shall forward to voters `` . . . a ballot paper initialled by the State Returning Officer or bearing a facsimile of those initials . . . ''. It is apparent that, in accordance with the rules, the Returning Office signed his initials on the master print copy of the ballot papers thereby causing a facsimile of his initials to appear on each ballot paper printed.

2. Allegation-``The Returning Officer was Robert Ridley, the former Tasmanian Secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, who was defeated in a ballot which concluded in December 1983 by Geoffrey David Adams.''
This statement was made for the purpose of showing a reason for ill-feeling between the Returning Officer and Mr Adams.
3. Allegation-``The roll of voters was not compiled by the Returning Officer the said Robert Ridley.''

Sub-rule 7 (b) of Part ``B'' of the rules provides that `` . . . the State Returning Officer shall compile the roll of voters for the ballot and may for this purpose direct the State Secretary to supply him with records relating to membership of the Union in that State.'' Membership records for the organization are kept centrally, on computer, in Melbourne. It appears that the Returning Officer in accordance with normal Branch election procedure requested the Data Processing and Audit Officer of the union to supply him with, inter alia, a computer print out of members eligible to vote in the election. There has been no allegation that the roll of voters used by the Returning Officer was in any way incorrect.

4. Allegation-``The sealed envelope enclosing the ballot papers and returned address envelope did not bear an endorsement that if it is not delivered to the addressee it is to be returned to the said State Returning Officer, the said Robert Ridley, at a specified private post box at a Post Office, being a post box other than that to which the ballot papers were to be returned.''

There appears to be no basis for this allegation. The Returning Officer obtained the use of Post Office Box 1332N for the sole purpose of receiving undelivered mail. A photocopy of such an undelivered envelope (ANNEXURE D) is self evident.

5. Allegation-``In past elections for the positions of Tasmanian State President and Tasmanian State Secretary the percentage of financial members eligible to vote who have voted in that election has been between 25-30 per cent. In this election 1747 ballot papers were returned out of a total of 3616 ballot papers issued being a return of 48 per cent.''

While it is possible that there may have been a higher return in this election than in many elections in the past, it is notable that the declaration in relation to the previous election for the subject positions, held in 1983, indicates a return in excess of 48%. (See ANNEXURE ``E'').
6. Allegation-``5000 manilla envelopes were printed for this election as were 5000 reply paid envelopes and 10,000 grey envelopes to hold the ballot papers by Monotone Art Printers Pty Ltd.''
See answer to question 17-Annexure ``B''. No further comment is required.

7. Allegation-``The ballot opened on the 30th of November 1987 and closed on the 21st of December 1987. Since the 14th of December 1987 approximately 700 ballot papers were received. This is contrary to all past experience where very few ballot papers are received in the last week of the election.''

During his interview, Mr Adams indicated that the date of 11 December 1987 would be more appropriate than the date of 14 December contained in this allegation which was purportedly based on the number of papers collected from the Post Office on certain days during the ballot. It is obvious (see attachment B10 to Annexure ``B'') that from and including 11 December 1987 a total of only 503 papers were collected. I draw no conclusions based solely on the numbers of papers collected from the Post Office on or from certain days.
8. Allegation-``Approximately 600 ballot papers appear to have been filled in by one person''.

It appears that Mr Adams was informed by his scrutineer, Mr Gyselman, that in his opinion some ballot papers had been filled in in similar handwriting. Mr Adams had then, for the purposes of his application, estimated that the number of papers involved was 600. This estimate does appear to have been based more on a false premise than on a fact. (See answers to questions 8 and 10-Annexure ``A''). Nevertheless, an exhaustive examination of ballot papers was conducted over a period of time by Mr P. Herrod and myself.
During this examination, a number of significant discoveries were made:
(i) It was apparent that a number of ballot papers (at least 144) had indentation marks consistent with ballot papers having been filled in one on top of another.

(ii) Having regard to the layout of the ballot paper, indentations on many of those papers were clearly consistent with having been caused as a result of another ballot paper being marked to indicate a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neill or Meagher (See copy of ballot paper-ANNEXURE I)
(iii) All ballot papers on which such indentation marks were evident indicated, on their face, a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neill and Meagher.
(iv) All of such ballot papers with indentations appeared to have been made out in the same hand.

(v) A large number of additional papers (at least 240) also appeared to have been made out by that same, or a similar, hand and also showed on their face, a vote in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neill and Meagher.

(vi) Of the 384 ballot papers identified above, 223 clearly exhibited evidence of what we believe to be the electrostatic solution used in the printing process. Evidence of that solution was found on only 11 of the remaining 1348 ballot papers returned from voters and on only 28 of the 1375 unused ballot papers. The significance of the existence of electrostatic solution on many of those papers will become evident later in this report when details of the printing of the ballot papers are discussed.

It is open to conclusion, based on these discoveries, that some person or persons unknown, fraudulently obtained, completed and introduced into the ballot an indeterminable number (but in all likelihood not less than 384) of ballot papers, ballot paper envelopes and Business Reply envelopes.
9. Informal ballot papers.
Sub-rule 7 (q)-Part ``B'' of the rules of the organization provides ``A ballot paper shall be informal if:
(i) it does not bear the initials of the State Returning Officer or a facsimile of those initials;
(ii) it has upon it a mark or writing by which the voter can be identified;
(iii) it is not marked substantially in accordance with any directions to voters by the State Returning Officer and the intention of the voter is not clear; or
(iv) it is not returned in the outer envelope.''

A number of ballot papers (82) were declared informal by the Returning Officer on the basis that they had not been enclosed in an inner ``ballot paper'' envelope as well as the Business Reply envelope. It could be argued that those ballot papers should, in fact, have been admitted to the count.
10. Postmarked Business Reply envelopes.

As a consequence of the matters covered in paragraph number 8 of this report, the Business Reply envelopes returned by voters were sorted, where possible, into various categories based on the postmark stamped on each envelope. A table detailing the results constitutes ANNEXURE ``F'' to this report. Despite an indication that the figures in relation to the numbers of papers posted in Hobart on certain days might appear to be inordinately high, I am unable to draw any definite conclusion solely from the information contained in the table.
11. Printing of Ballot Papers, etc.

The ballot papers were printed on 30 October 1987 by Tastech Print of 105 New Town Road, New Town. Information was provided by employees of the company as to the procedure followed when printing those papers (see ANNEXURE ``G''). It is apparent that during the course of the printing operation a number of sheets (each consisting of 2 ballot papers) were either treated as ``set-up'' copies or were culled during the printing run as a result of some imperfection including the existence of electrostatic solution on the sheet. I am satisfied that as a result of a number of such imperfections being caused by a problem with the template, a second such template was produced and used to complete the printing run.

Neither the printing machine operator nor the Returning Officer, who were both in attendance during the printing operation, were prepared to give an estimate of the total number of ``set-up'' or culled sheets produced during this operation. Unfortunately, the company's job control sheet for the job, which may well have shown the number of extra sheets used over and above the 2500 required, is not now available.

The ``certificate'' prepared by Tastech Print for the Returning Officer, and dated 11 December 1987, some six weeks after the job was completed, is in my opinion of no more value than simple acknowledgement of a job done. The ballot papers were not physically counted and I was informed that the mechanical counter used on the machine is only accurate to about 1%. That in itself indicates the possibility that up to 50 extra ballot papers may have been supplied to the Returning Officer. In addition, no information is given in relation to the number of extra sheets printed in the operation and described above, which were provided to the Returning Officer along with the master templates. It has not been disputed that the Returning Officer took possession of all ballot papers, the ``spoiled'' sheets and printing templates at the completion of the printing operation on 30 October.

An examination of the 40 odd ``spoiled'' sheets which are currently in existence reveals that a number of those sheets could easily have been guillotined to provide a suitable ballot paper for use in the ballot. In fact, some of the sheets contain ballot papers which are in better condition than many of the ballot papers actually used in the ballot.

Bearing in mind that because of the position of the electrostatic solution on the spoiled sheets only one ballot paper on each sheet is affected, the large number of ballot papers in existence which show evidence of that solution (i.e. 262 out of 3107 examined) is in my opinion inconsistent with the concept of the printing operator culling such imperfect sheets, unless of course, those sheets were somehow later included for use in the ballot.

Having regard to the available facts and particularly noting the lack of information available concerning the number of such extra sheets produced, I have been unable to satisfy myself that those sheets could not have been included in the ballot.

12. During the investigation, a number of persons suggested that ballot papers may have been produced by the use of a photocopy machine and then fraudulently introduced into the ballot. For a number of reasons, including the fact that all potentially fraudulent ballot papers appeared to have been individually stamped with the Returning Officer's stamp and that many had traces of electrostatic solution which would not have been evident had those papers been a photocopy, I do not believe that there is any merit in that suggestion.
D. Possible irregularities in connection with the election
Irregularities in the election could have occurred by virtue of the following:-
1. The action of the Returning Officer in declaring 82 ballot papers informal on the basis that they were not enclosed in an inner ``ballot paper'' envelope.

2. The suspected action of a person or persons unnamed fraudulently filling in an unknown quantity of ballot papers in favour of Luttrell, Finn, O'Neill and Meagher the successful candidates for the positions of State President, State Secretary and Delegates to National Conference, respectively.
E. Possible effect of above matters on the subject positions
The margin in votes between candidates in the ballot is as follows:-
State President-majority for Luttrell over Hill 279
State Secretary-majority for Finn over Adams 389
An examination of the 82 informal ballot papers referred to above revealed the following voting preferences:
Luttrell...34
Hill...47
Adams...48
Finn...34
Informal...1

Although no estimate is made of the total number of papers which may have been fraudulently completed, it is believed that at least 384 of such papers have been completed in favour of Luttrell and Finn.
Clearly then, the result of the ballot for the positions of State President and State Secretary may have been affected by the possible irregularities.
F. Conclusion and Recommendation

In my view the application should be referred to the Federal Court on the basis that there are reasonable grounds for an inquiry into the question of whether there has been an irregularity in or in connection with the election which may have affected the result of the election and that the circumstances of the matter justify an inquiry by the Court.

It should be noted that, had either of the applications sought to include the positions of Regional Delegates to National Conference in the inquiry, I would also have recommended that they be included in the reference to Court.
H. J. Asher

ANNEXURE C

Short notes of discussion between Mr B. Riseley (Branch Sec. A.T.E.A.), Ms R. Yaxley, Ms M. Watson, Mr I. McLeod and Mr H. Asher at the office of Tastech Print, 105 Newtown Road, Newtown on 11 February 1988.

Mr Riseley indicated that it was the company's practice when printing ballot papers of any kind to insist that the Returning Officer take possession of the master printing plate and any spoiled and discarded material.

When asked about the use of security paper, he replied that it was not normally requested although they had used it at times. They would order it if required, at an extra cost to the customer. He expressed doubts about its effectiveness.

Mr Riseley and Ms Yaxley said they both remembered the particular job done for Mr Ridley. Ms Yaxley indicated that a commonly available paper, Reflex Bond 80 gsm, was used for the job. When asked whether a template such as that used for the job could be re-used, they both were of the opinion that those templates are not made for re-use and in fact it would be completely impracticable to try to do so particularly once the template had dried.

The pale green substance, which was evident on the sample ballot paper shown to them, was identified as the electrostatic solution used in the printing process. They indicated that an efficient printer could cull sheets with such solution on them.
The printing process was described as follows-

After the template is made up it is placed on the printing machine and a number of sheets run through to obtain a good print. A normal job would probably involve 30 to 40 sheets being treated as ``set-up'' copies or ``spoils'' before the desired print was obtained. After the last ``set-up'' copy was printed the numerical counter on the machine would be set to the number required for the job. The operator would then watch during the print run and cull any spoils such as copies badly printed or containing electrostatic solution. At the end of the run the operator would then count how many sheets were culled and reprint a corresponding number to ensure the correct total number is printed. The total number of sheets is not then actually counted but the machine is accurate to about 1%.

Despite initially indicating that she remembered the particular job, Ms Yaxley could not remember how many ``set-up'' copies were printed prior to the start of the run, could not remember making a second template and additionally therefore, the reason for so doing, and could not remember how many sheets were culled during the actual printing process or how many extra sheets were subsequently printed.

An examination of the order book indicated that 6 reams of paper totalling 3000 sheets were ordered for the job. As it was a ``two-up'' job only 2500 sheets of the desired print would have been required.
We were informed that the job control sheet for that particular job, which may have shown the exact number of sheets actually used for the job, was no longer available.
The guillotining of the sheets was undertaken by the operator.

Ms Watson indicated that the figure of 5000 contained in her ``certificate'' of 11 December 1987 was obtained from the job invoice, it was not a figure arrived at by physically counting the papers provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about a matter of public importance which is of particular concern in my State of Tasmania. I refer first of all to the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill, or Act as it now is to become, and the guillotine which was pushed through in this chamber earlier today. I had hoped to speak in the committee stage of that legislation because it is a matter in which, as a Tasmanian, I have a particular interest. As a lawyer I also have a particular interest in the rights and liberties of the citizen. I think this legislation is a particularly bad example of the power of the Federal Government riding roughshod over the rights of citizens no matter where they might live.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to have it on the record just how this Government has changed its attitude over the last few years to the use of the World Heritage legislation. To demonstrate that, I wish to read into the record excerpts from a speech made in September 1984 by the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Hon. Barry Cohen, at the National Conference on Conservation and the Economy. He was referring to demands for the Great Barrier Reef, the Kakadu National Park, Lord Howe Island, et cetera, to be placed on the the World Heritage List. He said:

At the time of these demands on the Federal Government to use its powers under the Act, the Greater Daintree Area was not on the World Heritage list, nor was it being considered for nomination. Nevertheless, it was argued that the Government, despite this, should act as it was claimed that the area met the World Heritage criteria as being `of outstanding universal value'.

I made it clear that the Federal Government would stick to the commitment, made at the time of the passing of the WHPC Act, that it would not use the legislation indiscriminately; that it saw implementation of the Act as a `last resort', and that it would consult with the relevant state before it nominated new areas for inclusion on the World Heritage List.
I also stated that we would have to be thoroughly convinced of the unique nature of a proposal before we considered such an area for nomination.

I pointed out that the World Heritage List ought not to be simply an extension of the National Estate. In other words, it should remain an exclusive list of the world's unique natural and cultural treasures. I said that I hoped the environment movement would not seek to use the list, and therefore the legislation, as a means of stopping every act of desecration of the environment committed by a state or local government. Attempts to add to the list everything which was merely of `national' value and not unique in a global sense would simply debase the currency.

I have no trouble at all in supporting the words used by the former Minister in his speech in 1984. I have great trouble with the way the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act is now being used by the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the present Government. It seems to me that they are not using the Act as a last resort any more. They are not consulting with the relevant States before nomination, and they are not thoroughly convinced of the unique nature of proposals before nominating areas. I am particularly concerned to see the way they have gone away from that commitment by the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen.

I also mention my great concern about the powers which are being given to inspectors under the amending legislation that has just passed through the Senate. I draw the Senate's attention to another document which is of great relevance to us in this place-the report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which was tabled in the Senate yesterday. On the question of these inspectors, the Committee said that it had:

consistently drawn the Senate's attention to powers of entry and search possessed by officials and inspectors under a variety of Commonwealth legislation. Included among such officials are customs and taxation officers, and inspectors under primary industries legislation. The Committee is concerned to note the grant of powers of search and entry to another group of officials.

The particular concern of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee was the widening of the groups of officials. I do not limit my concern only to that but I certainly think that it is ominous when we have continually widening groups of officials in this country who can enter the private property of citizens without a warrant and without the consent of the owners. In the earlier debate somebody suggested that a large number of former New South Wales State Ministers were looking for jobs and may be eligible for appointment as inspectors.

We cannot possibly approve a situation in which people in this country can no longer live peacefully on their own land without intrusion from Commonwealth officials. Every time we open a Bill these days, we find that the Commonwealth is giving more and more people the power to intrude upon the privacy and the private property of citizens of this country. It is totally unacceptable. It is not just the Liberal Party which finds it so. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Senator Richardson has been well advised of this by several of the councils for civil liberties in this country. I have in front of me a copy of a letter which the Minister received from the Queensland Council for Civil Liberties. I do not intend to quote it at any length, but the entire letter is directed to concerns about the warrant issuing process and the powers given to inspectors. In summing up that letter, I think it is fair to say that the basic concerns of the Council for Civil Liberties go to the need to tighten up the warrant issuing process and to avoid misuse of the powers given under the warrant. The letter states:

. . . dangers associated with inspectors being appointed from officers of a public service department who are inexperienced in the need to respect the rights of the citizen and who are not subject to the normal disciplinary procedures that would apply, for example, to a member of the Australian Federal Police.
The letter concludes:
. . . it is exceedingly important that such a major extension of powers of the state into a new area be subject to the strictest safeguards to prevent misuse of such powers.

It is clear that we are not witnessing an hysterical exercise by opponents of this Government. This is very definitely a matter of real concern to anybody who understands how the liberties of the citizens are being continually eroded. It is colourful to say that this is jackboot government, but it is not very far wide of the truth. I say in summing up that I am particularly concerned that there has been such a rude refusal to allow debate in this place. Allegations were made earlier today that the Opposition was filibustering. We believe that these matters are far too--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Newman, you must not reflect on a decision of the Senate. You have been sufficiently general up to date but you must not become particular about a debate that has concluded.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I certainly have concern about some of the provisions in this legislation. I also have concern that the debate was not given the time necessary for such an important matter. I have particular concern at the general change of approach by this Government to the whole question of World Heritage listing, the protection of World Heritage properties and the enforcement of Commonwealth legislation in relation to World Heritage properties. The actions of the Government today and in the introduction of this legislation are all part of an increasing tendency to ride roughshod over the rights of the citizens of this country.
