In real terms pensions have increased by 8.3 per cent since 1983. In unadjusted terms the increase has been 15.3 per cent. It should be noted that because of those increases pensions now represent almost 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. In the December 1987 quarter pensions represented 24.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. It should be noted further in this context that in 1983 when this Government was elected, pensions represented only 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. Those figures are not meaningless because when one looks at the increase in average weekly earnings during this period and compares it with the increase in pensions during the same period, one sees that pensions have increased by 50.3 per cent, whereas average weekly earnings have increased by 38.3 per cent. So, there has been an increase in both real and unadjusted terms. It should also be remembered that the Government has adopted a policy of indexing the purchasing power of pensions according to the consumer price index.

Mr Searle, and possibly Senator Chaney, may need to understand that the Government has also taken other measures to assist age pensioners. Honourable senators should remember that rent assistance has been increased by 50 per cent, that single age pensioners can now earn an extra $40 a week before their pensions are reduced, and that married pensioners can earn an extra $70 a week. From January this year pensioners will be able to retain fringe benefits for three months despite their income having risen by up to 25 per cent above the limit. Also, despite the cynicism of honourable senators opposite, it should be remembered that the earnings credit reform of the Government will allow pensioners to earn extra income without losing their current entitlements.

In closing I should say that the Government's actions so far are not the end of its commitment to pensioners. We are considering a social security review with a view to assisting age pensioners further.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I preface the question by referring to the disgraceful action of the Government in the Senate this morning in gagging and guillotining debate upon the heritage legislation, with the shameful assistance of the Australian Democrats. Will the Minister confirm that, as revealed in a letter to him from his Labor Party colleague Mr Eaton, who I understand is the Queensland shadow Minister for land management and forestry, members of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland were not consulted about the boundaries of the World Heritage area in the north Queensland rain- forest? Did the Minister fail to involve Australian Labor Party members of the State Parliament on the basis that it would be more even-handed to treat all those who disagreed with his plans with equal contempt-a contempt, I repeat, manifested in the Government's gagging this morning of debate on legislation central to the concerns of Mr Eaton as well as to those of many others in this place and elsewhere? Why, as Mr Eaton is reported to have said in his letter to the Minister, did the Federal Government consult in secret and only with conservationists about the boundaries of the proposed World Heritage listing area? Finally, will the Government reconsider its position on this matter and, as urged by the coalition parties in this place, by the Queensland Labor Party and, above all, by the people of north Queensland, adopt bound- aries and a management strategy that will adequately protect a great Australian inheritance without putting at risk the jobs of thousands of workers in the timber and associated industries?
—It was a long question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a long question, but I will endeavour to do my best. First off, I am being berated about the so-called disgraceful acts of this morning, for the attempt to gag the debate. I would like to point out to Senator Stone and to other honourable senators opposite that overall there were 12 hours of debate on the motion that the Bill be read a second time and five hours in the committee stage-a total of 17 hours. How many Bills ever go through this place after 17 hours of debate? How many Bills are debated for that long? I suggest that it almost never happens. Having responded to the first remarks made by Senator Stone, I turn to Senator Stone's question about a letter from Mr Eaton. I have not read that letter from Bill Eaton. It arrived in my office this morning. I have been a little busy this morning although perhaps Senator Stone has not noticed. I did not get around to reading that letter because I was attempting to answer Senator Stone's and other honourable senators' questions in the committee stage of the debate and, if I might say so, doing rather well. However, that has meant that I have not got around to reading the letter. However, I think that I can gather from the tone of Senator Stone's question what Mr Eaton said in the letter. I am asked about consultations in Queensland and whether I consulted people only in the Australian Labor Party or whether I treated everyone with equal contempt. Far from it. In fact, our consultation processes were as open as they could possibly be. There was a two-month period--
—Who with?

—Any member of the public in Queensland or, indeed, in Australia-even Senator Parer-could have sent to me a submission on the boundaries. It was because of the submissions on the boundaries that we received that the final boundaries announced after that two-month period in fact differed from the indicative boundary that had been announced some months earlier. It was because we had a consultation process and because we listened to members of the public that we did it.
—Didn't the Labor Party put in a submission?

—It is never possible in an exercise of this scope to please everyone. No exercise in the world would ever please Senator Walters. Certainly I hope that I am never party to one. It is not possible to please everyone. At times there have been a number of people in my Party who have disagreed with me. I might even say that they have disagreed with me on other issues. However, I have had to bear that. I have had to live under the yoke of it at times.
—That was never the case.

—Senator Cook assures me that it has never been the case. However, in Queensland I know that the only forum of the Labor Party to have met and discussed the issue was the State Council which overwhelmingly endorsed my position. I have no doubt that if it meets again it will do the same thing. I understand where Bill Eaton's concerns would lie. I can always understand people doing what they believe is best for their constituents. However, on this occasion if Mr Eaton has said some of the things Senator Stone claims he has said, he is wrong. This is a democracy and Bill Eaton and anyone else has a right to be wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether we would adopt different boundaries or different management strategies. The reality is, as I said, that the boundaries have been announced and the nomination has proceeded and as there was a long consultation period we, therefore, have no intention of changing them. In regard to the question of management strategy, I shall be suggesting to Cabinet in the next few weeks what I believe to be an appropriate management strategy. That will form the basis for discussions with the Queensland Government. I and all other members of the Government are anxious for those discussions to take place with Queensland, and to take place soon. To that end I have been in contact with Premier Ahern's office and a date has been set for our first meeting. I will take great delight in informing the Senate of the results of progress with Premier Ahern.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMENTS BY PRESIDENT OF THE LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Transport and Communications has seen the report of a speech by the President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott, yesterday at a lunch organised by the American Chamber of Commerce in which, among other things, Mr Elliott attacked the development of a multicultural Australia and the introduction of multicultural television. Is it not a fact that this is the second time in the last 10 days that Mr Elliott has dealt with such an issue in such a way?

—Yes, I saw the report in this morning's Australian Financial Review-a report which was obtained, I understand, despite the efforts of Mr Elliott to exclude the media from yesterday's lunch in Melbourne. At that lunch Mr Elliott reportedly not only developed his views on taxation which have caused so much heartache in the ranks opposite in the last couple of days but also described--

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The question in its terms obviously raises no matter relevant to the Government's administration at all. It asks no more from the Minister than his comment on Mr Elliott and how many times he has made certain statements. It seems to me that quite clearly that has nothing to do with the Minister's administration. He should therefore not be permitted to answer the question, which should be ruled out of order in total.

—Order! The question did cover the matter of multicultural television and other activities which are relevant to Senator Evans's portfolio. Of course, he should confine himself to matters for which he is responsible.

—Mr Deputy President, I will be delighted to do so because they are very revealing indeed of the sort of person who is now purporting to lead, outside the parliamentary party, the Liberal Party in this country. At the lunch in question Mr Elliott repeated the remarks that were attributed to him in London the other day, which were the subject of some comment by me in this place, when he described the development of a multicultural Australia and, specifically, the introduction of multicultural television, the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), as being `a major step backwards'. These comments come hard on the heels of Mr Elliott's speech in London in which it will be recalled he called for Australia to move to a limited democracy, he attacked the Aboriginal population and asserted again that migrants coming to Australia should not seek to maintain cultural differences. What these comments made on two occasions in recent days amount to is nothing less than a campaign by the President of the Liberal Party against the ethnic communities of Australia. Clearly, Mr Elliott is not merely xenophobic but is harbouring deep-seated prejudices against anyone that does not conform to his own particular perception of a stereotypical Caucasian Australian.
—Order! Senator Evans, you are straying away from your portfolio.
—Mr Deputy President, I am indebted to you for having reminded me--
—Tell us about Unsworth's comments about `going back to where he came from'.

—Look what happened to Mr Unsworth. Look what will happen to Mr Elliott when he persists in this particular attack which is manifestly as misconceived as another that I can think of in recent times. These sorts of attacks on the ethnic population of Australia provide a very disturbing insight into the kind of society that we would have under a future Liberal government, either one headed by Mr Elliott, as is manifestly his ambition, or one in which he retained his status as the President of it. However, the point I particularly want to make is that what is even more disturbing than these remarks being made and repeated in recent days is that we have not heard a word, not a squeak, from the Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, the communications spokesman, Senator Messner, or, indeed, anyone else on the conservative side of politics to distance themselves from these tasteless, insensitive and thoroughly prejudiced remarks. Unlike the consumption tax issue when Mr Howard described Mr Elliott's views as restating a personal view, we have not heard anything expressed in those terms on the multiculturalism issue. We have not heard Mr Howard saying in relation to multiculturalism or SBS television that he and Mr Elliott do not have to sing like choirboys on that issue. The only conclusion that one can possibly draw from all of that is that Mr Howard's and Mr Elliott's views are not different in these matters and that they do sing like choirboys when it comes to their perception of the role of multiculturalism and multicultural television. The Liberal and National parties should be condemned by the entire Australian community, not merely the ethnic communities, for their implicit endorsement of Mr Elliott's comments and, indeed, for allowing him to remain as their national President.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health to recent reports about the effectiveness of the drug AZT in overseas and Australian clinical trials in which it has been shown to alter the course of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and prolong the life of people affected by it. First, who is currently funding the trial program using AZT in Australia and where does the Minister believe that the responsibility for future funding lies? Secondly, when will a final decision be made between the Federal and State governments in respect of the inclusion of AZT funding under the Medicare arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States? Finally, will the Minister give an assurance that the Commonwealth Government will bear the cost of AZT treatment for patients who are eligible to receive it under the present trial criteria until such time as the Federal-State agreements have been concluded and the drug's availability under Medicare is determined?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin asked me three questions. I will take them--
—At least we now know that you can count.

—At least honourable senators know that I can count up to three. I have a big surprise for them; I can count a lot more than that. I will deal with the three questions in order. Clinical evaluation of AZT, involving some 200 patients around Australia, is being funded on a dollar for dollar cost share basis between the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories. The Commonwealth Government has undertaken to contribute $1m to this program in the 1987-88 financial year. The provision of AZT to public hospital patients is the responsibility of the States, as the primary providers of health care, through the public hospital system. Currently, AZT can be provided only through a hospital and specialist regimen. It is the responsibility of the States, in the context of administering their public hospital systems, to provide the necessary drugs for public patients in hospitals and hospital outpatients. The Commonwealth does not provide special funding for other drugs supplied to patients in the public hospital system.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Macklin's second question on when a final decision will be made, this issue was discussed by the Health Ministers at the Australian Health Ministers conference held on 7 and 8 March this year. The Commonwealth is preparing a paper on the principles for renegotiation of a revised Medicare agreement to incorporate AIDS treatment and the provision of AZT. This will be considered by Health Ministers at a special conference in May this year before the Premiers Conference. As to the third question, whether we will give some assurance that the Commonwealth will bear the cost, the Commonwealth has already provided $1m for clinical trials in 1987-88, as I detailed in the earlier part of my answer. Funding for AZT beyond the scope of this arrangement is a matter for the State and Territory administrations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the concern expressed by unions and management in the Australian cement industry about the potential for dumping of cheap imports. The Minister would be aware that, for several months, representatives from the industry have voiced these concerns through the media and in meetings with Federal Ministers and members. I ask the Minister what action he intends to take to ensure that the cement industry is given a fair chance to compete and grow.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent months a number of problems have been raised in respect of the cement industry. The first is--
—The main problem is that no more boots are being made in New South Wales.

—Senator Stone's interjection is one entirely of his own making. I will pass it on to the cement industry for its consideration. For the past nine months or so there have been complaints about the potential dumping of imported cement, imported cement generally, threats to employment in the industry, and so on. I am very aware of these concerns expressed by the industry. On a number of occasions in recent months I have met with industry representatives. Other members of Parliament have also met with unions and management from the industry.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two current allegations affecting the cement industry. Firstly, in respect of cement clinker in Western Australia, the Australian Customs Service has initiated a formal investigation and officers are visiting affected firms this week to collect evidence. That is in respect of the dumping complaint. The second-if I might use this expression in this context-concrete case involves cement which is proposed for importation into Victoria. The industry lodged applications for anti-dumping protection late last year, but the evidence provided by the companies was deficient in a number of respects. The Australian Customs Service has advised the industry of the nature of the shortcomings in the material provided and has had several meetings with affected parties. The Australian Customs Service now awaits a revised application from the companies. However, in spite of these matters being processed in recognition of industry concerns, I announced recently the establishment of a tripartite committee to evaluate current problems of the industry and future directions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another delaying mechanism.

—I have also asked the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) to do a little study on the competitiveness of the industry, the appropriateness of its technology, investment in the industry, and so on. The committee will comprise five people-two drawn from the industry, two from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and me or my representative. It is to be formed after consultation with industry representatives in Canberra over the last few months. The committee will be able to consult widely, assess the current competitive position and monitor the progress of the industry on a range of issues. Specifically, the committee, in consultation with relevant State governments, will monitor the progress and outcome of dumping complaints lodged by the industry, monitor the progress of the BIE study, evaluate the need to restructure the industry and evaluate the question of labour adjustment.

ANSWER.PARA: The committee will report to Federal and State governments, as appropriate, on the committee's consideration of these matters and may advise the Federal Government as to whether the industry should be referred to the Industries Assistance Commission for inquiry. Those steps have been taken to try to alleviate what is a difficult situation. I would not want to say publicly what my views are about some of the tactics adopted by parties involved in this matter, but--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't approve of dumping bags of cement on people's doorsteps.
—No, I do not; or on Japanese consulate doorsteps.
—Are you looking after any of your mates?
—Senator Lewis has interpolated in my answer to the question which the good senator from Tasmania so astutely asked me.
—Do you mean the well-known one?

—No. I know him very well. I was going to call him Senator Beijing because he is on a learning curve about Peking duck. I was tempted to call him that, but I decided not to do so. Senator Aulich asked a very astute question and as I gave an informed answer, Senator Lewis interjected persistently. As Opposition spokesman on industry matters, he is not interested in solutions to industry problems, regrettably. He is just--
—You are deferring the whole matter.
—Perhaps Senator Lewis will make a speech in the adjournment debate explaining how he would deal with this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody has to stay and listen. My God, what a dreadful--

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from the Government benches.

—It is shocking behaviour by those on the Government benches! I remind them, because clearly they have not thought of this, that none of them would have to stay to listen to Senator Lewis speaking on the adjournment. I would stay because, as distinct from Senator Lewis, I am a man of diligence. I am even prepared to listen to him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BURSWOOD ISLAND RESORT HOTEL AND CASINO

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) is investigating allegations that a Japanese businessman involved in the purchase of the Burswood Island Resort Hotel and Casino in Perth owns hotels in Japan which are often used by gangsters for meetings and celebrations? Has the Minister noted the comment by a senior official of the company, headed by Mr Hidemi Sasaki, that, even when told by police that intending guests are gangsters, it does not refuse them hotel bookings because, and I quote, `Yes, we are afraid of them'? Is the Minister concerned that this refusal by Mr Sasaki to stand up to gangsters in his own country might be translated into a compliant attitude towards criminal elements in Australia? What information does the Minister have about the way in which Mr Sasaki operates his hotels in Japan? I ask the Minister to ensure, on this occasion, that he provides the Senate with all the AFP information in his possession. Does he believe that the company involved, and its principal, are suitable purchasers of the casino, particularly as it is a casino frequented by the Australian Prime Minister for special rules gambling and for mingling with a strange assortment of patrons?

—I have no knowledge of any Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigation into the Japanese business consortium which is seeking-I think this is what the honourable senator indicated-a management role or an ownership role in the Burswood Casino. I know nothing of any such AFP report being prepared, and certainly nothing of its contents. As to the remarks attributed to a senior official of the Japanese company, of course I am equally unaware of those. As to whether I formed any opinion whether the company concerned or its senior management would be suitable to operate a casino, clearly, given the previous answers, I am in no position to form such a judgment. If the AFP is indeed preparing a report, I will seek further advice from it as to what might be properly put into the public domain. I will do this if, as I say, it is compiling such a report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in the Sun of today's date which states:

QUESTION.PARA: Federal Police are investigating a report that Japanese gangsters are frequenting hotels owned by Japanese businessmen . . .
A spokesman said yesterday they want to speak to Japanese police about it.

When does the Minister anticipate that he would receive a brief if such action is in fact taking place and that there are relationships between the Australian Federal Police and the Japanese police on this matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tambling for drawing my attention to a report in the Sun. I do not know whether it is the Brisbane Sun. I will certainly follow up the indication given by that report. I do not know whether it is true or not.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headlined `Promises the Government is likely to hold itself to'? What are the implications for the national economy of the promises made by the new Government in New South Wales in the course of the recent State election campaign? Will the Commonwealth Government provide any additional funding to New South Wales to ensure that these promises can be met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article-I do not think it appeared today; it was published, I think, a couple of days ago-in which it was reported that Mr Greiner has said that the new Government in New South Wales will stand by the promises that it made in the period up to the election. Those promises total additional expenditure of something more than $1.4 billion. I have been asked-and I am sure that I can answer this with supreme confidence that the Treasurer will endorse and agree entirely with what I say-whether the Commonwealth Government will be providing any financial assistance to the new Government in New South Wales to meet those spending commitments. The answer is the same after the election as it was before the election-definitely not.

ANSWER.PARA: The people of New South Wales who voted in the Greiner Government will have to live with the consequences of that. I believe that the preferred consequence would be just a quick and clean repudiation of everything that it promised in the last 12 months. This would be the quickest and cleanest thing to do. Of course, the numerically dominant Liberal Party in the coalition Government in New South Wales will not do that because, as usual, the National Party tail will be wagging the Liberal Party dog. I refer specifically to one of the promises put out during the runup to the New South Wales election. The Deputy Premier elect promised to allocate, hypothecate, for road maintenance and construction all of the State petrol tax. That entails an increase of $180m of spending on roads.

A road funding lobby has been wandering around Parliament House this morning, trying to get some more money from the Federal Government for roads. What I suggest that it do as far as New South Wales is concerned is to go along to Mr Greiner and Mr Murray and say, `We want that $180m for road construction that you promised in New South Wales'. That will be more than the industry could responsibly or sensibly gear itself up to spend. So there is no need to worry at a Commonwealth level about road funding for New South Wales because there is going to be stacks of it if this promise is honoured.

I mention just a couple of other items. The coalition promised to halve the public housing waiting list in New South Wales over five years. That would cost $150m. It promised an extra $100m a year, maintained in real terms, for additional housing loans. Just in those three items, we are up to something over $400m of the $1.4 billion.

Finally, may I give a bit of gratuitous advice to Mr Greiner: if he wants to have a decent government he should follow Charlie Court's example in Western Australia and roll right over the National Party, just kick it in the stomach and take absolutely no notice of it and the fiscal and political irresponsibility that it habitually displays, because the National Party has nowhere else to go. I give Greiner that bit of gratuitous advice. If he follows it he might be a successful Premier. But I guarantee that he will not because, just like every other State and Federal Liberal Party Leader that I know of, except, as I said before, Charlie Court, he will not have the intestinal fortitude to do it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EXPORT OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND COMPONENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Yesterday the Minister boasted about the export of motor vehicles and components. Will these exports be subsidised by Australian consumers by the operation of the passenger motor vehicle plan, and, in particular, the export facilitation scheme? If so, by how much? Will the vehicles and components be sold to the foreign purchasers at prices no lower than the Australian wholesale prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should put the question in context. If Senator Lewis reads the Hansard, I think he will agree that it is an unfair characterisation to say that I boasted about export sales in respect of the passenger motor vehicle industry. The expression I used was that the Government greets these figures with cautious optimism. I would have hoped that the honourable senator would have done the same thing. I do not regard that as a boast; I regard it as a proper statement of fact. We can have cautious optimism about those sales.

ANSWER.PARA: The other context in which I would like to put the honourable senator's question is that this week he has been pursuing me about subsidy schemes for exports generally. He has been saying to me, `Look, you have delayed the payments in terms of subsidies under the export market development grants scheme'. The honourable senator has been on radio stations throughout Australia saying what a shocking thing it is that this Government has been delaying subsidies for exporters. He has been making a big fellow of himself on a radio program talking about that sort of stuff. He then comes in here and asks me whether there is to be a subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wants to know. Is there?

—Of course he wants to know. But in this case Senator Lewis needs to be helped with the learning process because that process is very important. I would have thought that Senator Lewis has to put his question in some sort of context. I just want to explain that to him.

ANSWER.PARA: I now turn to two issues in answer to the specific question. Sure, exports of motor vehicles and exports of components are subsidised to an extent under the export facilitation programs relating to the motor vehicle plan. The nature of the subsidy is somewhat different from the nature of the subsidies which are provided in other industries. The nature of the subsidy is simply that those companies which achieve certain export targets are allowed duty free entry of either motor vehicles or components into Australia in return for that export achievement. It is a slightly different sort of subsidy from the subsidies which often apply to exports. That is to say, there is a performance target directed at the exporters in order that they may attain certain benefits under the provisions of the export facilitation scheme. So the answer to that part of the question is yes, there is a subsidy. Any subsidy for any industry is in some way or another a cost to the Australian consumer. There is no doubt about that. One can go through the list industry by industry and reach the same conclusion.

On the question of whether components will be sold on foreign markets at a particular price, that is very much a commercial matter for the companies concerned in their negotiations with foreign buyers. Certainly, in terms of the price they arrive at, Australian companies will have the benefit of getting a subsidy in respect of their own import activities into Australia, as I have already explained. Of course, that will be a factor in enabling them to determine the price of their exported goods. Apart from that, all I can say is that this is a matter for determination between the two parties to any commercial agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not like the Opposition spokesman getting up his nostrils?
—All I can say to Senator Lewis is that I wish he would. If he would do so occasionally Question Time would not be so boring. Perhaps the honourable senator should try next week and see how he goes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to a succession of recent Press reports suggesting that Israel, India and Taiwan have acquired or are capable of acquiring nuclear weapons. In the light of these disturbing reports, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will continue its efforts to prevent the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons? Is the Minister aware that Palm Sunday rallies in support of peace and nuclear disarmament will be held across the country this Sunday? Will the Government continue to encourage community groups which are genuinely committed to arms control and disarmament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to its efforts to achieve a reduction in the nuclear arsenals of the nuclear weapons states, Australia is one of the foremost supporters of international action to limit the proliferation of nuclear weapons to other countries. The keystone of the current non-proliferation regime is of course the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) which came into force in 1970. With more than 130 members committed to preventing the further spread of nuclear weapons the NPT is one of the landmarks of international arms control efforts. Australia continues to take all available opportunities in international forums to support the aims of the Treaty and to urge those few countries which remain non-members to adhere to it.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been increasing public attention recently and frequent reports in the Press about the nuclear activities of the so-called threshold states-those countries with unsafeguarded nuclear facilities believed to be capable of producing nuclear weapons. Certainly, those reports are causing the Government great concern. Prominent among the countries in question are Israel, India, Pakistan and South Africa. Development of nuclear weapons by any such country would provide an incentive for all countries which feel threatened by those weapons to go down the same path. So the nuclear arms race begins-a race which threatens not only the region in which it takes place but also, of course, all humanity. Australia has urged, and will go on urging, all the threshold states to join the NPT or at least to place all their nuclear facilities under full scope safeguards as the best means of assuring their neighbours and the international community of the peaceful intent of their nuclear activities. There is of course no question of exporting Australian uranium to such countries. Thus, Australia is playing a major part in international efforts to strengthen and extend the international nuclear non-proliferation regime by increasing the obstacles to such countries acquiring nuclear weapons.

All along, the Government has emphasised that efforts against the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons are just as important as measures of arms control and disarmament which we also pursue as a matter of top priority. In that respect we are certainly heartened, as I hope all Australians are, by the current progress in the superpower arms control negotiations on deep cuts in their nuclear arsenals and wider international efforts on chemical and other weapons. We are very proud to be contributing to those developments.

As to the remaining part of Senator Childs's question, the Government recognises and applauds the Palm Sunday rallies to be held around the country at the weekend. They reflect a clear desire for peace on the part of Australian people. The Government's ongoing initiatives in the fields of arms control, disarmament and non-proliferation stem from and reflect the overwhelming support which the Australian people have manifested in the past and will continue to manifest, particularly on such occasions as the Palm Sunday rallies for the cause of global peace.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE: CONTINGENT IN CYPRUS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Why were telexes from the Australian Federal Police (AFP) contingent on Cyprus sent to the Soviet Embassy in Canberra? How many telexes were sent; on what subjects; and over what period? Were all of the messages in normal language or were some in code? If, as claimed in one news report two days ago, the Soviet Embassy always sends back messages advising the sender of the error, why was the mistake not realised until the arrival in Australia of an officer whose request for compassionate leave went astray? Does the Australian Federal Police use the telex system for communicating sensitive or secret information? What safety procedures does it follow to ensure that messages sent this way arrive at their proper destination? Does the Minister agree that it is very disturbing that police information can be so easily misdirected? Finally, what action will the Minister take to ensure that this ceases to occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I made a note of all the elements in the question but I can inform the Senate and Senator Teague that it is true that a number of cables from the Australian Federal Police contingent in Cyprus were mistakenly sent to the Soviet Embassy in Australia instead of AFP headquarters. The mistake was originally made due to the similarity in telex numbers for the two organisations and it was then repeated by the operator. The cables in question dealt with routine administrative matters only and were sent through the signals unit of the United Nations force in Cyprus. There is no substance to the Press reports and rumour that the Soviet Embassy replied to the telexes.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Federal Police informs me that there are few sensitive messages sent between its contingent in Cyprus and Australia, such sensitive messages being forwarded through the Australian High Commission in Cyprus. Steps have been taken to ensure that such mistakes do not recur. In fact, I held conversations with the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter McAulay, only two nights ago concerning this matter and sought his assurances in regard to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I would be grateful if the remaining questions could be taken on notice and answered. With regard to the Minister's reference to the telex numbers, can he make it quite clear to the Senate that the apparent excuse which was given-that there was a one-digit difference in telex numbers-can be put to rest? The Soviet Embassy's telex number-I think the Minister can confirm this-is 62602. The numbers for the Australian Federal Police are 62346, 61623, 62001, 62004, 61313 and 62736. There is not a one-digit difference in these numbers but several digits which are different.

—I have made no statement to this Senate saying that there was only a one-digit difference in the telex numbers. I will repeat what I said: I said it was `due to a similarity in the telex numbers for the two organisations'. Obviously, I will take up the matter of the number of digits difference in the two telex reception numbers and I will publish that information if it is relevant.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the recently published book Punishing the Poor by Eva Mysliwiec commissioned by the international aid consortium working with Khmer people in Kampuchea and on the Thai-Kampuchea border and which calls for international efforts to work towards a negotiated solution on Kampuchea? Will the Minister pursue and support the recommendations in this book Punishing the Poor? More specifically, will the Minister explain what conditions remain to be fulfilled for the Australian Government to recognise the state of Kampuchea and to restore bilateral aid to that country? Finally, will the Minister explain what Australia is doing now to further international efforts towards a political settlement of the Kampuchean dilemma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is aware of the book to which Senator Vallentine refers. He has drawn it to my attention and he has suggested that I make the following comments in relation to the quite significant recommendations made in that book which cover the range of matters to which Senator Vallentine refers. Firstly, as to the provision of aid, Australia is conscious of the intense suffering and deprivation of the Kampuchean people over and extended period. We provide aid to the Kampuchean people through multilateral agencies and Australian non-government organisations. In 1987-88 Australian aid donations to these agencies for work inside Kampuchea is expected to reach approximately $3.7m. Australian aid is provided on the basis of humanitarian considerations and is directed to meeting essential civilian requirements of basic shelter, sufficient food and water, primary health care and education.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the Khmer Rouge, Australians were deeply shocked by the atrocities committed by the Pol Pot regime. In the view of many countries, including Australia, the Pol Pot clique's continued presence within the coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea is a significant impediment to finding a solution to the dispute in that country. During the 1986-87 Association of South East Asian Nations post-ministerial meetings, Mr Hayden raised the question of establishing a tribunal to determine the culpability of the Pol Pot leadership. Whilst some interest was shown in that proposal, it has not to date attracted sufficient support to allow it to go ahead. Australia is firmly of the view that any settlement in Kampuchea must include arrangements to prevent the return to power of the Pol Pot group.

As to the question of the Thai-Kampuchea border, as a result of the dry season military campaigning along the border in early 1985, about 230,000 civilians were evacuated into Thailand. They have been provided with temporary sanctuary in camps administered by the Thai supreme command in cooperation with the United Nations Border Relief Organisation (UNBRO). The location of the camps in Thailand is a matter for the Thai authorities. UNBRO coordinates relief measures for the evacuees while the International Committee of the Red Cross has prime responsibility for protection. Australia has provided $750,000 to UNBRO in 1987-88 and further proposals for relief on the Thai-Kampuchean border are under consideration.

In relation to settlement prospects, Australia has been encouraged by recent signs of movement on the Kampuchea issue. We maintain close contacts with the parties involved in the dispute and encourage all efforts directed towards dialogue and a peaceful resolution of the issue. Most recently, Australia did welcome Prince Sihanouk's discussion with Hun Sen as a small first step towards settlement negotiations. Mr Hayden sent a message of support to Prince Sihanouk after that first round of talks. Bilateral aid will not be resumed until a negotiated settlement has brought about a peaceful, durable solution to the Kampuchean problem. However, Australian aid is provided under the auspices of multilateral and non-government agencies. I have already given an outline of Australia's efforts to promote movement towards a peaceful settlement.

Finally, under Australia's new recognition policy, which involves the recognition of states, not of governments, the question of the recognition of any particular government in Kampuchea simply does not arise. We remain of the view that no existing Kampuchean faction has a legitimate claim to acceptance as the representative of Kampuchea.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that the percentage of fuel tax revenue spent on improving roads has dropped from 67 per cent in 1984-85 to just 27 per cent in 1987-88, which is the lowest it has been for the past 50 years? Can the Minister explain the reasoning behind such a drop in funding when the tax on fuel is automatically increased in line with the consumer price index? Will the Minister give an assurance that the percentage of fuel tax revenue allocated to all roads, not just highways, will be increased from the present 5.355c a litre to at least 7c a litre to enable the condition of country roads throughout Australia to be improved?

—I will take that question on notice. I cannot remember enough about the subject from the previous portfolio I held. Mr Morris is handling it these days. I want to give Senator Bjelke-Petersen a decent answer and I am sure she will appreciate that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Has the attention of the Minister been drawn to media reports of an apparent turnabout by the Queensland Government over uniform gun laws? Was the thrust of this legislation, aimed at helping to prevent unlawful killings, agreed upon last week by all States except Tasmania-including Queensland? Was the Queensland Police Minister, Mr Gunn, totally supportive of the thrust of the proposed legislation? Was any verbal or written agreement obtained from Mr Gunn on this point? What will be the effect on the gun law legislation of Queensland Premier Michael Ahern's apparent pragmatic about-face which now apparently links Queensland with Tasmania as the only State governments in opposition to the measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was somewhat astonished to read Press reports to the effect that the Queensland Government, and specifically the Premier, Mr Ahern, had repudiated the resolutions passed by the Australian Police Ministers Council in which I clearly understood that Mr Gunn, the Police Minister and Deputy Premier, had concurred. If one reads the media release issued after the special meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council last Friday afternoon, which Press release was issued under the authority of Mr Gunn, one will see he says this:

ANSWER.PARA: The resolutions will form the basis for the implementation of uniform firearms controls and will lead hopefully to a more responsible community attitude towards the use of firearms.

That is a direct quote attributed in the Press release to Mr Gunn. When one looks at the resolutions listed in that Press release one finds, for example, that Queensland supported the resolution to support the banning of all automatic firearms and to support the restriction of access to semi-automatic firearms to a limited category of authorised users having a legitimate occupation or sporting need to possess such firearms, including members of approved sporting shooting clubs for use in approved competitive events.

Queensland also agreed that strict licensing or other forms of lawful control should apply to the possession of firearms and that licences and/or permits to purchase should be issued subject to the requirement that the person is deemed to be a fit and proper person to possess a firearm, is able to demonstrate a genuine reason for possessing the firearm and is able to demonstrate competence in firearm safety and knowledge of firearms law in the jurisdiction. Again, Queensland agreed that before people may purchase firearms they must obtain permits to purchase them, and the Council noted the desirability of a cooling off period between the issue of the permit and the first purchase.

Again, in relation to registration, Queensland agreed-only Tasmania dissenting on this point as I recall-that all firearms purchased after a date to be agreed by Council at its meeting on 25 November 1988 should be recorded by an appropriate authority in each jurisdiction.

I have taken some time to read those resolutions and Mr Gunn's accompanying comment in his Press release because it is quite clear that there has been either a confusion, a misunderstanding or a deliberate turnaround by the Queensland Government since the meeting on Friday. The Brisbane Sun of 24 March-today-in an editorial says:

The Media releases on the subject were quite clear. What happened is that Mr Gunn either got caught up in the fervour of the moment and agreed to something without checking with the boss or both he and Mr Ahern changed their minds after sleeping on it.

I am not necessarily going to go that far. I believe the Australian Police Ministers Council-at least a majority, Tasmania dissenting on most points-attempted to use language and to give as much flexibility to Queensland as was consistent with achieving the objective of an Australia-wide approach to the question of gun control. For that reason we were not wedded to any particular language and certainly were not looking for identical legislation in each jurisdiction. If a particular jurisdiction does not want to use the words `licence', `permit' or `registration' that is quite beside the point. One is not seeking that at all. What one is seeking is that the substance of those resolutions be incorporated in the statutory and regulatory arrangements in each jurisdiction. I believe the Queensland Government, with its particular emphasis on permits to purchase, the accompanying requirements before a permit to purchase can be obtained and the recording of that permit to purchase together with a sales docket where a purchase has occurred in reliance on the permit, would have in fact satisfied those resolutions. I believe that Queensland can work within that framework. Also, I believe that the Police Minister for New South Wales will be appointed this afternoon, and I look forward to conversations with him. Without the incoming New South Wales Government adopting every element of the Unsworth proposals on gun controls, I feel that it may find itself able to work within the resolutions of the Australian Police Ministers Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Durack asked me a series of questions in relation to the extension of the civil coastal surveillance contract, which I answer as follows: First, has the Government paid Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd $1.2m for the extension of the contract? The answer is no. However, the Government has agreed to pay Skywest $1.284m to reimburse costs incurred by Skywest in bringing its coastal surveillance fleet back to the same standard which applied prior to its being notified in March 1987 that its contract would not be renewed. Following notification that its contract would not be renewed, Skywest had disposed of one aircraft and committed three others to another contract commencing after 12 September 1987. The reimbursement costs in question were assessed by the Department in conjunction with an independent assessor, Price Waterhouse and Urwick, as being fair and reasonable.

ANSWER.PARA: The second question was: What has Skywest spent this money on? As indicated in my previous answer, the Government has not yet paid the sum mentioned. The costs for refurbishing aircraft are currently being met by Skywest and include the purchase of special communications and navigation equipment, painting to coastwatch livery, drop hatches and bubble windows.

The third question was: Is Skywest using only eight aircraft? The answer is no. I understand that Skywest currently has 12 serviceable aircraft on line with one more coming on line at the end of this month, when equipment refurbishment is completed.
The fourth question was: Is this in accord with the terms of the interim contract? The answer is that this is not applicable in light of my answer to the previous question.

The final question was: Is the figure of eight aircraft the same number that Amann Aviation Pty Ltd had when its contract terminated on 12 September 1987? The answer is no. When Amann's contract was terminated it had seven serviceable aircraft available. However, none of these fully met the specifications required in the contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on the operations of the Bankruptcy Act is for the 12 months from July 1985 to 30 June 1986-and it is now March 1988. The standard of reporting is, in other words in terms of time taken, not simply disgraceful but a matter which the Government should promptly address. The nature of the report is not such as to justify a delay of that order from 30 June 1986 to March 1988. It is intolerable and I hope that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is reasonable in these matters, will seek to improve the quality of the work of his colleague the Attorney-General. I can understand why the Government was not keen to get this report forward because it reveals that bankruptcies are exceeding even the record levels that were experienced earlier in this Labor Administration.

So far this year there has been a 45 per cent increase over the bankruptcy rates before this Government came into office. Although the figures revealed in this annual report relate only to the 1985-86 period, subsequent statistics have been issued by the Attorney-General on a quarterly basis, but have not been subject to the detail or analysis available in this annual report. We note, however, that the reasons for bankruptcy are depressing. The main one seems to relate to the fact that, under this Government, it is easier for people to be forced into bankruptcy because of the combination of high interest rates and the taxes, charges and the anti-incentive policies introduced by this Government. Many ordinary Australians-not simply businesses-are going bankrupt because of the severe cuts in their standard of living which has occurred under the present Government.

Clearly, Australia now has the highest number of bankruptcies on record. About 8,000 businesses are going to the wall under the Hawke Government's high interest rate policies and bankruptcy figures in the latest quarter indicate that the situation will be even worse than it was last year. I would expect about 9,000 bankruptcies in the current financial year judging by the interim figures so far. Of course, the effect of the recent stock market crash can only place additional pressure on an already alarmingly high level of bankruptcies. When this dramatic increase in the level of bankruptcies was raised by my colleague in the other place Allan Cadman, MP recently, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, simply said:

Look you make no point about bankruptcies of small businesses, they are on all the time. What one must look at is the buoyancy of the economy and the buoyancy of business in particular and that's what this Government has delivered.

Clearly, the Government does not care about small businesses going broke and the fact that bankruptcies are at record levels. Many of these are small businesses that have been established by hard working newcomers to Australia from overseas and, as I have said, this has been exacerbated by the high interest rate policies of this Government.

In conclusion, I urge the Minister to do what he can to ensure that figures of vital concern to Australians, contained in the annual report of the Attorney-General entitled Operation of the Bankruptcy Act 1966, be made available more readily so that we can really see just what disastrous consequences are following from the anti-small business and anti-consumer policies of this Government-particularly its high interest rates, high taxes and general anti-small business approach.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Patterson:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the report of the National Health and Medical Research Council, not just because I noticed in it that my brother, Professor Sheil, at the University of Sydney, was given quite a considerable grant and that grant is to be repeated next year. It is a comprehensive report and covers a lot of ground, but I would like to mention a couple of things that the National Health and Medical Research Council has brought to our attention. The first is the advertising of foods, many of which are dangerous, in Australia. They are widely advertised in the print and electronic media and are actually causing health problems. The Council has called for a conference between the various authorities and the media to see whether they can agree on some sort of code which will preclude this kind of mischievous advertising. I draw that to the attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Council points out to people the dangers of calcium intake, which is in vogue in Australia today, for the treatment of osteoporosis in women after their menopause; that is, when their bones are getting thinner. The Council points out that we can get all the calcium we need from milk and cheese rather than by taking high doses of calcium which do not cure the condition and which can be dangerous in producing other conditions in people.

The third and last issue I wish to raise is the mention in the report of the National Health and Medical Research Council of the bringing into Australia of smokeless tobacco. This has been proven to be dangerous overseas but it is allowed into Australia at the moment. We ought to take action to see that imports are prohibited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) because I would like to place on record my admiration for the work of the Council which is clearly evidenced by this report. I would like to say also that the Council deserves support in what I hope are its successful attempts to make sure that the growing fashion of saying that medical research is somehow in competition with other scientific research and perhaps is entitled to a lesser share of the cake does not come to fruition. It is important to put on the record that there is a need for blue sky, non-contract research to be carried out in this country. Although there is again a fashion of saying that perhaps we are better served by having specific contract research done, it is well to remember that many important discoveries that are being made in the scientific field have arisen from blue sky, pure research where the product that may have come as a result has not been the specific end of the research.

SPEECH.PARA: Concurrent with this thinking is that we need always to keep the best brains in this country. In the event that research grants and university research functions are not maintained, many of our better brains and those people who contribute to the overall wealth of knowledge in this country will be tempted to leave. The grant system which is administered by the NHMRC is an important one. It realises as well that the element of private funding for research is an important aspect. Many researchers have to go through a very competitive and extensive peer review system to show what their research is doing and this is commendable. But if there are not sufficient resources for a sufficient number of researchers to be successful, we will ultimately be the poorer for it.

Private funding is an area with which I am familiar. I spent some seven years on the board of the Asthma Foundation of New South Wales. Indeed, I was its vice-president and chairman of its appeal committee in 1975. The thrust of the Foundation has been to support research. I know from the experience that I have had that when one is raising private funds for that purpose one will always find it easier if one says to the general public, `It will buy a bed or a respirator'-something to which a name can be given or a specific thing which can be seen. But when one is selling the concept of research and that ultimately people's health will benefit by some breakthrough that may occur in the future, it is a much more difficult concept for people to come to terms with. Yet the result of much of that research has been the improvement in the management of asthma and the lives of the people who suffer from it. Its incidence appears to be growing when we look at the number of sufferers in Australia. There is no cure, but the research has enabled better management, better health and a better standard of living for those people who are receiving treatment.

It is important that we do not lose good and able people-people whose minds are attracted to research. It is truly a vocation; it is truly something that some people have a specific facility for which they exercise well in this nation. When we talk about cutting back in the pure research area, if we are not careful we will take away from the collective wisdom and medical knowledge that make up the base and the rigour medical research and practices in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago I spoke about the acceptance of a paper by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) on home births and alternative birthing centres. Following that paper, which had many problems associated with it-a lack of statistics, lack of any mention of the morbidity of the mother or the baby in association with home births, and lack of scientific data or a scientific approach at all by the committee that looked at the matter-I sent a copy of my speech to the NHMRC and to Dr Cathy Mead, Secretary/Convenor of the Women's Health Committee that put forward the paper. Since than I have received a letter from Dr Cathy Mead. I was delighted that she wrote as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Women's Health Committee which established the Working Party on Homebirths and Alternative Birth Centres considered your comments along with other comments received at its most recent meeting. Following discussion of these comments the Women's Health Committee has recommended that a consultative group be established to prepare a supplementary statement on homebirths and address minimum standards for implementation. Representatives of the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, the Australian College of Paediatrics, and the Australian College of Midwives will be invited to join this group which will be chaired by Dr Aileen Connon, Chairman of the Women's Health Committee. The consultative group will be able to consider the comments you have made.

This was a very worthwhile exercise. I shall be looking forward to receiving a copy of the review. I note that this is not uncommon. Evidently there was another one, a working party to revise the document `Organisation of Peri-natal Services'. A committee has been set up to review that document.

It concerns me, I suppose, that the NHMRC, which I have always held in great esteem, accepts documents from its working parties without really giving them the due consideration that such a body should give such documents. It is strange that the NHMRC has to conduct reviews of its considered acceptances. As I say, I am looking forward very much to the working party's review, and I thank Dr Cathy Mead for taking note of my comments and for setting up such a review panel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Flags Amendment Bill 1987, which has been introduced by the Opposition, I reiterate the purpose for its introduction-that is, to ensure that our national flag cannot be changed unless the people are asked and give their consent and approval. The Bill is identical to that introduced in the Senate in 1984 by Senator Peter Durack. The Bill was passed by the Senate early in 1985. On transmittal to the House of Representatives, however, its progress was thwarted by the Hawke Government and it was not debated-hence the need to reintroduce the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I am proud to have been the inaugural Vice-President of the Australian National Flag Association in New South Wales. Since being elected to the Senate, I have stood down as Vice- President, and I have been honoured to be made an honorary member of the Council of Management, so that my interest continues. Indeed, next Wednesday there will be an important presentation to people who have honoured the flag by the Australian National Flag Association, which is an important activity that the Association carries out.

The reason that the Flag Association was established was not a reactive measure but a proactive measure. It was designed to promote the use and knowledge of the Australian national flag. Indeed, the brochure for membership says that the aims and objectives of the Association are as follows:
To communicate positively to all Australians the importance and significance of our chief national symbol-the Australian National Flag;
To provide promotional and educational material concerning the existing Australian National Flag;
To promote the Australian identity overseas by the use of the Australian National Flag;
To support existing `fly the flag' programs and encourage support from recognised service organisations;
To encourage personal identity with the Australian National Flag at all levels within the community.

The Flag Association has been very successful. It exists right across Australia and has a very high membership of thousands and thousands of people. Indeed, I shall quote some of the words in a most important publication, The Flags of Australia, which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This magnificent poster, which is a bicentennial project, depicts all the flags of Australia since the discovery of this continent and the use of the Queen Anne flag. Printed on it are these words:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Flag is our chief national symbol within Australia and overseas. It identifies a free and democratic people in a nation united in purpose, custom and traditions. Our National flag belongs equally to all Australians whatever their origins. It is the right and privilege of every Australian to fly the Australian National Flag.

But again, the concern and the reason for the introduction of this Bill, the underlying disquiet which many Australians feel, are very simply that the flag could be changed very easily by the Australian Labor Party-indeed, the Labor Government. I would cite as evidence for this a report in the Sun of 11 June 1986 under the heading, `Change the Flag and abolish the Senate'. The report stated:
A top level Labor Party committee plans to change the national flag and abolish the Senate in the most significant constitutional overhaul since Federation.
The radical policy, to be put at next month's ALP National Conference in Hobart, also backs the fixed term four-year Parliaments Prime Minister Bob Hawke promised in 1983.
Bob Hawke has promised many things over time, some of which have been honoured and some of which have not.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wants to abolish the States, too.

—Indeed, he does. It is important to note that the assurance by the Prime Minister that the Government simply had no plans before it at that time to change the flag was given contemporaneously with the statement I just read from the Sun publication in 1986. Quite frankly, the people of Australia do not believe that that assurance is enough. They do not feel assured that our flag, our national symbol, is safe. There are many arguments as to why the Australian national flag is held so dearly by the majority of Australians. The push by Ausflag 88 to try to have the flag changed in the bicentennial year was founded simply on the ambition of a few people without sounding the wishes of the rest of Australia. So the debates that ensued and the so-called alternatives that ensued were rather facile and were accorded no response from the Australian people except to engender further determination, as has been evidenced by the number of petitions to this place calling on the Government to ensure that our national symbol cannot be changed without the people being asked.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that a country that has such little heritage is celebrating 200 years of settlement. We have been a nation only since 1901. As a nation that needs an important heritage, we are far too young to try to jettison any that we have. Our flag is an important symbol and should be treated in an holistic way. It is not something that one should pull apart and say, `I like this bit but I reject that bit'. The flag is a symbol that is important to all Australians. Indeed, Australian forces have died under it while fighting for the freedom that it represents.

From time to time in this bicentennial year we hear arguments concerning the maturing of the Australian nation. To me, maturity means that one accepts the facts. They are that we were settled by the British, and we inherited British institutions. In a splendid address given by Mr Justice Michael Kirby entitled `The Anglo Aren't the Enemy' in response to I think Mr Donald Horne's paper to the effect that the Anglos are the enemy, Mr Justice Michael Kirby pointed out that it is the British institutions that have engendered a tolerance in this nation, a tolerance which has enabled us to accept people from different cultures and ethnic backgrounds. Those people have added to the collective whole that now makes up Australia. Some like to call it multiculturalism but we can also call it an enriched cultural Australia.

The point I want to make is that if a nation is maturing it must accept its origins as a matter of fact and not pretend that they did not exist. As we go forth into the Pacific region and say that we are an important player in the region, we will go forward from a position of strength if we acknowledge that we are a Western culture in an Asian region, that as a people we know who we are, that we are proud of our origins and admit that perhaps there are things in our past that we might hope had been done differently, but which nonetheless we acknowledge, just as we acknowledge our origins.

In keeping our flag in its present form we are saying that we are sure of who we are and that we are maturing as a people. It disappoints me greatly when I hear the Ausflag people say that somehow by maintaining our flag as we do, we are not an independent and rigorous nation. I say that the true argument is the contrary: by saying that this is our flag which by its design recognises our origins, we say that we are a proud, free and independent people.

Historically it is interesting to note that in 1901 the original competition to design our flag received 32,823 entries from men, women and children. The judges assessed those entries using guidelines which included history, heraldry, distinctiveness, utility and cost of manufacture. On 3 September 1901 a public ceremony was held at the Exhibition Building in Melbourne where Lady Hopetoun, the wife of the Governor-General, opened a display of entries in the competition. The Prime Minister of Australia, Edmund Barton, announced that the five entrants who had submitted similar designs were to share the honour of being declared the designers of Australia's own flag. They were Ivor Evans, a 14-year-old school boy from Melbourne; Leslie John Dawkins, a teenager apprenticed to a Sydney optician; Egbert John Nuttall, a Melbourne architect; Annie Dorrington, an artist from Perth; and William Stevens, a ships officer from New Zealand. The Commonwealth Government and the Review of Reviews for Australasia each provided #75, to which the Havelock Tobacco Co. added #50, making a total of #200 prize money-a considerable amount of money at that time. The five winners each received #40. It is interesting that when Ausflag launched its competition for what produced some rather good logos, as distinct from national emblems, it received considerably fewer entries than were received from a far smaller population in 1901.

The important thing that this Bill will ensure is that our flag will be given a proper place within our constitutional framework. Our flag will not be dismissed, as it was by Senator Gareth Evans when on 15 September 1985 he was asked by Senator Kilgariff what had happened to the progress of the Bill introduced in the Senate by Senator Durack entitled the Flags Amendment Bill 1984. As six months had passed, Senator Kilgariff asked, `If the Government does intend to process the Bill, when will this take place?'. Senator Gareth Evans, adopting a flippant attitude, as he often does, said, `I have no brief on this matter, but it is my understanding that the Bill has died a well deserved death in the other House'. That is the sort of attitude which is unacceptable and which the people of Australia find unacceptable.

That is why this Bill is important and why it is being debated here today. I can only hope, as the Bill goes through the processes of this Parliament, that it will meet with more respectful and more befitting treatment than it received on its previous journey. In commending the Bill to the Senate I say that should we pass this Bill we will be thanked by the people of Australia who regard their flag as their national symbol, an important expression of their pride in what is a great, mature, independent and resolute nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Flags Amendment Bill 1984, which essentially is designed to so amend the Flags Act 1953 as to prevent the Government of the day designating flags, other than that which we all recognise as the Australian flag, as flags for special occasions. In Senator Durack's second reading speech when he introduced the Flags Amendment Bill 1984, prior to the last double dissolution, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Fortunately the flag is prescribed by the Flags Act 1953 and the flag designated as the `Australian national flag' could only be changed by legislation. Nevertheless, the Act does allow the Governor-General to `appoint such other flags and ensigns of Australia as he thinks fit'.

In other words, the Government may, by advice to the Governor-General, designate other flags for special occasions. These occasions could conceivably cover a whole range of events such as the Olympic Games or on any occasion when our nationality on the world stage is on show. The object of this amendment is to prevent the Government by this surreptitious means replacing the Australian flag with a new de facto flag of its choice.
Senator Durack stated in his second reading speech:

2. The Governor-General will be specifically prohibited from appointing, upon the advice of the Government, `other flags or ensigns' as the standard for the Commonwealth of Australia, the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia or the Australian nation. This will prevent the Government from advising the Governor-General to appoint other flags to challenge or detract from the Australian flag as the symbol of our nation or national institutions.

A referendum provision is also inserted in the amendment to ensure that the Australian national flag cannot be amended or replaced without a referendum voted on in the manner prescribed in the Constitution in regard to constitutional amendments. In other words, the referendum would be of a type that would require a majority of votes in the majority of States.

There is a widely-held but mistaken view that Australia has had foisted upon it or has inherited a flag from Great Britain. Of course, the truth is to be found elsewhere. Therefore, I bother to give just a short history of the Australian flag to demonstrate that this is not so. As we all know of course the first national flag raised in Australia was a Dutch flag. It was raised by Abel Tasman when he discovered Van Diemen's Land, as it was then known. We were told that in fact one of his sailors braved wild surf to take the flag ashore. The flag history of Australia as a British possession began on 29 April 1770 when Captain James Cook raised the flag at Botany Bay. A few months later, on 22 August 1770 at a ceremony on Possession Island off Cape York, Cook raised the flag again and, on that occasion, formally claimed the east coast of the continent in the name of King George III. However, Britain did not of course take physical possession of eastern Australia until 18 years later when New South Wales was founded. This delay gave the French time to make their territorial claims. They did this when the flag was raised by Lieutenant Francois de Saint Allorarn at Shark Bay in Western Australia. Coincidentally, this is the place at which this evening there is to be a large public meeting of people who have taken exception to the World Heritage legislation passed in this chamber this morning.

As I understand, the next known flag to be raised into our skies was that raised by Governor Arthur Phillip in 1788 at Sydney Cove when he founded the first British colony. Of course, the flag that was raised on that occasion was not the Union Jack. It was the Union flag-the distinction being that it contained only the red cross of St George and the white saltire of St Andrew. The red saltire of St Patrick was not added to the union flag until 1801 when Ireland officially became part of the United Kingdom. As we know the English flag is not the Union Jack, as is popularly understood.

We further learn that in the early 1820s two sea captains, Nicholson and Bingle, made the first real attempt to give Australia a flag of its own. It was approved by the Lords of the Admiralty and it is known to have had a white background charged with the red cross of St George with, in each corner, a star, symbolising the Southern Cross. For obvious reasons the flag never attracted the wider imagination of the Australian people, primarily because it offended those of Scottish or Irish descent. While it included the Cross of St George, it excluded the cross of St Andrew and the cross of St Patrick.

Over the years there were several more attempts at designing and establishing an Australian flag. Perhaps one of the most notable and most popular was the Anti-Transportation League banner of about 1851. As I understand it, that flag was remarkably similar to the present Australian flag-it featured the Union Jack in the hoist and had the five stars of the Southern Cross in the fly. We then had the Eureka Stockade flag of 1854-a flag which has now been adopted by the Builders Labourers Federation. That flag has a broad white cross and five white stars resting on a blue background. As best I understand it, there were no other memorable flags created until 1873 when the Australian Federation League was formed in Sydney. The League's slogan was, `One people-one destiny-one flag'. Again this flag had a Union Jack in the hoist and featured a pale blue cross with a white star at the extremity of each corner and a white star in the middle.

In 1900, with Federation almost a reality, the Melbourne Herald conducted a competition seeking designs for an Australian flag. The winner produced a flag which, again, included the Union Jack, the stars of the Southern Cross and six red stripes to symbolise the six States. A further flag competition was conducted by the Review of Reviews. This competition was in progress when Federation was proclaimed on New Year's Day in 1901. The first Australian Government then joined with the Review of Reviews in the search for a national flag. The total prize money was #400. As was pointed out by the previous speaker, Senator Bishop, there was a total of 32,823 entrants in that competition. There were five winners, not the least being a lady Mrs Dorrington, from Western Australia. In 1909 the flag was changed to include a further white point, to add the seventh point to the Commonwealth Star, to symbolise the Territories of the Commonwealth of Australia.
