I have spent some little time giving the history and evolution of the present Australian flag to make it clear that the flag we have is unquestionably an Australian flag-developed, designed and accepted by all Australians. It is interesting to note that in this evolutionary process there are two features that seem to thread their way in the design of so many of the flags. These are, of course, the Union Jack and the Southern Cross. It is often argued by those people who want our national flag changed that we should follow the Canadian system and adopt a new national flag. Perhaps that argument can be put no better than by quoting the words of Mr R. B. Walker, a past mayor of Launceston. He said in a very articulate way in an article in the Hobart Mercury of 31 October 1983:
The adoption by Canada of a new national flag is sometimes given as a good reason why Australia should do the same.
May I point out that the circumstances prompting the Canadian action are entirely different from those prevailing in Australia.

French culture and traditions preceded the British in Canada and the names of Champlain, La Salle, Cartier and Cadillac are writ large in the early history of Canada and the fruits of their achievements did not die with Montcalm on the Heights of Abraham in 1759.

Because the great divisions and bitterness between the British and French in Canada have never really abated to this day, it was decided that the best way to bridge the gap was to try to start afresh under a new flag and most would agree this was the sensible course to take.
Even so, the Union Flag is retained in the Canadian arms and in several of the provincial flags.

I might add that it was in 1925 that the debate on a new Canadian flag commenced. At that time a committee was formed for the purpose of designing a new flag. It was in 1965, some 40 years later, that Canada's new flag was first raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very nice flag it is too.

—I do not disagree with that. It is interesting to note that, in the end, the bitter arguments and debates that raged throughout Canada for 40 years were settled because the Liberal Party abandoned the flag designed by their Prime Minister and agreed to the design adopted by the Conservatives. The Conservatives never intended that their flag should ever get up because they did not want to change the flag. However, they did not want to be seen as obstructionists, so they proposed a flag. The smarties in the Liberal Party joined them and they found themselves with a new flag.
—Would you agree with half the Union Jack?

—That gives me some hope that we will retain the present flag. Mr Walker also dealt very eloquently with the argument used by some that the present flag does not reflect the character of our comparatively recent migrants. In the same article he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are those Australians who pander to these comparative newcomers, using them as a vehicle to advance their own views and ambitions.

I would only say that when the United States flung open its doors to foreign immigrants after the Civil War, the same arguments could have been applied. However, those people from alien cultures were encouraged, and indeed expected, to accept the stars and stripes and they certainly did so. `Accept' is the key word, and why not? Those immigrants proudly chose to assume, as their own, the American flag and tradition, and to no mean effect. Yet, looking back to their old motherlands and retaining most of what was good, they left their impact on the American way of life, to its general benefit, as they have done in Australia to ours. But the United States still has its Old Glory.

It seems, for reasons which I am not thoroughly certain I understand, that there is some embarrassment, shame, cringing or an inferiority complex which causes some people in Australia to seek to deny the fact that we were first settled by the English. It is as if something causes them to want to disguise that fact. I am not certain I understand what their obsession is with cutting these intrinsic links with our heritage and that of our forefathers and forebears. We have inherited the finest judicial, legal and political system. Many of those migrants who are used as an excuse to change the flag, because it has no intrinsic merit or relationship for them, are the same migrants who fled to Australia from totalitarian regimes seeking comfort and the coverage and support of the very fabric of institutions which Australia is able to provide because of the inheritance it received from the English. It is the recognition and acknowledgment of those fine values and institutions which is causing some people, for reasons which I do not understand, to seek to deny them. I rather wonder what this obsession is that drives people in the Australian Labor Party to deny fundamental Australian history. What is it that causes them to deny Australia's historic links with England? Is it part of their wider proposal for an Australian republic? Is it that, for some reason, they want to sever links with the monarchy? I always find it passing strange that whenever members of the royal family visit Australia, it is the Labor Party leaders, in that obsequious way which only they can demonstrate, who fawn around them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not me.

—I accept that; perhaps Senator Ray does not do so. However, I have watched his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his obsequious, fawning way, seeking just to stand near enough to the royal family to attract some of the reflection of popular adulation which invariably goes with the royal family when it visits Australia because of our feeling of warmth for and our relationship with the United Kingdom. However, when we hear talk of Australia becoming a republic, we find no sophisticated explanation for what is intended. It seems to be, in some way, driven by an inferiority complex. It seems to be a statement of social values and has nothing to do with political argument. It is almost a cultural statement. It is as if to say, `We can't stand up alone in the shadow of our forefathers'.

SPEECH.PARA: I can conceive of only two premises upon which the Labor Party would wish to extinguish any perceived ties with the United Kingdom. Perhaps one, as I have suggested, is that there are those in the Labor Party who are smitten with an enormous inferiority complex and are unable to cope other than to stand in isolation. Perhaps they are smothered or intimidated by their historical links. If it is not that, I can only imagine that there are other radical changes which they would have in Australia's system, in Australian society, which would cause them to remove all their ties and links. It is almost as if they want to obliterate our collective institutional memory. It is almost as if they no longer want any datum point. As Senator Ray would know better than most, the method of introducing radical changes into any system, in whatever form it may take, is to cut loose from previous norms, forms and comparisons and to remove oneself from the foundation and base from which one developed and matured. If one divorces one's system from intrinsic comparisons by which new and radical reforms can be compared, there is no longer a datum point; there is no way of making a relative comparison. I can only assume that the Labor Party, for whatever reasons, wants those radical reforms and understands that they can best be achieved in a vacuum, in isolation-certainly not by way of comparison.

I conclude by saying that it is obvious that the Labor Party has no love for this legislation. Certainly, it has no enthusiasm for it. Clearly, through the normal insidious, surreptitious manner in which it seeks to change society in this country, it wants to change the flag; not by way of a constitutional vote but by way of a proclamation-in the same way as the Prime Minister gave us his colours for our country. I note-it is referred to in Senator Short's second reading speech-that the Labor Party's 1986 platform, in the context of preparations for the bicentennial celebrations, was to initiate and support moves to establish, with popular acceptance, an Australian flag. I love the words `popular acceptance'. What does that mean? Is it like the Government's form of consensus-as long as Bob Hawke agrees, everybody will agree with him?

We are told that we will have a national day, a national anthem, which will more distinctly reflect our national independence and identity, and a new Australian national flag. It is as though, for some reason, that which we have at present is not adequate, satisfactory and necessary. We have to have change for change's sake. We have to have change so that, at the end of the day, this failed Government can look back and reflect upon material achievements to the extent that it was able to change the flag or the national anthem. I have no doubt that this legislation has overwhelming support from the vast majority of the community. If this Government wants, as it says it does, to reflect the community view, it ought to allow this legislation to be passed expeditiously through not only this chamber but also the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Looking through the Opposition speakers list this afternoon, I was reminded of that great baseball side, the New York Yankees, which at one stage in the 1930s and 1940s had a batting line-up called Murderers' Row-Lou Gehrig, Babe Ruth and others. It was the most fearsome combination in American baseball. We have seen a similar replication here today on the Opposition speakers list. All of the hard Right of the Liberal Party of Australia are giving us 15 to 20 minutes on the essence of conservatism. There are one or two missing. I notice that Senator McGauran has not made the speakers list. Seeing he is here, maybe he is, in baseball terms, a switch hitter and will be coming in to supplement the line-up.
—Where do you and Collins stand?

—We have only two speakers. We believe that we can outweigh the Opposition speakers, both physically and mentally. There are two of us against six or seven Opposition speakers. I think the Opposition would agree with us on at least one of those grounds. It is curious to note that it must be the turn of the Right wingers in the Liberal Party to speak this afternoon. I wonder where all the wets are this afternoon. No doubt they are in the library or somewhere else.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we will listen to speaker after speaker give us a distillation of what conservatism really is. I wonder about Senator Crichton-Browne. I acknowledge that today he has put on the record what conservatism is. I feel sorry for him and I feel sorry for all conservatives if what he has said today is a reality of their lives. I feel sorry for them if they sit trembling, worrying about every piece of change or if, like the Amish community, they want to retain everything like it is. I really wonder whether Senator Crichton-Browne sleeps with the light on because he is so frightened of what the future may hold. I acknowledge that Senator Crichton-Browne is a good conservative inasmuch as he thinks about what conservatism really means. But I do not, and never will, support a purely conservative viewpoint in society. As honourable senators know, I will not support a revolutionary one either. I believe that real change comes about gradually.

We have heard from Senator Bishop who detailed what she regards as one of the crowning achievements of her life in New South Wales, namely, being on the Australian Flag Committee or something. I really wonder about Senator Bishop. Did she ever support the changing of the National Anthem? I suspect not. Maybe she would have supported changing it to the Horst Wessel Song or something. I really do wonder whether the honourable senator supported the change in the anthem.

This political exercise is really about the politics of exploitation, something that the right wing of the Liberal Party has always been good at. It operates something like this: one of the best ways of engendering support in the community is to create an atmosphere of fear. That is the politics of exploitation, the thing that Senator Knowles, Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Bishop and others have done par excellence. It was a lesson well learnt by Robert Menzies. He was not necessarily conservative, but this was just one of his techniques. I do not regard him as being conservative or reactionary per se. This technique has been used in respect of the flag. It is used in terms of talking to migrant communities. Right across the community we have this politics of exploitation.

Senator Crichton-Browne gave us a psychoanalysis of the Australian Labor Party. He told us what our methodology is. He said that in fact the only way to make progress is to cut the ties with the past. I do not believe that that is true. We on this side of the House have a good sense of history. We are proud of our heritage and in no way do we want to deny the heritage of this country. Our nation has many roots-British, European and, now, Asian. I think his psychoanalysis of the Labor Party is wrong inasmuch as we do not deny our past. We are proud of our past and we are proud of the role that Australia has played in a whole range of things.

Let me move to the second point. People have raised the question of what is the future of this Bill. Quite clearly, if the Bill gets the numbers in this chamber-and if the 1984 vote does not change, it will-it will go to the House of Representatives. People opposite seem to be arguing that we have a moral obligation to consider the agenda that they have set for us. I am about to tell them that we do not. We have no obligation to pick up any private member's Bill out of here and run it through the House of Representatives. I guess if we did, and we had a consistent attitude, all that there would be in the House of Representatives would be a debate and a defeat because we have the numbers in that place, just as today the Opposition has the numbers here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you say you are going to defeat it, Senator Ray? Why do you assume it will be defeated?

—I put in a presumption. I said `if' we were motivated to defeat it in the House of Representatives. If Senator Crichton-Browne had listened properly, he would understand what I said. I am putting on the record now that there is no obligation from a moral or ethical point of view for a government to have to list legislation that is brought forward by the Opposition. Indeed, if we look at the record of the Liberal Party when in government, we can see that private member's Bills were passed in this chamber, sent over to the House of Representatives and listed in that place at the bottom of the Notice Paper. I am not complaining about that. They are the facts of life. Honourable senators opposite will be able to get the legislation passed in the House of Representatives in 1990, 1993 and 1996 or whenever, when they get 50 per cent plus one of the votes. So it is just a pure debating point to say that in the natural course of things this issue should go to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go to what the Government's intentions are with regard to the flag. I suppose I hinted at that some months ago in answer to a question by Senator Short. My view is that this is not a key issue in politics; that in the life of the third Hawke Government the matter is very unlikely to be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlikely?

—It is very unlikely to be addressed. It falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I have no instructions via a Cabinet minute or anything else to raise this as an issue. When people have written to me and said that they do not want the Australian flag changed, I have drawn to their attention comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in answer to questions in the House of Representatives in which he indicated that we have no current plans to change the Australian flag. That, in fact, happens to be true.
—What happened to your 1986 policy?

—The 1986 policy refers to us changing the flag in a certain period. I counsel Senator Crichton-Browne, and anyone else who is interested, to read the foreword to the national platform of the Labor Party. Unfortunately I do not have it with me. The most crucial thing ever carried by a national conference is the three to four paragraph foreword because it delegates to the Federal parliamentary Labor Party the right to implement policy over time. Indeed, it is a great myth that everything that is in the Labor Party policy can be implemented at one time. It cannot be and it never was intended to be. What we do is set the general broad framework of policy in a whole number of areas and leave the priorities up to the Government to determine. At the moment, if I were asked where I regard this issue in terms of priorities, I would say very low. I will return to that point in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the thing that creates the most misgivings over the Australian flag is whether we should continue to have the Union Jack. This issue is distinctly different from the National Anthem. Until 10 or 15 years ago our national anthem was God Save the Queen, which I think even some of the conservatives in politics found a little anomalous. What anthem was played when Betty Cuthbert won a gold medal in the 400 metres at Tokyo in 1964? It was God Save the Queen. A lot of the audience wondered, `for heaven's sake, what is going on?'. While I am in the Olympic vein, I am fairly certain that history records in different ways the events surrounding the win by our first gold medallist, Edwin Flack, who won the 800 and 1,500 metres in 1896 in Athens. There was a lot of confusion once he had won. I am not sure whether people ran around looking for an Australian national anthem or an Australian flag. I tend to think that it was a flag. What did they run up the pole? Because of the confusion, they ran up the Austrian flag.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Dawn Fraser?

—Senator McGauran says, `What about Dawn Fraser?'. Just for his information, Dawn Fraser won four Olympic gold medals-the 100 metres freestyle in Melbourne, the 100 metres freestyle in Rome in 1960, the 100 metres freestyle in Tokyo in 1964 and she was part of the successful 4 x 100 metres freestyle female swimming relay team in 1956 in Melbourne. See if you can count this far, Senator McGauran: how many times did they play God Save the Queen? Can you work that out? When you have done so, let me know and I will mark your answer.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a distinction between the question of the national anthem-our replacing something of purely British origin with an Australian anthem-and this question about the flag. Our flag contains the Union Jack but it also has other distinctive Australian features. I do not dislike the Australian flag; what I dislike is the fact that some people overseas do not understand that it is an Australian flag. That annoys me. Of course, its similarity to the New Zealand flag causes more confusion, but we will not go into that today. The only point at which I object to the Union Jack being on the Australian flag is that it can be misinterpreted that we are still a colony or it can be thought of as a British naval flag or something like that. That is where I have some major objections.

Let us look at the crucial high ground from which we can oppose this matter, rather than just saying that it is an obsession of conservatives and therefore a trivial matter. Does this matter have to go the referendum route? Before he sat down, Senator Crichton-Browne said some interesting words. They will come back to haunt him. He said, `Let the people decide'. Therefore, I take it from him that if later this year we bring in legislation to enable referendums to occur on various matters-for example, one vote one value or on four-year parliamentary terms-Senator Crichton Browne will jump to his feet and say, `Let the people decide. I will not debate the merits of this one way or the other; let the people decide'. That is exactly what the Australian Democrats say every time. They will be delighted to hear Senator Crichton-Browne's endorsement today of that proposition. I bet that Senator Crichton-Browne will recant; he will stand up and oppose this or that referendum. He will say, `We will not let this through' and run a filibuster. He will have to eat the words that he said here today-`Let the people decide'.

In my view this motion today is important because it should indicate to the Australian people the priorities of the Opposition. There are a lot of important current issues out there in the electorate which affect people. There is a whole squad of macro-economic issues relating to the way in which this country should be heading. We have the micro-economic agenda to discuss. Why is Senator Lewis not in here discussing industry policy? That is far more important than this issue. Why is Senator Chaney not in here discussing industrial relations and other critical issues on which we can have an interchange of views? Where is Senator Stone? Why is he not here discussing trade policy or Budget deficits or going on with his normal obsessions? Why do not other front bench spokesmen raise important subjects? Why are we left with this non-issue? Is this an indication of the priorities of the Liberal Party of Australia that its members can think of nothing better to do than throw a dead cat in the ring and raise the question of the future of the Australian flag? I wonder.

I realise and I concede that this is private members' business and that it does not always have to be dominated by the shadow Ministry. Nevertheless I wonder where the priorities of the Liberal Party lie. Can Liberal senators not raise those issues because they do not yet have one policy on the record in the run-up to the next election? Will they repeat the mistakes of the past when they belted together policy at the last minute and made monumental mathematical errors in their sums? We had a position in the last election where the Liberals' communications policy was never released. It was supposed to be released at the beginning of July 1987 but we are still waiting for it. Mr Beale never put it out. We are still waiting for Mr Shack to put out the costing of the 1987 Liberal education policies. He put out the education policies two or three weeks before the election and then told us that the costings would follow in four or five days. Now we are 10 months down the track and we still have no costings and no detailed policy. On this side of the House we are all very good from time to time, giving the Opposition a bit of gratuitous advice. Here is some more: It may be more profitable to go to the more central issues than to be continually diverted to the peripheral ones. It may be better not to let the conservative rednecks of the Liberal Party raise these extraneous issues and go back to the issues that concern middle Australia. Middle Australia will determine whether the Liberals move from that side of the House to this side.

TALK.START.PARA: —So central that you put it on your advertising.

—Of course we do. It is unfortunate that Senator Bishop walked into this House and made a very pathetic contribution. She then left and did not listen to the rest of the debate. She should read Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution because it was logically consistent. It argued a case and it defined Senator Bishop's conservatism in a far more articulate way than she ever could.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude of the Australian Labor Party is that we do not believe that this issue is really about the future of the Australian flag. It is about a methodology if that flag were ever to be changed. Therefore, the crucial issue for the Labor Party is whether this matter should inevitably go to a referendum. It may well do so, but should it inevitably be dictated by legislation that it must go by referendum? The answer is no. Therefore, we will oppose the Bill in the Senate. Recognising that we will probably be defeated, we will not divide on the matter. I can give no guarantees one way or the other as to the future of that legislation. If it is passed here I cannot guarantee that it will go to the House of Representatives for consideration. I cannot guarantee that and nor should I have to because no other government has every guaranteed the passage of a private member's Bill in the other place. I am sometimes amazed when I listen to either the amnesia of older honourable senators or the failure of the new ones to read history. It is as though the periods from 1975 to 1983 or 1949 to 1972 had never existed. When honourable senators opposite come in here and say `We must consider this in the House of Representatives' what they are really saying is that previous Liberal governments were total failures or not ethical or moral because they constantly failed to progress private members' legislation in that House.

In conclusion, I am very interested in this proposition coming from those opposite that the people must decide. That is not a view that I take strong exception to. But I bet any money that when other referendum proposals come in here the Liberals will get up and oppose them. They will no longer be saying, `Let the people decide'. They will argue on the merits of this or that, whichever fits into their ultra-conservative, reactionary philosophy. When they come in here and lecture us about letting the people decide it is nothing more than absolute crass hypocrisy. The issue we are debating today-the future of the Australian flag-is basically a dead issue in the life of this Government. As Minister for Home Affairs, I do not intend at this stage, without an instruction from Cabinet, to take this matter any further. There are more important issues for Australians and their political representatives to concentrate on. This debate has achieved only one thing: those who may in their heart of hearts believe in the abolition of the Senate have once again been given a lot of firm evidence as to why they may want to entertain such hopes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Robert Ray's comments.
—You are now able to speak on the misrepresentation of your speech, but you must confine your comments to remarks made in Senator Ray's speech.

—Senator Ray did reasonably accurately reflect what I said about letting the people decide, but he put it in the context that I was arguing that all matters should ultimately rest with the people as the judges. Clearly that is not what I said. Clearly it was not what I intended. What I said in specific terms was that if there is to be a change to Australia's flag it ought ultimately to be put to the people for their decision by way of referendum using the present provisions in the Constitution. I was putting it in the context that this is an issue quite capable of standing outside party politics and it is an issue on which the people of Australia are competent, of course, to make a decision. The judgment ought not to be, in some insidious way, made by this Government by way of legislation or by way of proclamation by the Governor-General at the invitation of the Government.
—I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Ray.
—Senator Bishop, you may now speak in relation to the matters in your speech on which you were misrepresented.

—My concern is the mention that was made of the national anthem and Senator Robert Ray's imputation and statement that somehow I would have supported the changing of our national anthem to some foreign sounding title, the meaning and understanding of which escapes me. By those offensive remarks he is somehow daring to question my loyalty to this nation and my value of Advance Australia Fair as our national anthem, which I sing with great pride. Indeed, I know the words, which probably puts me in a category outside some in the Australian Labor Party. I also have a very good understanding and regard for God Save the Queen when it is used on regal occasions. I find the statement questioning my loyalty to this nation and my appreciation of my own national anthem highly offensive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Flags Amendment Bill which Senator Short has introduced in the Senate. I would like to refer to some of the remarks Senator Robert Ray made in his speech when he suggested that he could not understand why we wanted to discuss something so important as the Flag Act and why we wanted to continue to keep our flag as Australia's national flag.
—You had better hurry because the Minister is leaving.

—Yes, I am sorry about that. He asked why does not Senator Lewis come in here and discuss industrial policies, why does not Senator Stone come in here and discuss trade policies, why does not Senator Chaney come in and talk about financial policies. Well, my remarks to the Minister are that yesterday we debated a very important matter of public importance that was raised and spoken to by Senator Chaney and spoken to by Senator Stone and Senator Lewis. Where was Senator Robert Ray? Nowhere to be seen. In addition to two backbenchers, the only Minister to speak on such an important matter was Senator Bolkus. If the Minister had wanted to hear what our thoughts were on these very important matters, he would have been able to listen to the effects of Labor's financial policies being discussed in a very important matter of public importance. Senators were talking about how the Australian Labor Party had shortchanged the people of Australia and the impact that had made on their living standards. I believe the time to discuss these matters are when debates take place on matters of public importance-an important time in the Senate-and when the Senate is broadcast so that the Australian people can hear just how the Labor Party has been treating the people of Australia. People are noticing a sad effect on their pockets from the policies of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I was trying to explain why we think it is very important during private members general business to be able to discuss things like the flag. I consider it is a very important subject for all the people of Australia. Many people write in and tell us about it and many organisations within Australia want to continue to keep our present flag; they do not want it changed. I certainly do not believe there should be any thought or talk about change unless it is put to a referendum and the Australian people are able to say what they want to do and how they want to keep the Australian flag.

In October 1984, Senator Grimes, then Minister for Social Security, stated that the Government intended to allow a referendum to be held before any thought was given to changing the flag. I hope the present Government is of the same opinion, although I was interested to hear Senator Robert Ray say in his speech-and it shows I did listen to what he was saying-that it was not a key issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —A trivial matter.

—Yes, a trivial matter, and it was not likely to be addressed. He said it was very low in the Government's priorities. Well, it is very high in the Opposition's priorities and that is why we raised the matter for discussion this afternoon. In excellent speeches, Senator Bishop and Senator Crichton-Browne put the facts very clearly and succinctly so that people will know why we are very interested in retaining our present flag, and why we want to make sure the Government holds a referendum if there is any thought of changing it. I am certainly pleased to hear Senator Robert Ray say that there was no talk about it and he does not think the matter will be brought up by the Government. At any rate, I say shame on those honourable senators because he went on to say that the Labor Party is not going to vote for our Bill that Senator Short introduced. I say shame on the Labor Party for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The formation of our national flag was a conscious act by the Australian people when Australia became a recognised nation at Federation in 1901. Until then Australia flew the Union Jack. Senator Bishop told us about the early days of the flag and how there was a growing feeling that Australia should have a new flag, one that would reflect its own identity. There was a national competition to devise a distinctive Australian flag. More than 30,000 entries were received. Indeed, many of those featured Australian flora and fauna, sheaves of wheat, kangaroos, boomerangs, and kookaburras, together with the stars and stripes in various colours and combinations. However, the judges decided on the design for our national flag as we know it, with the addition in 1908 of an extra point to the Federation star to take account of the Australian Territories-at that time New Guinea. Of course, now it represents the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory.

The predominant colour on the flag is blue. I feel that no colour could be more appropriate for a country such as Australia which is world renowned for its clear blue skies. Around Canberra at the present time I am beginning to believe that the people wish the skies were not quite so blue-and the same applies to a vast area in Queensland-because they badly need some grey skies and some rain. The colour also represents the blue seas which surround us. Of course, I am proud that the Union Jack is still represented on the corner of the flag; that provides our link with Great Britain. We should remember that it was Lieutenant James Cook of the British Royal Navy who, after a long and adventurous voyage, discovered, charted and claimed the east coast of Australia for the British Crown. Indeed, when Captain Phillip arrived at Botany Bay after his epic voyage he did not find here a system of common law, representative government under the Crown or the English language.

Phillip's small contingent, including the convicts, transported over thousands of miles a culture which took root in the new land. That culture, of course, now goes back 200 years. But our nation's original roots go back to Britain, and that is why I like to see the Union Jack on our flag, and indeed the present flag maintained. The symbolism of the Union Jack is Christian in origin. It is a combination of the three Christian crosses-St George, the patron saint of England, a red cross on a white background; St Andrew, the patron saint of Scotland, a white diagonal cross on a blue background; and the red diagonal cross of St Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland, which was incorporated into the Union Jack in 1801.

Those who adopted the present Australian flag-itself the result of an enormous nationwide competition-had the foresight to pay tribute to each of the three nations which contributed to our foundation-England, Scotland and Ireland. Each of these ethnic streams, by the crosses of the patron saints already mentioned, has recognition given to it by the present flag. I believe it is important that the majority of Australians, who, I am sure, wish to maintain our links with Britain, voice their concern over the rumblings which have occurred from time to time in regard to proposed changes to the flag. The history of a nation is just as important as its geographical situation. To deny future generations of Australians some visible awareness of that history is to deny our future Australians their heritage. However, the Federal Labor Government's policy on the flag which was stated in the 1982 Australian Labor Party platform is to initiate and support moves to establish with popular acceptance an Australian flag which would be more distinctively reflective of Australia's independence and identity.

Some people argue that our present flag in some ways still reflects our colonised status and now that we have become an independent nation we should have a new flag to reflect our national identity. Others even suggest that migrants to this country cannot be expected to live and work under our flag. However, I believe that migrants generally see our Australian flag as symbolising the characteristics of Australia which attracted them to adopt this country as their own in the first place. I understand that members of the Ethnic Communities Council joined the Australian Flag Preservation Committee which was formed in Queensland some years ago as a demonstration of their commitment. A Gallup poll taken in May 1984 showed that 61 per cent of Australians preferred to keep the existing flag rather than have it changed. In fact, in an Australia-wide public opinion poll in the Bulletin of July 1984, 2,107 men and women were asked whether the Union Jack should continue to be in our flag. Sixty-eight per cent of those polled said the Union Jack should be retained in the flag, which I take as meaning that they believe the flag should remain as it is at present. In the Courier-Mail of 5 April 1984 the senior vice-president of the Returned Services League in Queensland in a letter to the editor stated:
The RSL has never claimed proprietal rights over the politics of patriotism, but that impression may have been conveyed because of its continual concern for the integrity of Australia.

Nor has it claimed the right to speak for all Australians, but by virtue of its 275,000 members' service in the defence forces of Australia during war and in peacetime, to speak in the interests of the nation as a whole.
The RSL policy on the Australian national flag is that the present one be retained without alteration.

I was very proud to see our flag hoisted at the Commonwealth Games held in Brisbane. It was an exciting time each time it was hoisted. Also, when the Australian flag is hoisted at the Olympics it gives Australians a thrill. As a senator I am always happy to arrange for the Australian flag to be obtained for schools and various approved organisations. On many occasions I am asked to present these flags which I do with a great deal of pride. I am sure that many other senators feel exactly the same way. At the school I explain about the Union Jack and its association with Australia's history and I talk about the Southern Cross on the flag-for Australia is aptly named `the land of the Southern Cross'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I once lived at Southern Cross.

—I am interested to hear that from the honourable senator. I understand that Senator Panizza lives at Southern Cross now. I also talk about the star of Federation, which stands for all States and Territories. I strongly believe that any changes to the Australian national flag should be made only if approved by a majority of people in a referendum. Our flag is a proud symbol of our history, our independence as a nation and our parliamentary and judicial institutions. I reiterate that the majority of Australians believe that the flag should be retained in its present form. Accordingly, I strongly support Senator Short's Bill and commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Robert Ray said so accurately, this is a very tedious debate. I was reading Senator Short's second reading speech this afternoon and went back over some of the previous debates in the Senate. I found to my great interest that it was an exact copy of the speech Senator Durack delivered in this place in 1984.
—No, it is not.

—It is. In fact, it uses precisely the same quotations as were used by Senator Durack. I do not say that necessarily is a bad thing in itself. I suppose that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery. I imagine Senator Durack's original speech said what Senator Short said in his speech, but his speech was a repeat of Senator Durack's remarks. Certainly Senator Short repeated the same kind of jingoism that was contained in Senator Durack's speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Like a lot of Australians I have no `die at the barricades' feelings about the Australian flag. There is one thing that irritates me about the present Australian flag, as much as I like it. I have the same emotional and totally Australian feelings towards the flag as most people in this country, but what irritates me about it is its lack of identification overseas and the confusion that constantly surrounds the flying of our flag. People confuse it with the flag of Great Britain and the flags of other countries. I am one of many people who believe that we should do a deal. Either we should change our flag, or the Poms should change theirs and stop using the corner out of ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the English flag.

—I am easy. But one of the things that irritate me about the debate about the Australian flag is the nonsense that is delivered in the form of patriotic fervour. There are two senators in this place who can, with some authority, talk about the advantages of having a truly Australian design. One is choosing not to do that, and I refer to Senator Tambling, but this particular senator from the Northern Territory is choosing to do so. As I said in my first speech in this place, the Northern Territory is the only political entity in Australia which has a flag that does not have the Union Jack on it. I must say that the Northern Territory flag is universally admired. It is a striking flag in the Territory colours of black, white and ochre, featuring Sturt's desert rose and the Southern Cross.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the record of paranoia that has been whipped up in the debate. I have with me a Press release issued by former Senator Bernie Kilgariff of the Northern Territory-a man whom I held and still hold in great respect. When dealing with the national flag, he said that it was essential for the flag not to be changed and that we should hang on to it. Of course, former Senator Kilgariff represented the Northern Territory of Australia in this Senate. The Northern Territory changed its flag and removed the Union Jack, with the full support of Senator Kilgariff and his colleagues in the Country-Liberal Party, without a referendum. Paul Everingham's Government-this is very much in the style of the kind of government Paul Everingham ran-did not even run a competition. It simply went out and selected a competent designer, Mr Ingpen. He designed the flag and the Northern Territory Government passed an Act of Parliament that put it into effect. Everyone in the Northern Territory said, `What a nice flag'. We have been saying ever since, and a great chorus of other people have also been saying, `What a nice flag'.

I would like to turn the debate away a little from the preoccupation of removing the Union Jack. As Senator Ray again said, there is a total preoccupation, when we are talking about a new flag for Australia, with whether the Union Jack should be on it. I think there is value in simply discussion the need for a new Australian flag, no matter what it looks like. But I will freely concede that it is a very subjective subject. Everyone has a different view on it. For example, I remember an editorial in the Australian newspaper that tore apart the proposal that the colours of the flag should be green and gold. I do not want to see a green and gold flag but I can remember this thundering editorial in the Australian denouncing this garish-I think that was the word that was used-combination of colours that do not reflect Australia. In the part of Australia that I come from I can understand why those colours are totally appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —National Party colours.

—The fact that they are the National Party colours does not even turn me off them, as it should. The colours are in fact strikingly Australian. If honourable senators climbed into a motor car in Alice Springs right now and drove out to a place like Yuendumu, they would drive through 400 miles of Australia that is green and gold. If one drives anywhere in the central desert areas of Australia after rain has fallen on the desert one can easily understand why those colours are so typically Australian because one just sees hundreds of miles of green and gold. It is a striking sight indeed with the acacias all out in bloom and the foliage that surrounds them-the green and gold of Australia. But the Australian newspaper, one of our major nationals, described that as being an appalling mix of colours and not at all Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: I said in my first speech in this place that I want to see the Australian flag changed; I make no bones about it. The design that I favour, for all kinds of reasons, is the one which the Ausflag competition discovered was one of the most popular suggestions. I believe that, when the Australian flag is changed, as it will be changed, the design that I favour will probably be the chosen design, or one very close to it-that is, our current flag with the Union Jack taken from the top left-hand corner and the Federation star simply moved up to a central position on the flag and perhaps slightly enlarged. Of course, the seven points on that Federation star can stay, even when the Northern Territory becomes a State, and it will then simply represent the seven states of Australia. The simplicity and the beauty of that design are what appeal to me. It is a minimal change to the flag and it would be a striking and very easily identifiable symbol for Australia.

I turn now to some of the remarks made by Senator Short. I take exception to the extent of the jingoism and the over the top sentiment contained in much of what he said. Senator Short said, `The presence of the Union Jack on our flag is the guarantee of our freedoms in Australia'. With great respect to Senator Short, I think that is somewhat of an overstatement. The institutions which preserve and protect the freedoms of this country are, in the main, this Parliament and the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And where did our basic institutions come from, Senator?

—I would like to respond to that interjection because there again is a gross distortion of historical fact and, I would have thought, a basic ignorance of the history of the founding of this Parliament and the discussions that went on at the many constitutional conventions that were held towards the end of last century, culminating in the Australian Constitution. In responding further to the interjection, I turn now to another of Senator Short's statement where he said, `The flag symbolises the political institutions in this country'. If we had a flag that symbolised the history of the establishment of the political institutions in this country we would be flying the stars and stripes, not the Union Jack on our flag. I ask Senator Wood, the Nuclear Disarmament Party senator present in the chamber, to restrain himself from saying that is what we might as well do now and make it obvious.
—I wouldn't say that.

—He did not say that. The reality is that our system of parliament is far more deliberately modelled on the United States system of parliament than it is on the British system. It is a common misbelief in Australia-I do not think this is shared by anybody in this chamber who is a legal practitioner-that we are modelled on the Westminster system. Our system is so dramatically different from the British system that it is ridiculous to make that statement. It is deliberately modelled on the British system, for one obvious reason.
—It is dramatically different from the American one too. Where are the Ministers in America?
—It is drawn on both the British and the American systems.
—In response to the idiotic interjections opposite, it is a meld. We have a hybrid system. Let me remind honourable senators opposite of what I said.
—That is better. Now you are getting honest at last.
—I will just repeat that I said-and the Hansard record will demonstrate it-that it is `more closely modelled on the American system of government than it is on the British system of government'.
—But it is not.

—It is, Senator. The reality is that, if it had not been deliberately modelled on and drawn from the American system of government a federation of Australia would never have been established. The fundamental creation of this Senate chamber, which was modelled precisely on the American model, solved all of the sticking points in those constitutional conventions in terms of the balance of power between the proposed Commonwealth of Australia and the States. It was no good looking to the British system because the state system there simply does not operate in the same way.
—I like the word `precise'. There are no Ministers in the American system.

—Once again, in response to that interjection, we have a hybrid system of government in Australia. I repeat that it is more closely modelled, in precise terms, on the American system of government than the British system of government. So there is a bit of a hole in that argument. To get to a very fundamental point-I do not think anyone has forgotten 1975-one could surely not forget or ignore that this chamber possesses awesomely greater powers than the House of Lords in the British system.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to point out another fundamental difference between our system of government and the British system of government, we have a constitution. The British system of government does not have a constitution. I would describe that as a fundamental difference between the two systems. But which system does have a constitution, the American system has a constitution. Why does it have a constitution? It has a constitution because, when the States federated, they wanted a legal contract drawn up between the proposed federal government and the existing State governments, where the limit of the powers of those two systems were clearly laid out and would be arbitrated upon by a superior court which, in the American case, is known as the Supreme Court of the United States and, in our case, as the High Court of Australia.

That was not an accident. It was modelled precisely on the American system of government. It provides the overriding reason why there is no British constitution, why there are no checks and balances in terms of a court-and there is a strong argument as to why there should be-as there are in this country. The British House of Commons could pass a law saying that black was white, or that the sun was not to come up in the morning, and there is no forum in Britain that can rule that such legislation is out of order. There is no system in Great Britain greater than the Parliament. There is in Australia. It is called the High Court, and it is modelled on the Supreme Court of the United States of America.

So, I rest my case. I would suggest that the House of Representatives and the Senate-modelled very largely on the House of Representatives and the Senate of the American Congress, operating under an overriding constitution, determined by a superior court; a fairly comprehensive model under which we operate-are very different from the British system. So I take some difference with Senator Short about all of our parliamentary system and constitutional history being embodied in the Union Jack. It plainly is not so.

Senator Short went on to talk about equality before the law, the right to a fair trial, the presumption of innocence until proven guilty, all being enshrined in some magical fashion in the Union Jack. Like many members of my Party and many other members of this Parliament, I am of Irish descent. I am an Irish Catholic Laborite. I am part of the great Irish family of the Australian Labor Party. There are lots of us about. As a result of that, I suppose, I am very conscious of the activities over the years of the British Government, the Government that Senator Short wants us to epitomise as everything that is fair, decent, honest and just. In the jingoistic fervour to cling to that kind of ideal, it irritates me that honourable senators can blind themselves to history.

British history indeed embodies many things that are fundamentally honest and supportable, just and decent. But it also embodies dreadful injustice, unfairness, denial of rights, outright brutality and outright bestiality in some cases. It was after all-it is a matter of history-the British and not the Germans who invented concentration camps. If honourable senators doubt that, I would refer them to some excellent publications which are available in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bookshop, which will show them in graphic picture form how true that was when thousands of South African women, children and old people died miserable deaths locked up behind wire and denied food and even the most basic medical resources. That caused an absolute scandal in Great Britain at the time. That was British justice in South Africa. None of us has to be reminded of the Black and Tans and the way in which they operated in Ireland in the past, or in India, or in all of the other British colonial outposts around the world.

The history of the British Empire is marked with some great institutions which are supportable; but it is not reasonable or fair to say that everything that is fair, honest, noble and patriotic in the world is enshrined under the Union Jack, because the Union Jack has flown over some despicable acts in the history of the world as well as the fair, honest and decent ones.

The honourable senator went on to point out, as many others have done in this debate, that the Australian flag with the Union Jack has flown over battlefields and that people have fought under it, have shed blood under it, and have won races in the Olympic Games under it. Of course, that is true. Indeed, two Australian flags fly over the roof of this building, so I imagine that all sorts of things have happened under the Australian flag over the years, not just here but everywhere else in the country. The Australian flag does not depend for its standing, its status as a symbol of everything we hold to be decent and honest in this country, on the Union Jack in the top left-hand corner.

I mentioned earlier my admiration for the Canadian flag. Most honourable senators will agree, I think, that it is a striking flag. I do not really see the relevance of the information that was given to us this afternoon that it took 40 years of fighting and arguing in Canada before that flag was accepted-the premise apparently being that we must argue and fight for 40 years over the same thing. It is about time that we tried just a little to cut loose from the apron strings that tie us to Great Britain.

We in this country are very reluctant to do that. We are a group of very conservative, very careful people. We do not like change. Change always causes division, whether it is about the Australian flag or anything else. Let us face it: We became the Federation of Australia in 1901, but we did not become Australian citizens until 1949-almost half a century afterwards when the Australian Citizenship Act was passed in 1949 in this Parliament. For almost 50 years after Federation, Australian citizens carried British passports with `Australian Citizen' stamped on them. We did not have our own citizenship Act for 50 years after Federation. We have had Australian citizenship for only a bare 40 years. Of course, Australian Aboriginals have had it for even less. The year 1988 is the bicentennial of European occupation of this country. It also happens to be the twenty-first anniversary of the granting of citizenship to Australia's indigenous people, the Aboriginals, in May 1967. They are 21 years old this year as Australian citizens. Indeed we have a short constitutional and political history; I certainly concede that.

I do not want to take up the Senate's time much longer on this matter. I simply say that I am not a died in the wool, at the barricades republican in my views on Australian government. I believe that the system of constitutional monarchy which Australia has adopted, overriding a parliamentary and high court system modelled on that of the United States-in other words, a hybrid model of government-with the same system, as we know it in this country, of responsible government, with Ministers and Cabinet and the Executive sitting in the Parliament, as with the British system, is a very good combination that works well in this country, and it should be retained. I am not going to go to the wall, either, on changing the Australian flag. The Government has indicated that it is not on its agenda to do so, as Senator Robert Ray has said, so I do not know what all the fuss is about here this afternoon.
I simply conclude by saying that there is no doubt that one day the Australian flag will change. In my view, it might as well be now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Collins misrepresented me on at least three occasions, and I should like to put the record straight. First, he said that my speech was identical to Senator Durack's speech in this place in 1984. I fully accept that Senator Durack's speech in 1984 was an excellent speech; so, I believe, was mine in November 1987. If Senator Collins compares the two, I think he will find that, whilst there are certain common parts, there are also significant differences, and that the two speeches are by no means identical.

SPEECH.PARA: The second misrepresentation was that Senator Collins misquoted from my second reading speech. If I got him right, he said that I had said then that the presence of the Union Jack on the Australian flag guarantees our freedoms. What I said was:

It is precisely the presence of the Union Jack, however, which symbolises the origins of our institutions that guarantee our freedoms which have been, and still are, the source of much of Australia's greatness.

There is a significant difference between the two. Thirdly, Senator Collins said, or certainly implied, that in talking about the institutions I was speaking only of the political institutions. They are the only institutions he referred to. He categorised our political institutions as being American rather than British. He is wrong on that. It is accepted that our institutions are hybrids. The misrepresentation to which I draw attention is that when talking about institutions I said, as I think most Australians who follow subjects such as these would realise, that the basic institutions of this country certainly include our political institutions, but, equally importantly, the fundamental legal and judicial institutions on which we have drawn so much from our British origins. It is misleading in the extreme to narrow my comments, in the manner in which Senator Collins did, and suggest that I was just referring only to the political institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said this afternoon, the Flags Amendment Bill was introduced in the previous Parliament but became stuck in the House of Representatives because the Government chose to do nothing about it there. The debate today has been particularly interesting, given that the Government has been able to dredge up only two of its so-called right wing heavyweights. Their argument has been that they of course were in favour of changing the flag. If people throughout Australia are concerned that there should not be a change to the flag, they should really read the speeches of those two so-called right wing heavyweights.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great concern that Senator Collins purely and simply dismissed our concern for the flag and the future of the flag by calling it jingoistic fervour. This Bill aims to do something very basic to the principles of democracy. I suppose that Senator Collins is not all that concerned or hung up about democracy. As a nation we must be conscious of two things: democracy and the nationhood of Australia.

The Bill's aim is to ensure that the national flag of Australia cannot be changed except with the direct agreement of the people of Australia voting in a referendum. Therefore that is the most fundamental element and the whole issue behind this Bill. Yet the Government will not agree to any consideration of the Australian people having the option to decide by referendum. Whether or not we are part of a majority that supports the retention of the present national flag, surely there can be no argument that the future of our most basic of national symbols must be decided by the people and not by the Parliament acting alone, or, even worse still, by administrative action by a government, and particularly one such as we have today.

I regard as essential that the Australian people should be asked unambiguously whether they want to change the current flag before they are asked to choose between any other alternatives. Nobody who believes in democracy could allow the possibility of the people of Australia being presented with a fait accompli by a government that itself has decided on a change.

A number of Australians remain unhappy with the manner in which our national anthem was changed. Honourable senators will recall that in 1977 a referendum was held for a preferred national song, and Advance Australia Fair was chosen. However, the specific question as to whether God Save the Queen should be abandoned altogether was not asked. However, to an unhealthy degree the full change has been effected by the actions of this Government since 1983. That question was specifically not in the 1977 referendum. I raise this matter not to seek to return to the previous anthem, but to note the principle that change ought not to be effected without a full, unambiguous, popular decision as to whether a current symbol should be discarded or changed. It goes without saying that the national flag is a far more potent and basic national symbol than a national anthem.

For years the Opposition has consistently supported that principle. As I said, this Bill is identical to that introduced to the Senate by Senator Durack in 1984. It does no credit whatsoever to the Hawke Government that that Bill was never debated in the House of Representatives, and that the Government's stalling caused the Bill to disappear after last year's double dissolution. Australians can only draw the conclusion that this Government is either so partisan that it will not support any constructive legislative initiative from the Opposition, that it does not care about the democratic protection of our national symbol, or that is secretly wishes to implement a new flag against the wishes of a majority of Australians if necessary. If indeed the latter motives are real, the Australian Labor Party is being profoundly hypocritical when, like the Liberal Party, it uses the national flag on its logo.

I think that we are entitled to be concerned when a senior Minister of this Government, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), is on record as stating his desire for a new flag. Of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will state whatever he considers is popular for the day, having put his finger in his mouth and held it up to the wind. Though we all know that Australians do not want to change the flag, that is not enough for the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister wants to keep faith with Australians he must ensure by law that Australians will not have their flag taken from them by any means other than a referendum.

A nation that alters its most basic of national symbols is one that has an identity crisis. Our flag has undergone only very minor change over 85 years. It is a flag that Australians have no trouble recognising and, let us face it, Australians are the only people who matter in this debate. It does not matter who else recognises our flag. It matters that Australians recognise our flag.

Though a few self-appointed elitists do consider that Australia must change its identity, and with it its symbols of nationhood, ordinary Australians simply love their country the way it is and have a profound need for the continuity of its symbols. Senator Collins referred on a number of occasions during his speech to the Canadian flag. Australia is not an historically and culturally divided nation like Canada is. The example of the Canadian flag, of course, is so often held up as an example of why our flag should be changed. I believe there is no correlation between the two.

Those who seek change, whether only as part of lobby groups or perhaps in secret, focus on the presence of the Union Jack as an integral part of our national flag. A feeble argument is often paraded that because not all Australians are of British stock, and because we are an independent nation, that this retention of our current flag is inappropriate. The Union Jack is of course an amalgamation of the crosses of England, Scotland and Ireland. According to Dr Charles Price of Canberra in 1986, these nations in 1978 supplied the racial origin of 77 per cent of Australians. He predicted that by 2008 72 per cent of Australians would still be of this Anglo-Celtic origin. The racial origins of Australians however are a peripheral factor in this whole question. What really matters is what the flag stands for. The Union Jack is a reminder not of ethnic origins but of the English, Irish and Scottish institutions that have shaped Australia over the past 200 years. If we asked where we would be without such British institutions as representative government and the rule of law, or what we would be like without our Irish rebels and pioneers, the answer would be that our whole identity would be profoundly different.

Any Australian who values a liberal democracy under the rule of law must be grateful to those institutions handed down from Britain. Indeed, many thousands of Australians who came here from undemocratic nations appreciate this heritage more deeply than any of us. It is in fact a mark of our maturity as a nation that we can include in our national flag the flag of another nation with whom our historical relationship is so profound, without in any way denigrating our own independence. On the other hand, an obsession with parading our independence through alteration of a national symbol shows a lack of proper confidence. At a time when, necessarily, Australia is undergoing economic and social change it is all the more important that we are able to look to a symbol of continuity in our nationhood. Australians know enough of their history to appreciate deeply that our national flag was a symbol in 1914 and again in 1939 when, as a nation, we were tested in fire. By necessity, changing the flag involves a degree of repudiation of the past, a past that the great majority of Australians see as something of which to be proud.

In a democracy there can be no objection to people agitating for change to a national symbol. We are not saying that people who believe they want a change should not say that. All we are saying is that it is essential that the only means that should be used is the persuasion of a firm majority of Australians that the flag should be changed. We are not trying to silence anybody, but let us put it to the vote. This Bill will ensure that any arguments for change must be directed to the whole community, not to a government that might alter our flag and its usage in an undemocratic manner.

The Australian flag as it stands today is the property of the Australian people. They alone must decide whether we need a new flag. This Bill will ensure that. That is why I am absolutely flabbergasted that this Government will not agree to the Bill. It is not good enough that the current Flags Act allows the Government to advise the Governor-General to `appoint such other flags and ensigns of Australia as he sees fit'. In effect, this allows a government to denigrate the existing flag by parading alternatives, not even sanctioned by the Parliament let alone the people. It is no accident that this Bill will ensure not only that the people have the final say by way of referendum but also that any such additional flags will be the subject of regulation and, thus, review by the Parliament. The Bill will prevent the appointment of any alternative flag as representative of the Commonwealth of Australia or of its government. We have a duty to ensure that the flag cannot be altered by backdoor administrative measures. Even honourable senators who may want a new flag have a moral obligation to support a Bill that gives control of the destiny of our leading national symbol to the people of Australia. I repeat: why will this Government-and Heaven knows where the Australian Democrats stand on this issue because we never know where they stand on any issue until the eleventh hour-not allow the people of Australia to decide this important issue? I wish to finish just by reading from an anonymous poem sent to me. I believe that the poem which is entitled `Keep the flag' encapsulates a lot of the thought and belief of Australians about our most important national symbol. The poem is as follows:
Our flag bears the stars that blaze at night
In our southern sky of blue,
And a little old flag in the corner
That's part of our heritage, too.
It's for the English, the Scots and the Irish
Who were sent to the ends of the earth,
The rogues and schemers, the doers and dreamers,
Who gave modern Australia birth.
And you, who are shouting to change it,
You don't seem to understand,
It's the flag of our law and our language,
Not the flag of a faraway land.
(Though there are plenty of people who'll tell you,
How when Europe was plunged into night
That little old flag in the corner
Was their symbol of freedom and light.)
It doesn't mean we owe allegiance
To a forgotten imperial dream.
We've the stars to show where we're going
And the old flag to show where we've been.

I believe that this Bill is particularly important to the people of Australia. Certainly, it is something that I would hope to see passed through the Senate. I hope that the Government will take it seriously enough this time to allow it to be debated and voted on in the House of Representatives so we can, once and for all, see where this Government stands in regard to this important part of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a promise to the Senate-probably I should not do that-to try never to use the word `hypocrisy' in this chamber. It seems that every time we have a debate the screams of `hypocrisy' fly in both directions. The term seems to have little relevance because hypocrisy seems to be par for the course. I promise to try not to accuse anyone of hypocrisy ever again.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Knowles said that the flag is a more potent symbol than the national anthem. It does not surprise me that some people think that this is so. As individuals people are bowed silent before the flag, whereas a national anthem is something that people sing together and participate in. I prefer symbols which are active, in which people participate, which bring people together, rather than symbols which cause people to be silent.

I spoke at a college in Bathurst recently. I was asked about Australian republicanism and whether Australia should have a republican Constitution. My answer to that question is the same as to the question of whether we should change the flag. I do not think that it is a republican Constitution or a different flag that we need, we need a republican consciousness in this country. This nation has never declared its independence. There has never been a declaration of Australian independence-not even in 1901 when a second-rate aristocrat in the rain in a park declared himself Governor-General. There were no cries of independence for Australia. There were cries only for the British to come to Australian aid. Politicians were at pains to tell people voting on whether we should become a federation that we would still be British, that we would still be part of the British Empire and that we would not be all alone. As John Pilger has said in his book, it is not surprising that the anniversary of Federation is rarely remembered, and even less often celebrated. It never was anything real in terms of the independence of this country.

We have heard all this debate about the Union Jack. However, all the foul oppression of the British jack boot in South Africa, Northern Ireland and elsewhere was made no sweeter by the flying of the Union Jack. Nor does it make the oppression here any sweeter. We talk about heritage and the history of a nation. It is said that the changing of the flag will be a denial of our heritage. We have heard that it is a symbol of our sovereignty and that it reflects our independence and identity. If we want to have a flag which represents our identity and clearly demonstrates our independence perhaps we should move the Union Jack down the flag a little bit and put the Stars and Stripes above it; perhaps there should be a small Japanese flag there somewhere to show how much of our country is owned by overseas interests. There has been talk about sovereignty and denial of heritage. We do not understand what independence means. We do not understand what sovereignty means. We have never been a sovereign and independent nation. We are not now a sovereign and independent nation. That is why we are totally blind to Aboriginal demands for sovereignty and independence. We do now know what they are saying and what they mean because we do not recognise it. Dr Timoci Bavadra was in Parliament House the other day. We saw the trampling of Fijian democracy and did very little as a nation to rescue democracy in Fiji. We did very little then and we are doing very little now, despite the so-called common British heritage of Fiji and Australia. It was Britain which created the Council of Chiefs which is so prominent in politics in Fiji at the moment. That is its British heritage.

The Aboriginal people have been here and have had ownership of this country for more than 40,000 years. Recent discoveries near here, at Lake George, have shown evidence of settlement going back 110,000 years. That is a very long heritage. Someone referred to comparatively recent arrivals, meaning those who were not from England, Ireland or Scotland but apparently more recently. It seems to me that, in the scheme of 110,000 years, one could not get more comparatively recent than 200 years. It seems to me that, when we talk about changing the flag, we should talk about creating a flag which also represents in it 110,000 years of carefully managing this country in a way that we have not been able to do in 200 years. In the 200 years that we have been in this country we have virtually destroyed it. In the debate on the conservation legislation, the loss of forests and soil erosion was catalogued. That has happened in only the last 200 years. It is ironic that in the first week, between the time members of the First Fleet landed at Botany Bay and their decision to sail to Port Jackson, they left behind them felled trees, sawpits and holes in the ground. Within days of European arrival we were digging up the earth and felling trees and we have never stopped doing so. What about that heritage? Do we want to put that in a flag?

If we truly want a flag which reflects the history of this land-surely any Australian has to feel some sort of connection with the country in which he or she lives rather than with the historical culture from which the original invaders came-and if we truly have some allegiance to this country, whose history goes back 110,000 years, we should reflect that in whatever flag we have. I would rather replace the Union Jack with the Aboriginal flag. Its top left corner denotes the place of honour. I would rather have the Aboriginal flag in that corner. It is black, representing the colour of the people, it depicts the sun in the centre, and it is red, representing the colour of the earth and the blood that has been spilt on the earth. I think that that would be a very apt way in which to recognise this country's heritage in a flag. However, I do not want to impose that on the Aboriginal people. It is up to them to decide whether they want their colours in our flag.

We must come to terms with our own identity. People have talked about an identity crisis. There is an identity crisis, but one does not solve it by hiding behind a flag; one solves it by taking a truthful look at our history and heritage and by making a realistic representation of what we are, what we have been and hopefully, more optimistically, what we wish to be in the future. Perhaps we should have little flags symbolising foreign bases on our soil. Perhaps we should have little stars and stripes for each foreign base. Perhaps we should have a little mark representing where some foreign mining company owns huge chunks of our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —A hole in the flag.

—A hole in the flag for Maralinga. Perhaps there should be a hole in the flag for a spot in the country in which we cannot live any longer because it is radioactive. Australians cannot go there because the British blew the blazes out of it and left it uninhabitable. I am not quite sure where one would put the hole. Let us not hide behind a flag. Let not our patriotism be based on waving a piece of colourful cloth. Let us face it: a flag is a piece of cloth. It is a coloured piece of cloth. What meaning it has is what meaning people vest in it. Its meaning does not exist by virtue of what it is; its meaning exists by virtue of what people believe it means to them. On some occasions people may feel like burning the flag and on others they may feel like waving it. Its meaning changes and is not absolute.

SPEECH.PARA: What I call for is not a republican constitution, a republican flag or a new flag. What I call for is some real act of independence, some real declaration of independence, rather than grovelling to what at one time was the British Empire and is now the empire of Uncle Sam. We should become an independent and sovereign nation not only in word but in deed-in what we do. We should start by getting rid of the bases, giving Aboriginal people there sovereignty and learning from Aboriginal people what sovereignty and cultural identity mean in terms of the survival of values through 200 years of oppression.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of views today about various senators' approach to our Constitution, our flag, our national anthem and various other important national symbols. It has been an interesting debate. I am concerned at the approach of a couple of Government senators. Senator Ray is on the record as having said today that this is a trivial matter. He then resorted to abuse of two of my colleagues, Senators Crichton-Browne and Bishop, both of whom, I think, have managed to deal with that criticism quite effectively and do not need any help from me. Senator Collins accused those on this side of the chamber-I might say at some length-of jingoism. There was further talk, as we heard just now from Senator Wood, of being tied to apron-strings. First of all, I find that a bit of a nonsense. Secondly, it is irrelevant to the debate on the flag.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to speak very briefly to ensure that I am on the record as very strongly supporting the Flags Amendment Bill 1987. I totally reject the charges of triviality and jingoism but I am not ashamed that I approach this matter with a fairly conservative air. I think most Australians would wish to see this approach in dealing with our national flag. This is an important piece of legislation.
