The flag may simply be a piece of cloth, and I understand Senator Wood's approach when he refers to it as that. But he also said that the importance of that piece of cloth is what it means to Australians.

To me, the flag represents our history, and I do not intend to go into this in detail. But, clearly, it is particularly important that the flag should show where we came from as a nation. What we have fought for as a nation is also extremely important. To me, the place in our history that our flag occupies is very important. I believe that our flag has a precious place in the hearts of most Australians. But that does not mean to say that in due course, and from time to time, there will not be proposals for change. Senator Wood made some proposals today, most of which I would not be very happy with. But that is part of the democratic process and it is right and proper that it should take place.

I think it is only proper that we ensure that the people of this country are the ones who have the power to decide whether the flag should be changed. I am not so concerned about the detail of how it should be changed, but the power to change something as important as our flag should reside purely in the hands of the people. To me, one of the sad and, I think, incredible things about this debate is that quite clearly this Government is not prepared to put that power into the hands of the people. It is not prepared to trust the people and all of the bluster that we have heard from Government speakers cannot conceal that basic fact. We want the people to have that power but the Government does not, and I condemn it for that.

We have heard a lot lately about whether or not the Government has been listening to and communicating with people at the grass roots level. Whether or not it has, it clearly does not trust the people at the grass roots level. I also condemn the Government for that. I am very proud to support this Bill so that protection of the Australian flag can be placed and remain in the hands of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support Senator Short's Flags Amendment Bill 1987. This Bill is neither for nor against the flag. I think people listening to this debate would be astounded by the line taken by members of the Australian Labor Party that somehow this Bill is a declaration that the present flag should never be changed, that it is immutable. That is not in fact the purpose of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate has been corrupted by members on the other side of the chamber. Senator Wood, the nuclear disarmament senator who has spoken in the debate, has no knowledge of what this Bill is all about. The Bill restores to the people the right to decide whether the flag is just a bit of cloth, in his terms, or whether it is meaningful. Heaven forbid that people like the nuclear disarmament senator should have the power to determine something that is dear to so many people in Australia. I would hope that his attitude to giving the Australian people the right to determine their flag will be reflected in the votes that he gathers in his authoritarian way at the next election.

The purpose of this Bill is simply to prevent changes from occurring to Australia's national flag without the prior consent of the Australian people through a referendum. It preserves the rights not only of the Parliament but also of the people of Australia to have a democratic say in any change. So why should the Government oppose this Bill? Why did it allow it to die in the other place? Is it because it wants once again to sneak through a change that so many Australians are determined that they do not want? As Senator Short pointed out, the Labor Party's own platform clearly says that it does want such a change. This is evident from the Labor Party's 1986 platform which states:
In the context of the preparations for Bicentennial celebrations, to initiate and support moves to establish with popular acceptance an Australian flag . . .

I emphasise the words `with popular acceptance'. Why does the Government reject the concept of a referendum if it is concerned about popular acceptance? What can be clearer evidence of popular acceptance than the holding of a referendum? So the Labor Party, which clearly wants to change the flag, which pretends that it wants to change the flag in the context of popular support, is not prepared to allow popular support or opposition to be expressed in the only effective democratic way that is available, and that is through a referendum.

We have heard people say that they will not use the word `hypocrisy'. What can be more hypocritical than a party saying that it wants popular acceptance for a change in the Australian flag and then denying the Australian people the right to express acceptance or rejection? As I say, this underlines the total hypocrisy and humbug of all of the people on the other side of the chamber who will vote against this Bill. All we are saying is that we want to put to the democratic test the proposition that the Labor Party maintained in its 1986 policy platform. We want to make certain that before any changes take place, there will be popular acceptance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted under the sessional order for consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will proceed to further consideration of Government Business.

—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Michael Baume said in his speech on the Flags Amendment Bill 1987 that I said that the flag was just a bit of cloth with no meaning. In fact, I said that the flag had a great deal of meaning but that the meaning was in terms of what people felt for it, not in absolute terms of what the piece of cloth contained. The flag has a great deal of meaning to the people who wave it or burn it, depending on their point of view. Whatever meaning the flag has is measured in terms of what people think of it, not in absolute terms of what it contains.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to make three amendments to the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974, each resulting from developments since the last major revision of the Act in 1986. The Government continues to attach great importance to ensuring that the Act is effectively achieving its aim of providing consumers and business people with an appropriate measure of protection against unscrupulous traders.

The first of the proposed amendments provides that a corporation (and in some cases an individual) shall not, in trade or commerce, falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value. This amendment clarifies the scope of the prohibitions contained in paragraphs 53 (a) and (aa) of the Act. Justice Ryan of the Federal Court of Australia, in Ducret v Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace Pty Ltd (1987) ATRP 40-804, indicated that a representation as to value may be a representation as to `quality' as defined in the existing section 53, but whether it does or not depends upon the facts of each case. This amendment should remove any doubt that s. 53 prohibits false representations as to the value of goods or services.

A number of States have enacted or are about to enact Fair Trading legislation which mirrors the provisions of Part V, Division 1 of the Trade Practices Act. This State legislation, promoted through the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Minister, extends the operation of the consumer protection provisions to cover all traders whether corporate or not. The Government strongly supports the development of such complementary uniform legislation, and has advised the States of the proposed amendment to section 53.

The second amendment proposes the repeal of section 65u of the Act. That section is a sunset clause on the application of the product safety and product information provisions in the Act to food and drink for human consumption, which will take effect on 1 July 1988.

Section 65u was originally inserted at the request of some sectors of the food industry in order to give the States the opportunity to put specific food recall legislation in place. These industry sectors argued at that time that food recalls should be controlled under State food law rather than under the Trade Practices Act.

Division 1a of Part V of the Act is concerned with product safety standards, the banning of unsafe consumer products and the recall of consumer products with safety related defects. The essential elements of the recall provisions are mandatory notification of safety-related product recalls and a reserve power to require further recall action if there is evidence that voluntary recall procedures have not removed the risk to consumer safety. Foods and beverages are essential consumer products and, to provide the level of consumer protection from health and safety risks which consumers reasonably expect, it is not desirable to omit foods and beverages from the reach of the Act, unless, of course, it was clear that food and beverage safety, particularly in relation to recalls, was assured by some other protection mechanism. This is not the case.

The hoped for uniform food recall legislation at State level has not eventuated. I am advised that, at present, some States do not have specific food recall powers and that, in any case, existing State powers are not uniform.

Food and beverage distribution is of a national character. State borders are artificial in such a national market. Even in the case of so called `local' food products, one can never be sure that a potentially lethal food product has not crossed a State border. Australians travel interstate extensively and food purchased in one State may be consumed in another. Cities and towns close to borders are often supplied food and beverages from the adjoining States. If a safety-related recall becomes necessary, then the recall is generally national in character and national co-ordination of such recalls is essential.

If section 65u is not repealed, the Commonwealth would not necessarily even know of a food safety problem and the recall may be conducted on a State basis with little or no co-ordination to ensure national consumer protection.

As mentioned previously, not to repeal section 65u would have the effect of removing foods and beverages from the scope of Division 1a of the Act entirely from 1 July 1988. That is, not only would the recall powers of the Act not apply to food and beverages, but the power to prevent the supply of unsafe food products would also be lost. This would be a cause for great concern, as it would mean that the Commonwealth would be powerless to prevent the supply of a food product clearly shown to threaten the health and safety of consumers. There is a clear and very reasonable expectation by Australians that the Commonwealth would be able to protect consumers nationally from unsafe consumer goods, including unsafe foods and beverages. This is not to say that the States do not have a legitimate role in food safety. Indeed, the States have a primary role in this regard, particularly through the adoption of the Australian Food Standards Code and State health and food inspection systems. However, the reserve ability to protect consumers nationally from defective foods and beverages, just as for any other product, should remain with the Commonwealth under the Trade Practices Act.

The last amendment is administrative in nature, resulting from the transfer of responsibility for the enforcement of Part V, Division 1a of the Act from the Trade Practices Commission to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. Consistent with the practice of the Commission, the amendment will allow persons authorised by the Secretary to the Department to institute prosecutions for alleged contraventions of the Act without being required to obtain the prior consent in writing of the Minister. The usual requirement to obtain Ministerial consent ensures that private prosecutions for contraventions of the Act are only instituted in accordance with the Commonwealth's prosecution policy. There is no need for this requirement when prosecutions are commenced by officers from the Commonwealth agencies responsible for the enforcement of the Act, such as the Federal Bureau.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposals in this Bill will not require any additional expenditure by the Government. Any additional work involved in ensuring compliance with the amended provisions of the Act should be capable of being absorbed by existing resources.

Further, the proposals will not impose any new costs on industry, as this Bill does not place any regulatory burden on business other than that which has existed since the last major revision of the Act in 1986.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, and commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Precincts Bill 1988 provides for the delineation of an area to be known as the parliamentary precincts over which the Presiding Officers of the Federal Parliament will have management and control. I note from the speakers list that Senator McMullan, who is also a senator from the Australian Capital Territory, and I are to speak on this legislation. I would not like it to be interpreted that we are the only senators who care about the new Parliament House or its precincts. I think this probably reflects the fact that we realise the importance of this building to the Australian Capital Territory. It is a very significant part of the national capital and a significant attraction to visitors. We also note the importance of that to this area.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past there has not been such a definitive statement of the boundaries of the parliamentary precincts and this has raised questions from time to time of just where the control of the Presiding Officers begins and ends in relation to matters affecting the management of the buildings and the grounds of the Parliament. This Bill makes quite clear the extent of the parliamentary precincts which will encompass virtually the entire area enclosed by State Circle and all the buildings and structures within that area. The Opposition supports this Bill.

The need for a defined parliamentary precinct has been recognised for a number of years. It was picked up by the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, which is now the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, of which I have been a member for some time. The Committee recognised this as a matter that needed attention. It also recognised that issues such as the extent of parliamentary control over the land around the buildings, traffic control and access, control of persons in the parliamentary area and police powers or activities were matters which required clarification. They probably required it for this building; but they certainly will for the new one.

As long ago as May 1978 the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges also called for legislation to define the boundaries of the Parliament and in 1984 the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege recommended:
. . . the precincts of the present Parliament House and of the new Parliament House, be defined authoritatively.

The need for such definition stems in part from the doubts which have existed in relation to Parliament's powers in a number of respects. These include the capacity of the Presiding Officers to compel police to carry out their orders, including the power to compel prosecution.

The Parliamentary Precincts Bill establishes the management and control of the precincts in the Presiding Officers of the Parliament-that is, the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate. Generally, the area will be subject to the laws of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). There are a number of exceptions which are enumerated and apparent from this Bill. Agreement between the Presiding Officers and the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Protective Services and the Director of Public Prosecutions for law enforcement in the precincts may be made under this Bill. In addition, the control of the ministerial wing is subject to agreement between the Presiding Officers and the relevant Minister. I think this aspect needs some clarification which I hope we will get in the committee stage of the Bill because it is something new. I would like to know exactly what power it is envisaged that the Executive will have in relation to dealings with the President and the Speaker.

In addition to the provision for a parliamentary precinct, the Bill will also have the effect of extending the parliamentary zone. Of course this is quite necessary. The new zone will include the land of the parliamentary precinct in addition to the land contained in the parliamentary triangle bordered by Commonwealth Avenue, Kings Avenue and the southern shores of Lake Burley Griffin. In the area within the zone no buildings may be constructed or work undertaken without the approval of both Houses of Parliament. I certainly support that.

Of all the area of the ACT, that triangle very significantly relates to the national capital. Of course the people of Canberra have an interest in what happens there as well, but I do not think it can be denied that it has status within the concept of its being the national capital. It is appropriate that such a restriction should be placed on the area including the national Parliament and other significant institutions. While the area forms part of the physical city of Canberra its national character demands this.

It must be recalled that the Federal Parliament's place here, the Federation, the establishment of a national capital is significant and nobody can deny that Canberra has developed as a beautiful modern city. It is important to understand that is not only the home of the Parliament, but also home to 260,000 people who live here as part of the national capital and we do take an interest in what happens in this area. Zoning otherwise and planning at present rest with the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC). That organisation will need to continue to play a significant role in the planning and recommendations which will come before the Parliament for any further developments within the parliamentary zone or the extension of it. Of course, the NCDC is also heavily involved in planning in other parts of Canberra.

Undoubtedly, this building will have an impact on some of the residential areas in its vicinity. This has been the case where there has been expansion, particularly at Barry Drive which, when I came here, was full of houses. It is now all office buildings. There are also other parts of Canberra where there has been expansion. I wonder what the future will be for State Circle and the roads nearby-Canberra Avenue and perhaps even down as far as Manuka. Those areas may, in time, seek to take on a different character. There has also been some concern expressed by people living in the vicinity of the new Parliament House about the likelihood that it may develop for use for professional purposes. So far inquiries to the NCDC have indicated that although it expects changes to the character of the area, there are no immediate plans for any development. However, I think that the NCDC should take note of what has happened in other areas of Canberra and give some thought to the future, rather than letting any form of trouble erupt in the first place. Some thought should be given to the development of a draft policy plan for the area so that people who are involved can have some idea of what will occur rather than merely having to wait until there are sufficient problems to demand that something be done.

It would be unfortunate if the parliamentary precincts and the zone, which are being so clearly defined by the Bill, get into any form of difficulties because of the development of the surrounding area. When speaking of the surrounding area I refer to clause 4 (2) (a) which specifically indicates that the arcs by the outer edge will form the boundary of the precincts at the top of the retaining wall. I am curious to know, and the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Ray) no doubt will be able to tell us, why the precincts are determined at the top of the retaining wall rather than at the bottom. Logic to me would have required that it be the bottom of the wall. I can envisage, as has already happened, vandals painting the walls and graffiti appearing on them. Who will be responsible for removing it? What if there are conflicts in relation to that area? It seems to me that the bottom of the wall would have been the logical place. I certainly hope that the Minister will be able to answer those questions in relation to the maintenance of those walls which surround the building. I think that the area of the tunnel is specifically excluded-that is, the road part, but not the actual walls. From the point of view of traffic I understand that.

The other matter I want to refer to is the future of this building, which is part of the parliamentary triangle. I hope that the Government will tell us before we leave this building what will happen to it. I hope that tonight the Minister will be able to tell us what will happen to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —To what?
—This building.
—Do you want the next Melbourne Cup winner at the same time?

—That would be helpful. The sub-committee of the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House recommended that it be-loosely summing it up-a political and constitutional museum. I hope that it can be developed in that way so that the political history of this country, which is so closely associated with the building, can be displayed here in a way that is meaningful, in particular to school children who visit Canberra, so that they can get some concept of Australia from 1927 to 1988. I hope that in a portion of it we might have the memorabilia that remains of the 1901 to 1927 era and that the portraits and objects that are meaningful will still be in this building. It will then be an additional significant tourist attraction in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important, though, that these decisions are made before we vacate the building and it is left in a slight shambles. I can imagine some of my friends taking the things they want and leaving the things they do not want, but if we are not careful this place may well look a bit of a mess. I would be very sorry indeed if that occurred. I urge the Government to make the decision and the commitment as to what will happen to this building. It is important. Of course, maintenance and upkeep will be expensive, but if it is to be retained, that expense will have to be met in any event. I think it would be wasteful to delay the future use of the building, and lock it up. I would have hoped the interdepartmental committee would have reported to the Government a long time ago.

Specifically though, we are discussing the precincts of the new building, and their definition. As I have indicated, the Opposition supports the Bill. We recognise the need for the powers of the Presiding Officers. I hope to get some answers to the limitations placed upon the Presiding Officers by this reference to the control of the ministerial wing being dealt with somewhat differently from the way any part of this building has been dealt with in the past. We support also the concept of the necessary extension of the parliamentary zone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my Australian Capital Territory colleague Senator Reid in supporting the Parliamentary Precincts Bill. I would also like to join her in her concern about the development and planning implications of the new Parliament House and the need for the National Capital Development Commission, or its successor body under self-government, to be conscious of and involved in the planning consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is important to Parliament itself. It deals with the problem of what area the Executive Government hands over to Parliament. It has been mentioned both in the House of Representatives and here that it is very important to the traditions of a Westminster parliamentary system that the Speaker and the President, as the representatives of the Parliament, retain their exclusive jurisdiction and control within the Houses of Parliament. The recognition of the need to define these boundaries goes back quite a long way. In 1969 the Joint Select Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House brought down a report which said:
Down through the years it has been an embarrassment to the Parliament to lack control or to be unsure of the extent of its control over the area of land surrounding the building.
The Committee recommended that:
. . . the desirability of having this power incorporated in a statute be considered at an early date.

I am not sure that even by our normal leisurely standards 19 years can be regarded as an early date. Nevertheless that matter has come forward. In my brief period here and in my experience of Parliament in a previous occupation examples have been referred to me of failures of definition that have been a matter of some controversy or inconvenience. Of course, it is not a matter of my personal experience, but in Australian Senate Practice Odgers refers to a case brought before a Canberra magistrate in 1974, who held that the roadway outside Parliament House was a public street. He said that the precincts of Parliament House were actually within the walls of the building, taking the definition that a precinct was enclosed by walls.

I noticed also in 1974 that the then President and my good friend, Senator O'Byrne, referred to instances when senators had been obstructed by journalists and cameramen coming to and going from Parliament. It was very prescient of him because it happens somewhat more these days. He referred to this as a possible obstruction of the right of people's access and he was concerned about the control of the precincts. I suspect that I and many of my colleagues would be more concerned if we were never obstructed by journalists on the way in than if it were to happen too often. Nevertheless, in a slightly less serious vein it is an indication of the need to have serious, effective control over the precincts and therefore to have the precincts defined. It is important as a matter of principle, as an assertion of the supremacy of the Parliament over the Executive.

Obviously, with my Australian Capital Territory colleague, Senator Reid, I want to refer to the importance of this Bill, the development of the new Parliament House and the implications for this building, for the Australian Capital Territory and for the region. It is important to remember that many of the benefits that will flow from the development of the new Parliament House and the decisions that are made about the utilisation of this building have economic and social implications beyond the Australian Capital Territory, into the surrounding regions of New South Wales. The decisions made following the completion of the new Parliament House are very important for the building industry and for employment in the Australian Capital Territory. The new Parliament House building itself, the precincts of which we are defining in this Bill, directly, through its continuing operations with the very large employment taking place within it, will make a continuing and substantial contribution to the economy of the Australian Capital Territory and will do so indirectly through the services provided by contractors, suppliers, lessees and licensees.

Relating to that, I want to take up a matter arising under clause 7 which is an important point and not unrelated to the point made by Senator Reid. In the very proper exercise which is defined in this Bill, whereby the Parliament can, through its Presiding Officers, issue leases and licences for the operation of commercial enterprises within these precincts, we have to give consideration to the impact of the operation of those leases and licences within the precincts on the existing businesses within the region. A number of businesses, finance and others, have grown up in Barton, Kingston and Manuka, which provide services to a great extent to people from Parliament. Until recently I was the manager of a building in the Barton area in which resided both an office of Australian Airlines and an office of the Commonwealth Bank. Both those offices were heavily frequented by people from the existing Parliament House. The commercial operations of those enterprises and others will be affected. That does not mean the change should not take place-it already has and it is beneficial that the leases and licences should be exercised within the new Parliament House. It is a necessary service to the very large number of people who work there. But I draw attention to the fact that there are potential commercial implications for other businesses in the region and it is a matter that should be noted as being of concern.

I want to refer also, like Senator Reid, to the importance of the decisions to be made fairly soon about the use of this building, a building that comes within the zone as defined in this Bill. I have always been sympathetic to the proposal that it should be developed as some form of constitutional museum. However, I am interested in the fact that people are coming forward with perhaps more enterprising versions of that idea. I do not want to endorse any particular commercial proposal, because that would be entirely inappropriate, but, as many senators are aware, there is a proposal for the development of a politics in action centre here which would involve a democracy theatre, a Prime Minister's gallery, a section on the political process, and what is fascinatingly called a parliamentarians' hall of fame. I am not sure how many of my current colleagues would qualify but it is certainly important. Another suggested section is politics and humour, for which I would not qualify, but some of my colleagues would, and there are other proposed sections such as politics and the media, political systems and an education centre, as well as the normal tourist facilities for the sale of souvenirs, et cetera.

I do not necessarily endorse that particular proposal but I refer to it because of the importance to the tourist industry in the Australian Capital Territory of the use of the two Parliament House buildings together. In 1987 the old Parliament House, that is this building, was the third most popular attraction, attracting almost 473,000 visitors to the Australian Capital Territory. The sixth most important attraction was the new Parliament House, with 377,000 visitors. In this zone, the National Gallery and the High Court were fourth and fifth, and the National Library was the ninth most important attraction in the Territory. So it is very important that an early, sensible and attractive decision is made about the use of this building to sustain that important impetus to the tourist industry and therefore to the region. I recommend that those matters must be given important and early consideration. This is not a controversial matter on which I shall take up the Senate's time any further. I wished to raise the matters that I thought were important for the Parliament and for the people whom I represent here in the Australian Capital Territory. I welcome the Bill, which will clarify a longstanding shortcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators who have spoken in this debate on the Parliamentary Precincts Bill for their support. Senator Reid raised one or two points in her remarks and put me on notice that she would be raising a couple of other points later. One of the major queries was why we defined the precinct at the top of the wall rather than at the bottom of the wall. It was primarily for patrolling reasons. It is easier to patrol inside the top of the wall than to have all the patrols going outside the wall. A lot of thought was given to exactly where the boundaries would go. Even more thought was given to that than to the redesign of Calare and other electorates some years ago. That is the primary reason.

SPEECH.PARA: If one has the design of Parliament House in mind, one realises that it is a lot easier to define the boundary as being at the top of the wall and to patrol around there and be responsible for that, because if it is defined at the bottom of the wall one would have patrols outside it. Does one patrol 6 feet or 8 feet from the wall? That would depend on where the road cuts in and all the rest of it. I think that is the reason for that definition.

The second query concerned the relationship between the Presiding Officers and the executive wing. I notice that portfolio Minister West went to that point in another place. The debate there clearly indicates that this is a matter for negotiation between the relevant Minister in charge of the executive wing, who in this case at present is myself, and the Presiding Officers. But if we do not reach agreement, then the Presiding Officers, by virtue of this Bill, will have the say. At present work is being done on various memoranda of understanding-one relating to the Australian Protective Services, one with the Australian Federal Police, one with the Director of Public Prosecutions, and finally one on a memorandum of understanding, as I understand it, between the officers of the Parliament-the Speaker and the President-and the officers of the Executive in respect of the new executive wing. I understand that those memoranda of understanding will not be completed for some weeks. In the end, they will have to go to the Attorney-General's Department for checking, but I understand that the discussions-negotiations would be putting it on too high a plane-are proceeding very amicably and we look forward to a fairly prompt result.

Both Senator McMullan and Senator Reid referred to the future of this building. Probably the biggest problem is that there are so many alternatives, all the way down to privatising the place via Simon Townsend through to constitutional museums, knocking down this part of the building or that part of the building. These are not easy decisions to make. As we all know, a couple of sections of this building are full of asbestos and are a menace to man and boy. Do we leave those here? Do we give in to the barbarians from the Department of Finance who would just like to utilise this as office space and nothing else? All those ideas are floating around.

I am confident that at the end of the day the more enlightened people will prevail. This matter in some form or other will come back to Cabinet in the next few weeks. There are those who would like to turn this place into a major tourist attraction: perhaps that is the wrong expression; part of an integral tourist attraction-with the High Court, the National Gallery, the new Parliament House and the National Science and Technology Centre. It is a marvellous opportunity to have a rounded tourist complex.

I have a self-interest here. I would very much like to see, as I mentioned to Senator Short the other day, the Electoral Education Section of the Australian Electoral Commission come here. I am sure that there are many other ways in which to utilise this space. I am very much in favour of the living museum idea. I would like these chambers to be retained as they are; I do not want to see them roped off. I want the public to come and sit where Senator Puplick is sitting. I do not want members of the public to get ideas about taking pre-selection from me or getting too uppity. However, I think that is the sort of thing we need. We need something to attract tourists which is not too expensive and which would get school children through here. I cannot at this stage answer Senator Reid's threshold question `Have we made up our minds?' in order to give an answer tonight. There are a lot of things Senator Reid may like to know tonight. Unfortunately, this is not a matter on which I can help her.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow's race results.
—I suggested another matter earlier, Senator Colston; the winner of the next Melbourne Cup would be just as hard to predict. I thank honourable senators for their support and commend the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 2 of the Bill, under the heading `Commencement', is divided into two parts. One identifies those portions of the Act which will receive royal assent, namely, clauses 1, 2, 3, 4 and 7. The rest of the provisions will commence on a date or day to be fixed by a proclamation. I note specifically, though, that the portion which will proceed by way of proclamation is clause 6 which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The precincts are under the control and management of the Presiding Officers . . .
Subsection (3) says that in respect of the ministerial wing the functions will be given to the Presiding Officers:
subject to any limitation and conditions agreed between the Presiding Officers and the Minister.

I envisage a situation where the combined weight of the Presiding Officers does not equal that of the Minister. Could the Minister tell the Committee anything more than he has indicated so far? I note his comment that where there is conflict, the view of the Presiding Officers will prevail, but I recognise the weight that the Executive can bring to bear on the Presiding Officers. Is it envisaged that the control of the ministerial wing may, for example, be handed over to the Minister? Will that be the agreement, or will the Presiding Officers have control of that wing, but from time to time on matters of usage it will be by agreement with the Minister? Is this a way of saying that the ministerial wing will not be under the control of the Presiding Officers but under the control of the Executive?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is still a matter for discussion between the two arms of government in drawing up the memorandum. As I recollect the discussions when the Bill was being drafted, the ultimate control lies with the Presiding Officers. They may not want to exercise every responsibility in that area. There are differences-for instance, as to how the area will be protected. In general, the Parliament is protected almost exclusively by the Parliamentary Security Service. The executive wing, needing a more highly trained person, will be covered by the Australian Protective Service. In a general sense, the overall control will be with the Presiding Officers. They may want, in a memorandum of understanding, to cede certain administrative functions back to the Executive, on the grounds that that would make the executive wing easier to manage and to administer. But the ultimate power will still reside with the Presiding Officers. I am not necessarily sure that that was always the view when the Parliamentary Precincts Bill was first thought of. It was not always necessarily the view of the Executive that that was to be the case. But after some fairly protracted and complete negotiations, we have achieved that point.

—The Minister referred to the fact that, ultimately, the powers will reside in the Presiding Officers. Everything he has said tends to confirm my worst fears that the ministerial wing will be required to be given over by the Presiding Officers to the Minister. He also referred to a memorandum of understanding. Is he able to table that and let us have a look at what is included in it? Originally I asked whether it would be something that was done by agreement from time to time, or whether it would be something that would be given over. Can the Minister give us an assurance, for example, that the proclamation will not be delayed pending an agreement between the Presiding Officers and the Minister? Can the Minister give us an assurance that the memorandum will be tabled and made available for debate prior to its being signed and finally put together? If the Presiding Officers are giving over powers to the Minister that is something that honourable senators in this chamber would take a great interest in and they are entitled to because the President belongs to this chamber not, I suggest, to the Minister or to the Executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already dealt with one or two of those points. I do not think Senator Reid could have been concentrating at the time when I said that, as I understand it, currently the memorandum is being formulated.
—There must be a draft, you see.

—There may be a draft at this stage. As I understand it, that draft is being prepared by an officer of the Senate and then there will be a degree of consultation with the Executive. I think we are probably confusing two things here. Senator Reid asked whether powers were going to be handed over. I do not understand that to be the case. It is simply the way the executive wing is to be administered. What we are talking about in that memorandum of understanding are some fairly general principles. We will not spell everything out and it will not be precise.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asked whether there was an intention to delay the proclamation. No, there is no such intention. Of course, not everything will be proclaimed at the same time because not everything is ready to be handed over at the same time. But there can be no question that the power to delay proclamation can be used by the Executive in any dealings or negotiations with the Presiding Officers. That is not the Government's intention and, as I am one of the relevant Ministers, I will be making sure that it does not occur in that form, even though it could be said that some potential for that may exist in the way the Act is framed. That is not the intention. It is simply to fit in with the construction timetable that various areas of the House could be handed over at different times.

I refer Senator Reid to a letter-I will table a copy-written on 25 February 1988 by Senator Barney Cooney in his capacity as Chairman of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to the portfolio Minister, Stewart West, in which he raised the proclamation dates. I also have the response. I suppose that one of the crucial paragraphs in this correspondence is:

You might also wish to inform the Committee by way of background that the Presiding Officers were consulted during all stages of the preparation of the Bill and the commencement provision was approved by them at the drafting stage.
I table those documents as they may help to explain some of the points raised by the honourable senator.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is about to commence debate on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. It is simply a machinery Bill to ensure that the Patents Office acts with authority in meeting the requirements of the Safeguards Act without breaching the Patents Act. It has no wider implications than that. The Opposition parties support the Bill. However, I have had a look at the speakers list on this Bill which, as I have said, is purely a machinery Bill and it is clear that the maddies on the extreme left wing of the Australian Labor Party, namely the Australian Democrats and the people in the Nuclear Disarmament Party, will use this opportunity for some sort of debate in regard to nuclear fuel and nuclear weapons around the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I was somewhat disappointed recently to have had a conversation with a young gentleman of my acquaintance in which he criticised the export of uranium ore to France. I questioned him to find out what he knew about the subject and it became clear to me that the maddies and their publicity are getting through to the youths of Australia and that the young people of Australia really do not understand what this is all about. I wonder whether it might be possible for people, such as those on our side of the Senate and indeed on the Government's side of the Senate, who support the use of nuclear fuel for the generation of power, to put their case more simply so that the young people of Australia could begin to understand that there are no problems about the export of yellowcake. Indeed, there are no problems about the export of enriched uranium for peaceful purposes. In the case of Australia, nuclear material is currently limited to that used for scientific and medical purposes. It is a very simple proposition and I hope that people can understand it. We also have the Australian Safeguards Office as a statutory authority to oversee the use of our product, whether it is in Australia or around the world.

Let us then look at what can be done with uranium ore. Firstly, it has to be dug out of the ground, refined and brought down to a product which can be distinguished as uranium ore. That is all we do in Australia. It is a product which is commonly called yellowcake. We do not enrich it in Australia; we simply mine it and export to various countries-mainly to Canada-this stuff, using simple language, which is dug out of the ground. So all we really have is a product which is in the earth already. We clean it up by taking out the products which are not uranium and we export this material which is called yellowcake, but which is simply an ore. In no way is it dangerous.

That ore could be used to produce nuclear weapons. Let me turn to that straight away. What the superpowers do with uranium-in other words, the United States of America, the Soviet Union, France and the United Kingdom-is go through what in simple terms may be called the plutonium route to produce a product called plutonium. That involves very complex engineering. It is a very expensive way of dealing with uranium, and probably only those four countries go through that route to produce a product which can be used for nuclear weapons.

Let us look, then, at an alternative route to doing something with uranium ore-what is called the centrifuge route, running the uranium ore around some sort of centrifuge. In simple language, it is something like a washing machine, although, of course, it is much more complicated. With a simple centrifuge system, by running the ore around and around for a long period, the uranium can be gradually enriched so that it becomes purer and purer, until ultimately it is 3 per cent pure. That is what we call enriched uranium. Once the uranium is at that stage, it can then be used for the production of electricity-power to keep people warm, to light their homes, and to run all the machines that need to be run around the world. It is the cleanest, purest way of producing electricity.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the leukaemia, the cancer?

—If Senator Sanders, sitting there and making his inane comments, were to visit western Victoria and see the smoke which envelops areas of western Victoria as we generate electricity there from brown coal, he would see why those of us who say that nuclear energy is the cleanest system want to see the world adopt the nuclear system for the production of electricity. We do not produce enriched uranium in Australia.
—What a pity we don't.

—Exactly. What a pity we do not. It would enable us to process our basic product and earn substantially more in export funds. For a country which is losing almost $1 billion per month on its trade, what a great tragedy it is that we are not exporting not just uranium ore but enriched uranium, enriched to 3 per cent. Let me explain why that would be also a safe thing to do. I hope that Senator Sanders and his maddie colleagues around the chamber will listen to the reason why I say that it would be a very safe thing. If the uranium is run around a centrifuge, one can keep purifying it until ultimately, after a very long period, one can reach a stage at which it is 90 per cent pure. Once that stage is reached, one has the ability to produce a very dirty nuclear bomb.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a very simple proposition. We talk about producing uranium that is enriched to 3 per cent or enriched to 90 per cent. That is a big jump. It is a long and complicated process to enrich it to 3 per cent. I have not worked out the mathematics of how many multiples of 3 per cent one has to apply to reach 90 per cent, but it is a great many. If we allow some of the Third World countries to set up enriched uranium plants, they could generate a dirty bomb through their plants. So it would be far better for us to enrich the uranium in Australia and export it to countries which do not have an enrichment plant. It is a very simple proposition. We would then know that they were taking it in the condition in which we were supplying it. They would not have the enrichment plant to do anything with it, so we would be able to see clearly that the uranium remained in the condition in which we exported it. We would not have to worry about what those countries were doing.

That is what Canada is doing. Most of the uranium we send to Canada as an ore is just dug out of the ground and cleaned up a bit, but not enriched. The Canadians make all the money by enriching it to 3 per cent and exporting it to those countries which wish to use it for the generation of electricity-not for use in nuclear weapons but for producing power to keep people warm, to keep their homes warm and to provide them with lighting.

The simple fact is that there are nuclear power plants in Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, Bulgaria, Canada, China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, East Germany, West Germany, Hungary, India, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Mexico, the Netherlands, Pakistan, the Philippines, Poland, Romania, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan, the United Kingdom, the United States, the USSR, and Yugoslavia. Only five of those nations-Argentina, India, Pakistan, South Africa and Israel-do not allow safeguard inspection of all their nuclear facilities. Despite these exceptions, 98 per cent of all nuclear facilities and installations are inspected under the international safeguards agreement, and 124 nations are signatories to safeguards agreements. All the evidence supports the view that the safeguards system is working.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha! Really! Don't you read the newspapers?

—We are not talking about enrichment plants. I am talking about nuclear power being used to generate electricity. The Government of the Northern Territory, sensibly, wants to have built in the Territory an enrichment plant that would enable Australia to export uranium enriched to 3 per cent for use in the generation of electricity. That would be a good thing. Much wealth would be generated as a result of that export. Are we to allow the Northern Territory to remain a mendicant Territory very substantially dependent upon Australian taxpayers because of the silliness of the present Labor Government in that it will not allow the Northern Territory to go ahead with such a plant? Are we to deprive Australia of the advantage of the opportunities that we have to export our product and to earn income because of the silliness of the Australian Labor Party, which will not support the building of an enrichment plant and, indeed, will not allow the export of our ore to France any longer? What absolute nonsense is this when we know that the safeguards system can be used to ensure that our ore is not used in connection with nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: By far the vast majority of the people of Australia think along our lines. It is time that we got these few simple messages home to young Australians. We ought to make sure that the messages of these maddies-we shall hear them later this evening-are pushed aside and shown to be the nonsense that they are, so that the young people of Australia begin to understand that they are talking nonsense and that what we are talking about is the sensible route for the use of a material. It is far better that Australia uses and encourages the world to use nuclear power for the generation of electricity, rather than that we keep burning brown coal and other dirty coals and keep pouring smoke and all the rest into the atmosphere and destroying it.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill pertains to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act which was passed in February 1987 and which gave legislative effect to a number of Australia's obligations at an international level, including the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I have no reason to oppose this amendment but I feel that it is a good opportunity to remind the Government of its original position on the mining of uranium in Australia, particularly as the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is so concerned about getting back to some of its grassroots support following the recent rather devastating election results. A recent opinion poll conducted by the Sydney based international market research company, Frank Small and Associates, indicated that 41 per cent of Australians opposed the mining and export of Australian uranium, while only 39 per cent favour it. Apparently 18 per cent did not care.

SPEECH.PARA: Given the current debate within the ALP on uranium sales to France, and the question of whether Australian uranium ends up in French nuclear weapons, it is worth taking notice of an article in the Age by Brad Collis on 20 February. Following allegations made in the West German magazine Der Spiegel that Australian uranium is being relabelled to allow some companies to bypass restrictions on its use, Mr Collis pointed out that it is technically impossible to determine whether Australian uranium is used in weapons grade material. The uranium processing pipeline in Europe begins with yellowcake supplied by various producers, including Australia. Once the uranium has entered the processing chain it is a raw material and its origin is indistinguishable. From yellowcake it becomes uranium hexafluoride gas and is later converted into a uranium oxide in the form of pellets which go into the reactor fuel rods.

Any argument based on country of origin would be valid only if the origin of individual atoms in the processed material could be identified-but it cannot. So it is obvious why the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) cannot give any guarantee about where Australian uranium ends up; nor can the French Defence Minister give a similar guarantee. France imports uranium from several countries as well as mining its own, and the uranium is all mixed up together. This makes safeguards absolutely worthless. South Africa provides no safeguards as to its uranium; nor do Namibia and Niger. Canada provides some safeguards, and Australia provides strict safeguards, so we are told. However, all of the uranium ends up in the melting pot. Doubtless some of it ends up at Mururoa Atoll to be used in nuclear weapons testing.

Officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have now admitted that the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM), which is meant to be a watchdog agency in Europe, sanctioned the reflagging of a shipment of Australian uranium to enable it to be enriched to nuclear weapons grade, without Australia's knowledge and in contravention of Australia's non-proliferation policy. Apparently EURATOM provided advice to the West German company Nukem on how to avoid Australia's nuclear safeguards policy, and then misled the Australian Government into believing that the safeguards agreements were being adhered to. I am sure that Senator Sanders will provide a lot more detail about that particular scandal.

Despite all the high and mighty posturing by the ALP, we now have the admission from on high that, as the Safe Energy Movement consistently has pointed out, all goes into one big melting pot. That is a quotation from a Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade official last week. Safeguards are utterly and totally meaningless.They are a fraud. Now we await an admission by this Government that its safeguards mean precisely nothing and that there is no way in which the Government can say categorically that Australian uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons, particularly French nuclear weapons. When will the Government admit to the truth on the subject of the destination of Australian uranium? When will the Government stop lying to the Australian people?

It will be interesting to see exactly what transpires at the Federal ALP Conference in Hobart in a couple of months time. The ALP promised three things to its members when in 1984 it changed from being an anti-uranium party to being a pro-uranium party. It promised, first, it would not sell uranium to France; second, Australian uranium would be used only for peaceful purposes; and third, that strict safeguards would apply to all uranium sales. All of those promises have been broken; they lie in tatters. It is no wonder that there is total disillusionment within the ALP throughout Australia, and outside the country as well.

It is also important to note the continuing slowdown of the growth of the nuclear industry around the world, as well as the continuing opposition to that industry since the disastrous accident at Chernobyl. That opposition includes protests in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe as well as in developing countries like India and Hong Kong. It recently came to my notice that some Soviet Union citizens actually halted the progress of a nuclear plant that was planned. That shows that although the Soviet Union Government's official policy is to keep up with its nuclear program, when citizens get busy and make their position well known on environmental issues they can reverse the decisions of their government, even in the Soviet Union. That happened recently with a planned project that has now been cancelled.

A recent article in the Guardian in Britain reported on the growth during the past year of the Safe Energy Movement in Japan, one of the countries most devoted to nuclear power. The article said that when in October each year the Government organises a national nuclear power day, there is significant opposition to the growth of the nuclear industry in Japan. In Sweden, a country with 12 nuclear reactors, which depends on nuclear power for 50 per cent of its electricity, the Government is committed to closing down the first of its reactors by 1995, a second by 1996, and the remainder by 2010. The Swedish Government has chosen an alternative energy path because it realises that it is environmentally too dangerous to keep up with nuclear power generation.

On 11 March the Italian Prime Minister resigned during a row over his decision to build a nuclear power station following a referendum last November when Italians voted against the construction of new nuclear power stations. In Britain, yet another country with a strong nuclear power program, Lord Marshall, Chairman of the Central Electricity Generating Board (CEGB), conceded last October in a radio interview that Britain has not yet reaped any economic benefit from nuclear power. This is the first time that the CEGB has publicly admitted that nuclear power has never been cheap when compared to other forms of electricity generation. That admission comes on top of growing concern about the long term effects of the Windscale disaster 30 years ago and continuing unease about experiments at two other reactors in England and Wales, one of which was called off after protests. The issue of nuclear waste dumping in rural areas has also seen the remarkable spectacle of Conservative parliamentarians supporting angry constituents on this concern. That is quite an interesting about-turn for the acolytes of a woman totally committed to a nuclear future for Great Britain.

Even in India there is a growing popular movement against the irrelevance of India's ambitious indigenous nuclear power program. India has seven operating nuclear power plants and a fast breeder test reactor as well as small reprocessing plants. There has been a history of accidents at the two Tarapur plants near Bombay, causing a great deal of prominent critics including Praful Bidwai of the Times of India and Professor Dhirendra Sharma of the Committee For A Sane Nuclear Policy. Grassroots safe energy movements have sprung up to oppose nuclear power station construction in Gujarat, Kerala and Karnataka, despite government arrogance and hostility. To top it all, the Indian Government is now lumbered with the task of dismantling the Rajasthan nuclear plant, Raps 1, which has been leaking since 1981. This reactor was a Candu prototype reactor built in 1973, that is a Canadian model, not an Indian one, although since then India has tried to design its own reactors.

In Hong Kong there is growing concern about a nuclear power plant being constructed on the Chinese side of the border as a joint project between the two governments. It is also noteworthy that in Malaysia during the recent arrest of more than 100 people by the Government last year, several were from Friends of the Earth and the group protesting at the dumping of radioactive waste by the Japanese Asian Rare Earth Company at Papan.

So we now have the spectacle of increasing opposition to nuclear power not only in the industrialised countries of the West including Japan, but also the socialist bloc countries and the developing countries. At the same time, the number of nuclear power plants planned for the future is declining, according to the United States Atomic Industrial Forum. There have been no new orders for nuclear power plants in the US for over 10 years, although the number in operation grew from 272 in 1985 to 285 in 1986. A number of proposed plants have been cancelled and others are being shut down. Only this month the US Department of Energy announced that it would not restart its nuclear reactor at Hanford, the nuclear reservation in the State of Washington which has produced plutonium for nuclear weapons for 25 years. This reactor, similar to the Soviet Union's Chernobyl reactor, was closed in December 1986 for a $100m safety upgrade after over 1,200 fuel ruptures in its long history. Many of these ruptures resulted in direct and constant contamination of the nearby Columbia River which flows into the Pacific Ocean, aptly labelled the world's nuclear dustbin. Obviously it is becoming too expensive for power generating companies to comply with the more stringent safeguards being applied in the US.

The New York Times of 11 March carried a fascinating front page story about the decision of the Department of Energy to sharply scale back the amount of radioactive material it plans to bury in its first permanent nuclear waste repository in salt beds in Mexico. This decision followed a warning by scientists that enough water was seeping into the repository to threaten its ability to safely store waste that would remain radioactive for hundreds of thousands of years. What concerns me is that countries such as the US and Japan will be looking for options such as burial of waste at sea or on Pacific islands, or even taking up some of the more crass proposals to bury it in Australia and make a few bucks in the process.

Despite the denials of the Australian Government that Australia would be taking the waste from weapons discarded by the superpowers under the terms of the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement signed in December last year, we should be wary of suggestions that Australia could set up a lucrative billion dollar industry for nuclear waste disposal. This was alluded to just before the meal break by Senator Lewis. By all means let us develop the synroc proposal for waste disposal, if that is the best offer yet for disposing of the world's nuclear waste. How it can be proved safe for the next 24,000 years is another question.

Two other points need to be made about synroc, apart from the fact that it cannot be adequately tested, and has not been adequately tested. The first is that if the technology is useful let us export it. Let us set up the waste disposal plants where the waste is already stockpiled. The waste is dangerous to transport and we do not want it here polluting our environment. Secondly, we should not see the development of synroc-as I said, as yet untried and untested-as a licence or excuse to perpetuate the nuclear industry. We need to get rid of the accumulated waste and stop producing more of it.

I must allude also to the ridiculous proposal already mentioned by the Northern Territory Government that it has a suitable waste disposal site for nuclear toxic waste disposal near Tennant Creek. However, no sooner had the site been designated than there was an earthquake-one of the severest earthquakes recorded in Australian history yet at that very site at Tennant Creek; so much for a geologically stable area. Something else about which I think people need to be aware is the ridiculous proposal put forward by Graeme Campbell, regrettably a member of the Australian Labor Party, who said that in his electorate of Kalgoorlie suitable sites would be available also for the dumping of toxic wastes, including radioactive waste.

I would like to return to some of the international evidence. The number of new reactors outside the United States dropped to 165 in 1986 compared to 178 in 1985, according to the Atomic Industrial Forum spokesman, Don Winston. He cited Mexico and Venezuela as being among those countries that had changed their minds about new plants. He added Turkey as another doubtful country. Prospects for new plants in West Germany are uncertain and there is continuing opposition to plans to bury nuclear waste there. Even France will be scaling down to one new plant a year after opening four plants in 1987. France is cutting back because it is fast approaching the point at which it cannot use more nuclear power for political reasons. In fact, that country actually has a surplus of electricity which it is trying to sell off to its neighbours. What we are probably seeing is the number of new plants declining to about five a year. Around the year 2000 a lot of existing plants will be going out of commission. We will then face a political battle over disposing of these reactors as well as the accumulating waste. At the same time the economic factor will make nuclear power less and less viable.

Nuclear power is particularly irrelevant for Third World countries, few of which have a grid large enough to take the output from a nuclear reactor and where small-scale, local electricity generation would be far more efficient. When we consider that a nuclear reactor can now cost over $US1 billion we realise that any developing country buying one from the industrialised countries will face a massive increase in its interest payments. The Philippines has now discovered this after deciding to pay the bill but not to open the Bataan reactor that was built by the Westinghouse company during the Marcos years. What a great rip-off that was. How environmentally unsound it was to build that reactor on an earthquake fault line. The Aquino Government has seen the wisdom of not opening that reactor but it is still left with the bill-it still has to pay the debt to Westinghouse.

It is this assessment which makes economic sense for the Australian Government to maintain its three-mines uranium policy or, perhaps, even a two-mines policy. If we opened up all the other uranium mines we would only depress the world market even further. There is a glut of uranium on the world market at the moment because of decreasing demand. The same logic applies to Canada which has large reserves of uranium and which will dominate the United States market in years ahead alongside United States domestic production, to the exclusion of Australian imports of uranium. It was never a question of morality, but just of sound economic sense. Of course, I think that the moral argument should be relevant as well but at least we can appeal to some people on economic grounds if we cannot appeal to their moral sensibilities or their environmental concern for future generations.

An interesting article in the Melbourne Age of 11 March by Peter Kellner about a study by Dr J. Gould of the New Jersey Medical School indicated that Chernobyl may have been responsible for the 40,000 extra deaths which occurred between May and August 1986 in the United States. The hypothesis is that radioactivity, even at low, so-called safe levels, generates ionised particles inside the body. These particles are called free radicals and do not have an electrical charge. They are attracted to blood cells that contain an electrical charge. On impact those blood cells are destroyed. Our body's immune system depends on the survival of these cells. Dr Gould and his colleagues are suggesting that Chernobyl's fallout aided the grim reaper by weakening the immune systems of nearly 40,000 more Americans than would normally have died in the given period.

The arguments for and against nuclear power are familiar enough after years of debate but the real issue is a political one, the politics of energy. It is for this reason that I refer to a paper by Amory Lovins published in 1976 in the American Foreign Affairs Quarterly Review. The paper was entitled Energy strategy: The road not taken? In this paper the author, a consultant physicist, presents a choice. It is most important for us to remember that we do have choices about future directions in energy generation. The first path relies on the rapid expansion of centralised high technologies to increase supplies of energy, especially in the form of electricity. The second path represents a serious commitment to efficient use of energy, rapid development of renewable energy resources, matched in scale and energy quality to end-use needs, and special transitional fossil fuel technologies.

The two paths are mutually exclusive, with the second path representing a long term goal and a shift in direction but offering many social, economic and geopolitical advantages, including the virtual elimination of nuclear proliferation from the world. I think that it is worth stressing this last point as we are coming up to the next conference of the countries that belong to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons in 1990, when it is quite possible that it will finally break down.

Although we have been spared the horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons that many of us feared, there are still many nations on the threshold of producing nuclear weapons and, I am quite sure, quite a number that have them unofficially. There are still a number of threshold countries such as Pakistan, Brazil, South Korea perhaps and, of course, Israel and South Africa which already have nuclear weapons. Therefore, we need to be very concerned about possible proliferation. Of course, the link between nuclear power generation and the nuclear weapons industries is absolutely irrefutable.

With 41 countries now developing a nuclear power program obviously this number could increase. Nuclear weapons technology is not complicated. When countries resort to smuggling or stealing the necessary components, as Israel and Pakistan have done in the past, the dangers grow. To those who say that nuclear power is safe, I simply ask them to remember the connections between nuclear power and nuclear weapons as well as the 10- to 30-year period it takes for the cancers to show up after accidents occur. Any increase in radiation is dangerous and we do not know much about the subject, even after 40 years of dealing with nuclear technology. The answers have not been found as to what to do with the waste and no answers have been found as to how to eradicate the cancers which accidents in the nuclear industry cause.

Australia could be a world leader in safe energy if we are prepared to make the choice presented to us by Amory Lovins, both domestically and with regard to the whole question of the mining and export of uranium. A substantial way in which the Australian Labor Party (ALP) could restore some of its lost faith with its traditional supporters is to return to its earlier total opposition to uranium mining. This will certainly be one of the crucial debates at the forthcoming national conference. Unfortunately, there is pressure from my home State for the ALP to continue its electorally disastrous pro-uranium policies. The Western Australian Minister for Minerals and Energy is pushing for a substitution-type three-mines policy-that is, for a new uranium mine to be opened up in Western Australia to replace the Northern Territory Nabarlek mine which has virtually ceased production. So the illogical three-mines, phase-out policy will be further weakened if David Parker has his way with Rudall River opening up in Western Australia. So far Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd has carried out extensive exploratory tests in the region, so the stage is set for licence approval to be given. The project has been described by critics as a triple-headed monster. Uranium mining on Aboriginal land and in a national park is an electoral disaster package, I would think, to which can be added the uncertain state of the nuclear industry worldwide. Surely sense will prevail and delegates to the national conference will knock back the David Parker plan if it is actually put up in that form. It would mean a great deal to traditional Labor Party supporters-and I used to be one of them-to see the Labor Party return to an honourable position on the uranium issue. The only safe place for uranium is in the ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to the substance, if one could euphemistically call it that, of Senator Vallentine's speech later. I note, with sadness, that, after being a member of the Senate for four years, Senator Vallentine still has to read her speech. I would have thought that she would have enough pride to know it by heart now. She has just made the same speech. When she used the phrase `a triple-headed monster', I thought, `Goodness me, I've heard that on many occasions'. Maybe it is the same person or group outside the Parliament who writes her speeches who has a one-track mind. Enough of that; let us turn to the business at hand. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987--
—You are not reading, are you, Senator?

—I have read two speeches in this chamber. The first was my maiden speech and the other was a speech on a very important matter where I had to be particularly precise in what I said. On no other occasion have I read speeches. I obey Standing Orders. The Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 18 September 1987. The Opposition supports it. The purpose of the Bill is to overcome some conflicts between the earlier Bill we passed and the Patents Act 1952. It establishes procedures for handling patent applications which relate to nuclear technology and it ensures compliance with the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987, which was important legislation. The safeguards Act, as it is known-Senator Vallentine and the extremists probably do not recall it; certainly they did not understand it-gave legislative effect to Australia's obligation under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material. It also established a permit system for the possession and transport of nuclear material and created the Australian Safeguards Office to oversee the system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us resolves the conflicts between the Patents Act and the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act. It makes minor amendments to the Patents Act 1952 to ensure that the Patents Office is able to comply with the provisions of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act, without being in breach of the Patents Act in relation to associated technology which is defined as `a document containing information that is primarily applicable to enrichment of nuclear material, reprocessing of irradiated nuclear material, production of heavy water or nuclear weapons, or nuclear information that is covered by an international agreement', is declared as such by the Minister and `is not possessed or communicated without the relevant permit or authority of the Safeguards Office'. The Bill enables the Commissioner of Patents to refer a specification which appears to contain this kind of information to the Director of Safeguards and for the Safeguards Office to check whether the necessary permit and authority to possess and communicate the information has been given. Currently, the officers of the Patents Office, in refusing access to associated technology, could be held to be in breach of the Patents Act. The purpose of this Bill overcomes that anomaly. There are other minor amendments which relate to matters, such as the lapse of patent application, its restoration and confidentiality. As I have said, we support the Bill.

One of the fundamental things that are associated with the whole spirit and content of the Bill is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. That is a very important treaty which Senator Vallentine spent a considerable amount of time abusing. She said repeatedly that safeguards were absolutely worthless and useless. I happen to think, as do most people in this Parliament-not only in the Senate-that the treaty is one of the great achievements of multilateral diplomacy in the postwar world. Certainly, it has its imperfections. It needs constant vigilance and surveillance. It certainly needs improving, but the world today would be a far more dangerous place, and the nuclear world would be far more unpredictable, but for the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

It is all very well for people such as Senator Vallentine and Senator Sanders to rail against the treaty, but they do not come up with any alternative proposition-not a thing. They just want to forget, somehow or other, that nuclear weapons and nuclear powerhouses exist and that the whole vast field of nuclear physics has not been discovered. They want to run away from it in some way and hide under the bed. I am afraid we do not have that option. We have to cope with those difficulties, however severe they may be. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is a very constructive move that most of the nations of the world have agreed to.
