The obligation on us is not to ridicule it, but to take a constructive and creative position, improve and support that treaty. Absolutely no credit can ever be given for what the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty has done. For the benefit of the Senate, I wish to quote, in precise form, what the six articles provide. Article I provides that nuclear weapon states undertake not to transfer nuclear weapons to the control of another country or to assist a non-nuclear weapon state to acquire them. Article II states that non-nuclear weapon states undertake not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or nuclear explosive devices. Article III states:

Non-nuclear weapon States agree to accept IAEA safeguards on all nuclear activities in their territories for the purpose of verifying the terms of Article II. Each member country to require IAEA safeguards on exports of nuclear items to non-nuclear weapon States which are not a party to the NPT.

Article IV affirms the rights of all countries to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes and requires countries in a position to do so to contribute to the development of nuclear energy in member countries. Article V requires each party to undertake to ensure that potential benefits from peaceful applications of nuclear explosions will be made to non-nuclear weapon member states on a non-discriminatory basis and the charge will be as low as possible and exclude research costs. Article VI states that all parties to the treaty undertake to work for a cessation of the nuclear arms race, for nuclear disarmament and ultimately for general and complete disarmament.

Currently, 122 countries are signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Some significant countries are not members. The obligation on us is to encourage all the other countries to join in. The countries that are not signatory to the Treaty which cause concern are France, South Africa, Israel, India, Pakistan and the Argentine. But over three-quarters of the memberships of the United Nations are members of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Some of the criticisms of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty stem from the non-nuclear weapons states which claim that, while they observe their responsibilities under the Treaty, the nuclear weapons states, namely the two super-powers-the Soviet Union and the United States of America-have failed to stop the competition in nuclear weapons. Perhaps the recent intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty and the foreshadowed 50 per cent reduction in strategic nuclear weapons will be a significant reversal of the policy that we have seen up to the present and the spirit of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty will be observed by the two superpowers. But, with all its faults, the Treaty has been of enormous benefit to mankind. Certainly the Opposition-and I am quite sure the Government also-supports the Treaty and wants to see it developed and strengthened.

The other relevant point to this legislation is the report commissioned by the Australian Labor Party and presented in May 1984-the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) report-the so-called Slatyer report. ASTEC was required to look into Australia's role in the nuclear cycle. After an exhaustive examination, it came down with a report which found that Australia should be very significantly involved in the whole of the nuclear cycle. I will quote from a part of the report. ASTEC said that by being involved in the cycle, Australia would be:

able to make a direct contribution to the development of the civil nuclear fuel cycle in ways that will increase global energy security, help to strengthen the elements of the non-proliferation regime and help to reduce the risks of the misuse of civil facilities and the diversion of nuclear materials from civil to military uses.
The report considered that without such involvement:
global energy security would be less assured and our ability to strengthen the non-proliferation regime and to influence future developments in the fuel cycle would be reduced.
The report further said:

We do not wish to exaggerate Australia's role in matters related to the nuclear fuel cycle but, as in most other human endeavours, it is only by active involvement that Australia can expect to be able to influence the future course of events.

The report recommended that Australia should actively encourage `the concept that sensitive facilities, particularly in enrichment and reprocessing plants, should be located in as few countries as possible'. That is a very important point. It gives substance to the arguments advanced by Senator Lewis earlier tonight that we should certainly be exploring the possibility of setting up in this country a nuclear enrichment plant and that we should certainly be looking at the processing of nuclear wastes to find out whether it is feasible and practicable for us to do it. The report went on to say:
Australian participation in stages of the nuclear fuel cycle should be permitted, where such participation promoted and strengthens the Non-Proliferation regime.

I think it is very sad that we do not have a nuclear industry in Australia. We really have no practical involvement in nuclear engineering and, as such, we are denied a whole field of what is very important technology. It is a matter of regret that Lucas Heights has not been expanded and modernised. Above all, I think it is a tragedy that the proposal in the early 1970s to go ahead with a nuclear powerhouse as a training facility at Jervis Bay was abandoned by the governments of the day. We have no practical nuclear engineering capability or experience in this country. As a consequence, our scientific pool of knowledge is diminished in a very important field. It means that commercial sales in the nuclear engineering field are denied Australia because we have no production facilities.

This deficiency impacts upon us even in areas such as defence. I am sure that one of the contributing factors which led to the Royal Australian Navy not considering the purchase of nuclear-powered submarines as opposed to nuclear-armed submarines, which were never under consideration, was the fact that it felt that we could not go ahead with such a purchase without a nuclear engineering base in this country. So we are now committed to one of the most expensive projects ever in this country, a project which will probably cost us over $6 billion for a collection of six quite antique diesel-electric powered submarines by the end of the 1990s. This will happen in part because we do not have the support facilities for nuclear powered submarines.

The Luddites, of course, rejoice in this. They think it is good that coalminers can die in their hundreds and thousands hewing coal in underground mines. They carry on about environmental issues. But they do not worry about the carcinogens that are pouring into the air, the lung cancer cases who are dying every day from epithelial carcinomas. They do not worry about the smog in the air, the pollution of the fabrics, the death of the forests and all the rest of it. They do not worry about the bare hillsides in India and Africa where people chop down every tree for firewood. I am reminded of a talk I had a couple of years ago with some friends whose life-long wish was to see the Taj Mahal in India in the moonlight. So they planned a trip to India. But when they went to the Taj Mahal on a moonlit night, they could not see it for the smog which was caused by the burning cowdung fires of the Indians living around it. Very severe environmental problems arise from persisting with thermal generation of power using fossil fuels which are so beloved by the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmers.

We saw the absolute intellectual vapidity of Senator Vallentine when she said in her speech that the answer to our energy problems is small-scale electrical generating facilities. What are those small-scale electrical generating facilities going to burn? Are they going to burn liquid hydrocarbons like oil, or are they going to burn solid coal? Does the Australian Democrats' approach of banning nuclear power as a clean and environmentally safe source of electricity mean that they want everyone in the world to be running around barefoot and pregnant, as serfs and slaves? It is all very well for them to want that, but the selfishness of these people is striking. So long as they are warm at night, well-dressed, living in houses in which the roofs do not leak, are well fed and all the rest of it, they do not care at all about the rest of the world. They are not concerned about the problems of the Third World countries. They are not concerned about countries that do not have natural resources that can be burnt up. That is beyond their pale and certainly beyond their conscience.

But that cannot be the view that the world takes. The world needs energy. It needs energy to feed and clothe its people and to produce the goods that a modern society requires. We simply just cannot proceed down the path of burning up fossil fuels and turning this whole globe into a massive garbage heap. At present nuclear energy has a most important place in the quest for alternative energy sources. It has a minor place but a most important place-a place for which there is no substitute at present.

The case of the opponents of this Bill rests on two assertions. The first is that somehow or other Australia has a monopoly on the supply of uranium. The second assertion implicit in all of this is that somehow or other what Australia is doing is creating huge stockpiles of nuclear weapons around the world. I would like to deal with the first proposition that Australia has a monopoly on uranium. Nothing could be further from the truth. But we do have very considerable supplies of low-cost uranium. We should be using those for the benefit of mankind, not sitting on them and denying them to world markets. In fact, we are probably obliged to supply countries which have safeguards under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. In the extreme case if a country wants uranium, as Japan and Britain demonstrated in the early 1960s, it can extract it from sea water.

Uranium deposits exist in most countries. My argument is that Australia should sell as much uranium as it can in order to have an influence on the use of uranium throughout the world and for the benefit of the Australian economy. It is estimated that we have uranium reserves of 530,000 tonnes-those are the 1985 figures-representing 28 per cent of the known Western world's low cost uranium which is defined as uranium costing less than $30 per pound. But we do not have a monopoly on that. Although we have 28 per cent, Canada has 17 per cent, South Africa has 11 per cent, Brazil has 10 per cent, Nigeria has 9 per cent, the United States of America has 8 per cent and Namibia has 7 per cent.

This Government's embargo on uranium mining restricts production to three mines. Somehow or other we get good uranium from those three mines, but we cannot develop any further mines because that is bad uranium. One day the Australian Labor Party will overcome its schizophrenia on this point and realise that all uranium is the same and that Australia should be competing for as much of the market share as it can get. In 1985 Australian uranium exports totalled 3,500 tonnes worth $400m to the economy. That represented 10 per cent of the fuel for the world's 350 operating nuclear power stations. But in comparison, Canada produced more than 11,000 tonnes-more than three times the uranium we produced-and supplied 31 per cent of fuel to the world's nuclear power stations. I am not one of those who believe that there is a great and expanding market for uranium in the years ahead. I simply do not have enough information to make an accurate market projection of what might exist in the 1990s and I tend to discount the figures that come up from time to time which talk about a doubling or a trebling of the world market for uranium. Rather, my argument would be that irrespective of what the market is in total terms, Australia should be looking to double or treble its share of the trade. With the easily extractable uranium and low costs involved in Australia-particularly with the deposits in the Northern Territory-we should be seeking a far greater share of the existing world markets than we have at present.

As well as getting a larger share of the markets, I believe that we must be in the enrichment of uranium as a fuel source for nuclear power generation. Senator Lewis dealt with this point quite well in his speech earlier tonight. But there is a world of difference between enrichment to 3 per cent for a nuclear fuel and the enrichment to 90 per cent of weapons grade material. Although the distinction between the two is enormous in simple terms-between 3 per cent and 90 per cent-it is quite blurred by the opponents of the nuclear industry. We export yellowcake, which is uranium 238 which has with it about 0.7 per cent of uranium 235, a fissile material. The enrichment which takes place enriches the uranium-the 0.7 per cent uranium 235-to a 3 per cent uranium 235 fraction as a fuel for nuclear power houses. That is done either by a gaseous diffusion process or an ultra centrifuge technique. That is done in only a few countries because of the really huge capital costs involved in setting up the plant.

The gaseous diffusion technique, which was developed during the Second World War, provided the first material for the early atom bombs. The ultra centrifuge technique was developed later, but both techniques are characterised by massive capital involvement in plant. The techniques require big plant, are horrendously expensive and have huge energy demands. The electrical energy required to run one of those plants would probably be equivalent to that of a moderately sized city. It is a very big business to get into. I would not suggest that Australia go ahead with this technology, although there is a proposal to set up a plant in the Northern Territory. It seems to me that this plant will be a development of one of those two existing technologies. I doubt that it is an economic proposition for us, in Australia, to go down that path. Furthermore, if the capital could be raised the construction time would be about 10 or 15 years which I think is too long.

The existing techniques of gaseous diffusion and ultra centrifuge are now reaching the end of their economic lives and the uranium industry around the world is looking to new technology. There is the possibility of new technology at hand through laser enrichment. This has already been successfully done at Lawrence Livermore and other research units in the United States of America. This could have very great benefits to us because the unit size that one can start with is a magnitude less than the old techniques and the capital cost in building similarly is a magnitude less-probably one hundredth less-than the old techniques. More importantly, the electrical energy demands to run the plants are very much less. They are moderate and, from that point of view, comparable to running an ordinary factory. The opportunity for Australia is very real. We should grasp this in our hands; see if we can make this technology work and go down the path of uranium enrichment for two very good reasons.

First of all, the Australian Science and Technology Council report made a point about having enrichment facilities in few hands and in stable political countries. This is a very real need to control the enrichment process. Secondly, the value added aspect of putting yellowcake through to the fuel stage-the 3 per cent enriched stage-is very real. Instead of earning $450m or $500m from the sale of yellowcake, if we were selling fuel for a nuclear power house we would probably be earning $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion with very little expenditure on it if this laser technique worked. Given our huge balance of payments problem at present-we are going broke at an enormous rate-we are simply not in a position to neglect any opportunity to earn income, particularly the sizeable amounts of income that the opportunity of uranium enrichment provides. But more important than the money is the fact that this would give us a very influential position in the nuclear fuel cycle. It does not matter what the Luddites say, the nuclear fuel cycle will not go away. We have to cope with the difficulties involved. We have to have the intellectual resources and the character to stand up to those problems and dominate them, not be dominated by them.

In conclusion, I return to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill. I believe that it aids the nuclear industry in Australia although the nuclear industry in Australia requires far wider support than this Bill provides and, indeed, than the Government has the intention of providing. The nuclear industry is undoubtedly a matter of the greatest importance for the human race. It requires an enormous amount of effort and concentration to control and to make sure that things do not go wrong. I argue very strongly that we cannot opt out in the way that the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmers want. I do not know how one can unlearn nuclear physics. I suppose if one has a mind like some of them, nothing ever goes in, but the store of knowledge in the human race simply cannot be dispensed with. We have to cope with this problem. The legislative steps in individual parliaments in some of the countries around the world and agreements such as the Treaty on the Non-proliferation of Nuclear Weapons are a very significant starting point. Rather than trying to undo what cannot be undone, we would all be very much better off if we tackled the problems square on and constructively tried to make them work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I have to support the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill but I really do not believe it provides any guarantees of safeguards. In reality, we are only closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. Australia has signed a string of safeguards agreements with those countries that buy our uranium. They are intended to operate in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Authority (IAEA) and the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT). But safeguards are just a comfortable illusion, because Australian safeguards are supposed to prevent a customer country from reselling Australian uranium to a third country which is not a non-proliferation treaty signatory. These safeguards have not prevented France, the United States of America or Germany from importing Australian uranium so that it effectively replaces the uranium they export to non-signatory countries or, in the case of France, the uranium it uses in its own weapons program.

SPEECH.PARA: NPT safeguards apply only to nuclear weapons. They cannot guarantee, for example, that Australian uranium, once sold to another country, will not be resold as fuel for nuclear powered ships and submarines which may also carry nuclear weapons. The additional Australian safeguards which have been instigated provide only an illusion of security and are no more effective than the non-proliferation treaty itself.

Basically, the Government knows it cannot monitor the safeguards it seeks to impose. If it wishes to attract buyers for its exports-and this is the key-it is not in a position to impose too many demands. Most of the problems surrounding the monitoring of the world's nuclear materials trade rest with the IAEA. Its charter is both to monitor and to control as well as to promote the nuclear industry. That is an obvious conflict of interests. How can one monitor and control if one is also promoting the industry? For example, when a ship carrying 200 tonnes of uranium disappeared during transit only to turn up, later in Israel, it took 15 years, until 1983, for the public to find out because Euratom kept the documents classified.

The IAEA attempts to monitor declared inputs and outputs of nuclear plants from which it calculates amounts of nuclear material unaccounted for. These amounts are often so small that they are either missed through measurement or error, or simply not looked for. According to the Ranger inquiry the IAEA would be unlikely to look for a diversion if a discrepancy was less than 0.5 per cent. The IAEA inspects plants very infrequently-only a few times a year-and this leaves ample time for covert activity. Not only that, but it gives warning when it is coming. It calls `Cooee, we are on our way'. What sort of safeguard is that? What sort of inspection is that?

In 1978 the United States General Accounting Office found excessive discrepancies in inventories of enriched uranium and plutonium at three United States plants. In 1979, nine kilograms of enriched uranium were lost to a plant run by Nuclear Fuel Services Inc. in Erwin, Tennessee. In 1980 the General Accounting Office revealed that between 1955 and 1978 Dupont's Savannah River plutonium plant lost 145.5 kilograms of plutonium-enough to manufacture 20 nuclear weapons.

Despite the sorry history of monitoring discrepancies, the Government continues to assure us that international safeguards are effective. In January this year, the day after the German allegations that in 1985 and 1986 the IAEA lost fissile material sufficient to make 250 nuclear bombs, our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in an effort to defuse public concern over new contracts to France, publicly stated his confidence in the IAEA's ability effectively to monitor nuclear transactions.

The nuclear fuel cycle, by its very nature, proliferates more nuclear fuel and more nuclear waste. Each year it creates more fissionable material which the safeguard systems cannot adequately control and which technology cannot dispose of. Controlling this industry presents similar problems to that of controlling the illegal drug trade. It takes only six kilograms of plutonium to build a bomb.

In recent weeks there has been much debate in this chamber about revelations by Der Spiegel about allegations by members of the European Parliament of label swaps of unenrichable American uranium with Australian origin uranium so that Australian uranium could be enriched to weapons grade in contravention of Australian safeguards agreements with Euratom. The allegations suggest that the exchange was not merely flag swapping but involved different consignments-different in levels of enrichment and chemical composition. We have received ministerial assurances that no illegality has occurred, but on what basis? It was on the say-so of the alleged conspirators. When asked by a reporter on 15 March how the Australian Safeguards Office could be sure that Australian uranium had not been enriched to weapons grade, the Director of Safeguards, Frank Bett, stated that those allegedly involved-that is, Euratom, Nukem and others-had given that advice. They were asked, `Did you do anything illegal?' and they said, `Oh, no' and that is enough for Frank Bett and the Australian Safeguards Office. What sort of an investigation is that, where one asks people suspected of a crime, `Did you commit the crime?'; they say, `No, we did not' and they are taken at their word. It seems that safeguards agreements amount to no more than a matter of trust. In the uranium industry we need a great deal more than that.

Apparently satisfied with the safeguards system, the economic rationalists of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and the Opposition are currently arguing that Australia can go a long way towards solving its balance of payments problems by expanding uranium beyond the three mines policy. This argument was used to justify massive violations of ALP policy both in August 1986, in allowing Queensland Mines Ltd to export Nabarlek uranium to France, and the recent decision to allow Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) to conclude a contract of undisclosed size at an undisclosed price with the French Government owned Cogema firm. The Australian public still has not been informed of the price for which ERA and the Australian Government sold out ALP policy. In selling to France the Australian Government gives tacit support to the expansion of the French nuclear arsenal, which is amongst the greatest threat to prospects for nuclear disarmament. Our safeguards arrangements with France are meaningless since Australian uranium is mixed with that from other countries and becomes untraceable-merely a bookkeeping exercise. When is Australian uranium not Australian uranium? When it has a French Flag, a United States flag or some other flag on it. When is nuclear waste and tailings Australian uranium? When the American flag is taken off it and an Australian flag is put on.
If one wants to take the economic rationalists' argument as to why we should export uranium, why do we not export heroin?

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Why not? If one wants an economic rationalist argument, it would be a very profitable exercise. Tasmania grows opium poppies for use in medical drugs-codeine and other things. Why not expand that primary resource and export heroin around the world? There is a great demand for babies in the United States. Why not export babies? The simple argument is that it is an ethical not an economic question. In my view, the question of whether we should export uranium has nothing to do with economic rationalism, but more with the ethics of what we are creating.

SPEECH.PARA: Our exports go to France and the French civilian and military fuel chains are inseparable. This is the whole point of nuclear energy and it is the whole point about the ethical argument. One cannot divorce nuclear power generation from nuclear weapons production. As I have said, the French civilian and military fuel chains are inseparable. Between 16 and 20 of them have dual functions. At least one of these, the Tricastin enrichment plant, has processed Australian uranium. Tricastin pre-enriches uranium before it reaches the Pierrelatte plant of enrichment to weapons grade. Senator Gareth Evans wrongly denied the involvement of Australian uranium when he stated in 1986 that Tricastin was entirely a civil plant. He was wrong. Sir John Hill, a former chairman of the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Commission, roundly denounced the notion of a civil atom versus a military atom. One cannot divorce nuclear power generation from nuclear weapons production.

If one wants to look further at our client, France, France supplied the reactor, the reprocessing plant and the weapons design information with which Israel has built up to 200 nuclear weapons. We might remember that today Mordecai Vanunu was found guilty of treason for doing the world a service and informing us of the nuclearisation of Israel. France has pledged to build a 900-megawatt power reactor for Pakistan, when no other country would. France assisted South Africa to build an enrichment plant. It is helping to supply related technology to Iraq, Iran, South Korea and China. India, Pakistan and Israel all refused to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. I am sure that Senator Sanders will have more to say on France, the nuclear renegade. France is actively assisting proliferation, which today occurs primarily via civilian nuclear industries. A former Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Fred Ilke, said:

Today the speed of nuclear weapons capability is riding on the wave of peaceful uses of the atom . . . now it is peaceful technology that provides not only the means, but also the cover, in all cases where we fear that a new nuclear weapons program might be on the way.

Subtle diversions of nuclear materials can come from Australian uranium initially provided for nuclear power. There is increasing evidence that the existing nuclear armed countries either have or are using their stockpiles of waste from commercial nuclear reactors as the basis for weapons construction. French analysts have suggested that there will in future be a shortfall in the plutonium needed for presently planned new missiles and for the construction of miniaturised and neutron bombs. It is likely that the plutonium which will be bred in the new commercial Superphenix prototype fast-breeder reactor, which produces plutonium-239 and uranium-238, will be used in the French weapons program. The 1982 report of the French Government's supervising council on nuclear safety refers explicitly to the:
possibility with the fast breeders of producing important quantities of plutonium of excellent military quality.

According to a Dutch energy analyst from the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists 1985, Australia has agreed to an arrangement with the French which allows the Superphenix to be used for military purposes, even if it contains fuel of Australian origin. This is in violation of our safeguards agreements and makes a mockery of the system. It is also useful to note that 160 tonnes of Australian-origin uranium tailings are currently stored in France and may be used as breeder elements for the Superphenix.

We have heard a little about the world demand for uranium and uranium exports. We might examine world demand. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the International Atomic Energy Agency predict a global shortage of uranium by the end of the century. Though I do not agree with this assessment of the figures, many who advocate the expansion of our uranium industry do. Assuming for the moment that they are correct in their belief, an Australian decision to ban uranium exports would therefore be effective in influencing French nuclear policy.

A more accurate assessment of world demand is that argued by the recent Friends of the Earth (FOE) Greenpeace report and that of Chas Collison and the honourable member for La Trobe, Peter Milton. Not only is the demand for uranium declining, but in the wake of Chernobyl and Three Mile Island public opposition to the nuclear industry is growing. More than half the French population is opposed to the construction of new nuclear plants, the Swedish Government is phasing out its nuclear power program, and the Italians are putting a brake on theirs. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) has abandoned the construction of a nuclear power plant near Krasnodar and West Germany has cancelled orders for four reactors. In addition, moves towards protectionist legislation in the United States may well eliminate the United States as a market for foreign uranium as American producers seek to ensure their own survival. I think that the wheat farmers can identify with that. The Chief Executive of ERA, Peter Bradfield, admitted in October 1987 that export sales are increasingly difficult to obtain.

France has 30,000 tonnes of uranium stockpiled and is certainly not in need of Australian uranium for civil purposes. This was confirmed most arrogantly by the French Defence Minister, Monsieur Giraud, on his recent visit to Australia. As indicated by the FOE Greenpeace report the Minister's statement of August 1987, suggesting that Australia could potentially supply 25 per cent of French uranium needs, clearly is a vast overstatement. In a shrinking world market Australia would, in order to compete with Canada, have either to lower its floor price or compromise its safeguards policies still further-it has already done that. Floor prices are not of great concern to the Opposition. In fact, the Opposition's uranium policy involves phasing out floor price controls. This would have the effect of creating an even less responsible, indeed less safe, world uranium market. There are a number of suppliers of unsafeguarded uranium around the world-Third World countries such as South Africa, Namibia and Niger. Their major customers are West Germany, Britain, France, Japan, Spain, Italy and Taiwan. If Australia were to sell to those buyers at cheaper prices, we would place the Third World suppliers in the dilemma either of finding other customers or of losing valuable foreign currency. The President of Niger has said that he would sell uranium to the devil.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would sell a lot of other things too, even his grandmother.

—Cheap Australian uranium exports only increase the chance of this by denying the Third World its present customers. Senator Stone was right to say that the President of Niger would sell a lot of other things, too. So would senators in this place who are not concerned about the effects of things we export. Uranium is one example of a destructive export which we should not be exporting. Australian exports to France are clearly unnecessary for that country's power needs, and hence are only valuable to the French in expanding their nuclear weapons stockpile. Australian contracts make a mockery of Australian protestations about Pacific testing and French regional policy when, in effect, we supply the raw material for such tests. Australia is exporting uranium at a time when we should be placing maximum pressure on the French whose nuclear expansion program may well inhibit the chances of more extensive arms reductions between the United States and the USSR. French intransigence over cutbacks to her independent nuclear deterrence force stands in the way of more meaningful superpower negotiations.

SPEECH.PARA: As if the current abrogation of the Australian Labor Party platform on nuclear issues were not sufficient, in recent weeks we have seen proposals for the development of another Australian nuclear waste dump industry-yet another gross example of economic rationalism and political pragmatism. The Government recognised the political danger of the issue and, consequently, we saw denials that the industry would be established in Australia. But what followed were suggestions that we export the Synroc technology to some Third World country-I think the Sudan was mentioned-and so gain the economic advantages of the technology without the risks, whether they be environmental, health or political risks. Synroc technology may provide some sort of answer to the waste disposal problem, but the question remains as to its ability to contain waste for the enormous lengths of time required and under the geological and climatic changes which may occur during that time. Synroc is a product that we cannot adequately trial.

What are we asking this technology to do? We are asking it to store nuclear waste longer than the human race has existed. Caesium 135, for instance, has a half-life of three million years, iodine has a half-life of 17 million years and neptunium has a half-life of two million years. At that rate by the time, say, iodine 129 has reached its half-life, Australia will have moved 170 kilometres to the north-west. The whole continent will have shifted because of the changing geology of the earth. Yet we expect somehow or other to create a technology which will survive that time, survive that geological change and keep nuclear waste safe.

The history of Australian uranium mining does not inspire confidence. Of course, we have to ask the obvious question. For whom and for what purposes do we want to enrich uranium? Aside from the serious environmental risks associated with such an industry there are incredible civil rights risks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator MacGibbon laughs but we have only to look at legislation that was repealed last year by the current Government-three cheers for that bit of sense. Legislative provisions were enacted in the 1970s to protect the Australian uranium mining industry under the Atomic Energy Act and the associated Approved Defence Projects Protection Act. Under that legislation it was possible for any person who boycotted, threatened to boycott, hindered or obstructed uranium mining or who advocated in speech or in writing the hindrance of uranium mining, to be fined $10,000 and gaoled for 12 months. Ancillary legislation provides for prison sentences of up to 20 years for the communication of restricted information. That legislation was repealed only last year by this Government. If it had to go to that extent to protect the natural uranium product, to what extent would it be prepared to enact draconian supervision of the civilian population to protect plutonium?

SPEECH.PARA: The only real and effective way to control Australian uranium mining and to ensure that it is safe is, quite obviously, to leave it in the ground. There is no such thing as the peaceful atom-ask the remaining inhabitants of Chernobyl, those who live in the vicinity of the Windscale plant or Three Mile Island, or those who are currently threatened by nuclear weapons developed from so-called civilian power technologies. We cannot guarantee that the nuclear fuel cycle is safe at any point and we have demonstrably failed to control the nuclear Frankensteins we have created. The only way to safeguard Australian uranium effectively and to state unambiguously to the rest of the world that we believe that the threat posed by the proliferation of nuclear weapons is intolerable and that we are not prepared to participate in the growth of the nuclear fuel cycle is to stop the mining and export of uranium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. As Senator MacGibbon has indicated, we do not oppose this legislation. We have just heard-and I expect that more will follow me-one of the greatest heaps of garbage in this chamber. When Senator Wood first came to the Senate I was prepared to excuse him for some of the way-out ideas he had because I thought he was young and I thought someone had put him behind some bright lights and brainwashed him. I have since found out that he is not young-he is close to 40 years of age-although he looks young, so it probably means that he has a pretty quiet life. I make those remarks because probably the greatest problem that honourable senators have, not just on this side of the chamber, but also on the other side of the chamber is in counteracting what I believe is gross misinformation. I would not mind if I believed that the people to whom I am referring in this chamber were genuine. But they cannot be genuine and sensible at the same time because they are so illogical. If Senator Wood really believed what he said I would respect him, but I do not think he does or, if he does, somehow he has been poisoned by people who have a different agenda from the rest of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, we do not oppose the legislation. Because I expected this sort of debate tonight I believe it is proper to take this opportunity to correct much of the misinformation peddled around this country by quite irresponsible people about both uranium mining and the use of uranium. It is not that I do not know a little about radioactivity because, for the first 10 years of my working life, I had daily exposure either to X-rays or radioactive materials. In fact, they were used for both medical and industrial purposes and to good effect.

We have to understand that, something that people cannot see or feel will create emotion and a fear of the unknown. It is not too different from when electricity was first brought into England. People were concerned. The same sorts of people who are making noises about uranium today and its beneficial uses, made the same noises about electricity. People were warned, `Do not turn the light on. Do not leave it on at night. Something dreadful might happen to you. You will get a disease'. That was the sort of thing that happened in those days. I suppose that the only remark I can make is that people do not change.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are still getting the same thing in relation to power lines. It is exactly the same syndrome.

—It is. Even though we have many responsible Ministers on the Labor side who would agree with this attitude there is little or no evidence of it. My concern is that no attempt is being made by the Government to correct the gross and irresponsible misinformation which is being peddled. By not correcting or attempting to correct that the Government is doing itself and this country a great disservice.

SPEECH.PARA: Many countries are not as blessed as we are with natural energy resources. We have huge coal reserves. With the exception of a few hydro stations-which the Australian Democrats would shut down anyway, if they had a chance-all our electric power is generated by means of steaming coal. We burn hydrocarbons. In addition, millions of tonnes of steaming coal are exported for power generation overseas. The reason we are able to export is that we are also fortunate in that, compared with Northern Hemisphere coals, our coal is low in sulphur, which is of great benefit to those countries which are using steaming coal to generate electricity and which are concerned about acid rain. That is one of the benefits of our coal and it is one of the reasons why we sell it.

Prior to the first oil crisis in the early 1970s, a lot of power was generated in Europe and Asia with oil. The oil shock changed all that, because prices rose considerably. The reason why oil was used in the first place was that it was easy to handle and it was cheap. Everyone will remember that first oil crisis. Bear in mind that we are talking of countries that do not have energy resources of their own. In their position, one has to ask what we would do. They were forced to look to alternative energy sources.

Burning oil to generate power is akin to putting mahogany in one's fireplace. It is a great shame that 25 per cent of all oil supplied is still used to generate electricity throughout the world. That is a great misuse of a very limited resource. So the alternative resources available to those countries which were caught up in the oil shock and which were reliant on oil were coal, uranium, or hydro. As we all know, hydro-electric power can be generated only where a country has the natural facilities to do that-that is, if it does not have people like Senator Sanders stopping it from doing that. So for such countries the alternative, therefore, becomes coal or uranium.

Because conversion to coal from oil required much less capital and, hence, less consumer cost, it was to Australia's benefit to export coal. Many countries, particularly South East Asian countries, moved very quickly into coal generation. For new power stations, however, resource poor countries also looked to uranium as a reliable and clean method of generating power. The technology was already developed. For instance, there had been a nuclear power station, to my knowledge, operating at Dounreay in the United Kingdom since about 1960.

TALK.START.PARA: —Calder Hall in 1956.
—Thank you, Senator; you are right.
—It was first built to make nuclear weapons, though.

—I thought that Calder Hall was built to pump water up a hill to run a hydro down the hill, but we will debate that later. From an energy point of view, 3,000 tonnes of enriched uranium is equivalent to about 30 million tonnes of coal. I ask honourable senators to put themselves in the position of an energy poor country. I can recall this matter being debated 10 years ago, when people were making noises similar to the funny noises that Senator Sanders has been making, saying to me, `Have you noticed that the countries which want uranium for generating power are the evil sorts of countries?' I asked for some examples. Every example given was of a country short of indigenous energy resources.

SPEECH.PARA: So such countries have to make a decision. The Republic of Korea is a wonderful example. It had the choice, with its own projections, if it wanted to go nuclear, of 3,000 tonnes of enriched uranium as against 30 million tonnes of coal. Why not go for coal, it is said. One can store 10 years supply with a small stockpile-30,000 tonnes. I think that that is the figure that Senator Wood used about France. A lot of energy is stored up in that 30,000 tonnes. But 3,000 tonnes is equal to 30 million tonnes of coal. Just think of the logistics: the stockpiling, the concern, and the lack of reliability on the part of countries in which unions such as those in Australia hold back the ships. What government will make the irresponsible decision of going into something from which one day the people who live in its country cannot get heat, cannot cook their food, and cannot get a light to come on when they turn a switch, simply because of a breakdown in the chain of 30 million tonnes per year. So the advantages of shipping, handling and stockpiling uranium as compared with coal are patently obvious.

I can recall-I think Senator MacGibbon referred to this-serious consideration being given in Australia in the early 1970s to a nuclear power station being built at Jervis Bay, just to keep abreast of technology.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, for nuclear weapons.
—No, I am sorry, Senator Coulter.
—Absolute nonsense.
—Thank you. That was not the reason. It was to keep abreast of technology. We were, after all, blessed with our own uranium resources, and we were poised to be a major supplier to the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry has grown so that it is entrenched throughout the world. I have heard all the stories about not going ahead with one or cutting back on another. Let me give a few examples.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industry says that it will phase itself out in a hundred years.

—It might in 100 years because power will probably be generated from hydrogen by then-from water. I give a few examples. The United States has 103 units and generates 16.6 per cent of its electricity by nuclear methods. France, about which Senator Wood spoke, has 49 units and generates 70 per cent of its electricity by nuclear methods. I will just touch further on France. The use of nuclear energy for the generation of power is terribly important to France. What are the economic alternatives for France? It is not a matter of us sitting here and saying that we are economic rationalists, and that we want to sell our uranium to France at whatever price. The point is that there is a demand there for it, and we are not supplying anything like it. We supply a very small part; I will come to that later. But the French generate 70 per cent of their electricity in nuclear power stations.
—They have the reputation of being the dirtiest operators in the world.

—I suppose that as we go through every country, Senator Sanders will say that they are equally dirty operators. Japan has 38 units and generates 25 per cent of its power from nuclear energy. The Federal Republic of Germany generates 29.5 per cent of its power in this way; Canada, 14.7 per cent; the United Kingdom, close to 19 per cent; Sweden, 50 per cent; Spain, 29.4 per cent; Belgium, 67 per cent; and the Republic of Korea, 40 per cent and growing-and for the reasons I mentioned as to why a country such as Korea would go nuclear.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for us to sit in a big country that is rich in energy resources and be able to have a choice. Some countries do not have a choice. They must make decisions based on the most economic course they can take, bearing in mind the safety measures associated with it. Twenty-six countries are generating power by nuclear methods. Such power generation is here to stay, yet the rubbish that our young people are being fed is such that they are convinced-and those who get involved in this matter are playing on this, and they know it-that every pound of uranium mined in Australia goes to make a bomb. That is because that sort of stuff is being peddled quite dishonestly by people such as Senator Sanders.

I do not mind if they have genuine views on these matters, but when they peddle that stuff to our young people and the young believe it, they are doing a disservice not only to themselves but to the country as a whole. It is the most dishonest of propaganda, peddled by people who should know better simply for short term political gains without any concern about what the future of this country will be, or more importantly, the demands of people overseas who want to have electricity so that they can turn a switch and get a light to come on at a price that they can afford. It might suit the people I have mentioned, for their own political purposes, to play on the emotions of many genuine people, but, as I have said, in the process they are doing our country a great disservice.

We are all opposed to the spread of nuclear weapons and support any moves to reduce the level of nuclear weaponry throughout the world on a multilateral basis. Sources of uranium are readily available throughout the world. As Senator Wood mentioned, the French Minister for Defence said recently that if Australia did not want to supply uranium to France, that was fine; France can obtain it from many other countries. And so it can.

Let us look at the estimated reserves of uranium in various parts of the world. Seventy per cent of uranium is in Australia, Niger, South Africa and Canada. Australia has about 29 per cent. I believe that these figures are calculated on an $80 a pound cut-off cost of mining, though the price is lower today. Niger has 18.7 per cent, South Africa 14.3 per cent, Canada 10.6 per cent, Brazil 7.1 per cent, the United States of America 5.4 per cent, Namibia 5.4 per cent, and the rest of the countries outside the communist bloc have 9.5 per cent. It is worth comparing Australia with Canada. Australia has 30 per cent of the world's uranium reserves within the parameter I mentioned; and we supply 10 per cent of the world market. Canada has 10 per cent of the uranium reserves and supplies 30 per cent of the world market.

Uranium for the generation of electricity has been supplied for a long time. That supply has grown substantially and is here to stay. Already it earns Australia substantial export income, and has the potential to more than double that income. I know that people such as Chas Collison, whoever he is, and Mr Peter Milton, the Federal member for La Trobe, have put out a background paper for the delegates to the 1988 Australian Labor Party National Conference on what they call uranium mining market prospects and environmental consequences. I never cease to be amazed by instant experts who come along with a young researcher, do a bit of work and become marketing experts and forecasters of supply and demand about anything; the particular product does not matter.

I can recall in the 1970s, in the era of Whitlam and Connor, that the Labor Government of the day said, in its wisdom, that the world was oversupplied with coal; it would not allow any more new mines. I can remember the late Mr Connor saying, `We will not allow any more mines; just dig a little deeper'. That problem boiled to the surface. When Whitlam was thrown out, something like seven, eight or nine new mines commenced, each producing between 3 million and 4 million tonnes a year. Now people are saying that they were right, there is an oversupply of about 1 million or 2 million tonnes a year. However, production has increased by between 40 million and 50 million tonnes and there is oversupply of only 1 million or 2 million tonnes. Such people are in no position to determine the world demand for any commodity.

I return to uranium. The factor that will decide whether we will sell an extra kilogram or an extra tonne of uranium will be the market. If there is no market, no-one will build a mine. However, when one listens to people such as Senator Wood, they give the impression that Australians are selling uranium. We are not. The individual mines have to try to find their markets.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a market for heroin. Does that make it right?

—Those who have already found a market will not give it up lightly. Neither can someone now come in and build a mine and supply uranium to a market at a lower price than is already being paid, because the current capital costs are higher. They are simple facts, but I emphasise that governments and politicians are in no position to judge the market for any commodity.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Wood referred to heroin and asked why we do not export heroin. I am amazed that he would even make that comparison. This is not economic rationality. Heroin is one of the worst drugs that has ever been perpetrated on young people. Uranium is used to generate electricity in resource poor countries. If any honourable senator or anyone else can suggest an alternative that is cleaner, cheaper and more reliable he should suggest it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the waste?

—Senator Wood should go to those countries and tell them. If he can convince them, we would be delighted to go along with him. Another source of nuclear power is hydrogen from the hydrogen atom. It is abundant and exists in water. Eventually, with the development of technology, a method will be developed to control the splitting of the hydrogen atom. When that occurs nuclear energy will be available to any country in the world without having to worry about the importation of uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not oppose the Bill. However, I ask the Government to correct the quite misleading information which has been spread by quite dishonest people around Australia, and to get the message through that our uranium is supplied to countries that generate electricity from nuclear power stations. That technology is here to stay and it will grow with improved technology. Australia has the uranium and also has an obligation to supply it to those countries that require it for peaceful purposes. If we are to get the benefit of value added we must look at uranium enrichment, and the sooner the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a lot of allegations about nuclear power. However, I should like to address myself to the Bill. We are discussing the Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. The original Nuclear Non-proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 prohibited the communication or processing of information applicable to enrichment, reprocessing, heavy water production, nuclear weapons production or other matters without a permit. In other words, one can distribute design information on nuclear weapons if the Minister allows.

SPEECH.PARA: Because a patent application could communicate some of the information covered by the original Act, this Bill amends the Patents Act 1952 so that the Australian Safeguards Office can issue or deny permits for patent applications dealing with enrichment, reprocessing and so on. It should be illegal to distribute information on nuclear weapon production, reprocessing or heavy water production under any circumstances. Information on enrichment to greater than 20 per cent uranium 235 should also be banned, given that non-proliferation is the objective of the Bill. However, the original Act is the place in which this should be done.

We still wonder why the Government wishes to leave these options open. So we support the Bill. We believe that the Bill is a necessary adjunct to the existing legislation if the Government wishes to continue down this track. But of course we do not in any way approve of the use of uranium. In that instance at least, honourable senators who have contributed to this debate have portrayed the Australian Democrats' position quite accurately. We do not believe that uranium should be mined. It should not be milled, processed or enriched. It should be left in the ground. We have heard a number of statements about safeguards. Senator Lewis said there are no problems with safeguards on shipments of uranium. We heard a number of honourable senators say that uranium is clean, safe power. I wonder why they so vehemently support nuclear power. I wonder if that is because if they do not support it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Another conspiracy.

—Here is Senator Stone. I wonder whether Senator Stone really has any qualifications. He apparently is an economist. Economists are those who throw the entrails of animals upon the ground and interpret them. Then they take us down some path or other. They also follow the stockmarket. They do not lead it; they follow it, and tell us that we will have a bull market or a bear market. However, they do not seem to have any real expertise. Therefore it will be interesting to see what, if anything, Senator Stone will contribute to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have this technology worship by uneducated people, people who perhaps have not had the opportunity to understand the real world. Theirs is a worship of technology to save us from ourselves so that we can continue to sell whatever we wish to sell, in whatever quantity, however dangerous it may be to the environment or to our ourselves, and then ask technology to solve our problems. I think that that basically is the plea of the apologists for the nuclear power industry. They say that somehow technology will solve the problems of waste and of the dangers of radiation; in fact, solve the problems of the inefficiencies of the nuclear power plants themselves. They want to believe in progress. They want to believe in technology, otherwise they will have to accept responsibility for their actions. They do not want to do this.

What has happened in regard to radiation over the years? We have had a number of experts say that, in fact, radiation was good for you. In the early days radiation was considered to be quite beneficial when it was first discovered. Then, of course, it was discovered that radiation was not beneficial and in fact there were hazards. Over the years the dose limits have been consistently lowered. In the New Scientist of 19 November 1987 we read that Britain's National Radiological Protection Board:

yesterday called for a dramatic reduction in the radiation doses permitted for workers and for the general public. The proposals pose problems for the nuclear industry as well as for some doctors and radiographers.

Basically, the Board requires the figures to be lowered because of new analysis of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki blasts. The commission in charge of the whole operation has refused to reduce these limits because although it agreed that the latest analysis for the Japanese data doubled the fatal cancer risk, it decided against acting immediately to reduce dose limits because of the difficulties it would pose for the nuclear power industry. Therefore, there are increasing dangers and they are becoming increasingly apparent in terms of radiation damage. There is also the increasing danger of the construction of nuclear weapons.

Throughout this debate we have heard of the wonderful safeguards for uranium in general and our uranium in particular. Let us follow a case history of what happened to a shipment of our Australian uranium from the Ranger mine. This matter first surfaced publicly in articles in a German magazine Der Spiegel. My office, in particular my researcher Richard Bolt, had some previous information and had already sought to verify information about this operation. We received a number of documents directly from our contacts in the European Parliament, some of whom I met last August. As these documents were in German it took us a while to translate them. We have had three translations done; they agree. This is what the documents outline. This information was printed in abbreviated form in Der Spiegel. We now have the complete story. It involves Euratom, the nuclear watchdog in Europe. It involves a company called RWE, a German power production firm. It involves Nukem, another German firm and a firm called ILL which is a French firm located in France.

Nukem made a deal to sell 25 kilograms of highly enriched uranium-three bombs worth-to a French-German-British research reactor, in Grenoble, France; this was ILL. Nukem then started looking for uranium it could sell because it did not actually have any uranium to sell at that time. Nulux, Nukem's Luxembourg subsidiary, gave Nukem the rights to 2,900 kilograms of United States-origin uranium scraps. This was in the form of uranyl nitrate (UNH), which cannot be enriched. There was then a swap of materials. Nukem then arranged to swap its uranium scraps with RWE. In return, RWE gave Nukem a cylinder of 1,289 kilograms of Australian-origin uranium hexafluoride (UF6)-which can be enriched. Incidentally, this came from Ranger as yellowcake and was made into uranium hexafluoride in France. That company also received 2,388 kilograms of natural uranium, to balance up the amounts swapped.

This was legal. There was nothing illegal at all under the safeguards arrangements in this operation. However, there was then a swap of labels; a swap of nationality. This is where the illegality came in. Nukem did not want to-I quote from the document-`carry . . . the risk associated with necessary approval procedures with Australia' to enrich the Australian-origin uranium to weapons grade, in case Australia refused. Enrichment of Australian uranium to above 20 per cent U-235 requires written approval from the Australian Government. Nukem and RWE agreed, having swapped the material earlier, then to swap back the labels on some of that material. It was a conspiracy to defraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last we have got it.

—Yes, we do have it at last because the crux of the safeguards claims of the Australian Government is that we know exactly where our uranium is going and that it will be used for the purposes of which we approve. However, it is obvious that in this situation the labels were switched. This is beyond refute. This happened. The `Made in Australia' label on the uranium hexafluoride cylinder was stripped off and attached to some of RWE's uranium scraps. The United States label on the uranium scraps was stripped off and stuck on Nukem's uranium hexafluoride.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the flag swap, the dealings had been above board. Nukem had obtained a cylinder of Australian-origin UF6 and RWE had obtained an amount of uranium scraps in the form of uranyl nitrate. However, by swapping the flags, Nukem gave its uranium hexafluoride an American label. The United States does not oppose enrichment of its uranium to weapons grade, so the UF6 was sent to the United States for enrichment. Nukem got 25 kilograms of weapons-grade uranium back, which it passed on to ILL. Meanwhile, the scraps owned by RWE acquired an Australian label thus putting it under stricter safeguards. But who cared? Who cares about safeguards on scraps? The uranium itself had already been processed.

Where was Euratom, the atomic watchdog in all this? Euratom actually approved this deal. We have Euratom documents and one official in Euratom told Nukem that the flag swap was an opportunity to break down existing legal procedures preventing such swaps in order to create a legal precedent. The same official also advised Nukem that it should make the application for the swap, rather than RWE, because Nukem's application carried more weight. Another official assured the companies involved that, `in case of an inspection of one of these transactions, you would be notified'. Therefore, the watchdog in Europe on whom we hope to rely simply was in collusion with the companies doing the swap. Incidentally, all this is under investigation by the European Parliament and the German Government.

Nukem could not have enriched the uranium scraps it originally obtained from Nulux because of the pressures of time and cost. Therefore, removing the Australian label from the uranium hexafluoride made possible a deal which would otherwise not have been possible. RWE seems to have been charitable in swapping usable Australian uranium for the US scrap owned by Nukem, until it is realised that the two companies are related. RWE owns 45 per cent of Nukem. According to Der Spiegel, RWE has received bribes from the nuclear transport firm Transnuklear. Transnuklear, which is 66.7 per cent owned by Nukem, shipped the Australian-origin uranium hexafluoride obtained by Nukem to RWE.

Euratom at different times used different methods for calculating the quantity of uranyl nitrate which was equivalent to the uranium hexafluoride which came from Australia. The first method compares the equivalent quantities of natural uranium in two consignments of enriched uranium, while the second compares their U-235 contents. The first method found that 2,313 kilograms of the US-origin uranyl nitrate was equivalent to the Australian-origin uranium hexafluoride shipment which, in fact, was a gas. The second gave an answer of 2,176 kilograms-a difference of 137 kilograms. Clearly, uranium could be made to disappear or reappear by selective use of the two calculating techniques.

The Australian Government's response was quite similar to that of Senator Stone and his disbelieving friend, Senator MacGibbon. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, said in the Senate on 17 March that the transactions referred to were consistent with the Australian-EURATOM safeguards agreement. On 22 March Senator Cook said that the swaps were of equivalent materials. Yet, the Nukem and EURATOM documents show that Nukem could not have obtained the weapons grade uranium it sold to ILL if it had not obtained the Australian uranium hexafluoride and stripped it of its label. If the swaps were consistent with Australia's agreement with EURATOM, it is clear that our safeguards can be rendered useless by swapping the flags on a shipment of usable Australian uranium with an amount of useless uranium from a country with less strict conditions. If the swaps were not consistent with the agreement, the Minister has misled the Parliament.

This situation has come to light and we do not know how many times this sort of thing has gone on that we have not noticed. Obviously, what we need is a new regime for dealing with the problem of safeguards. To this end, the Australian Democrats have developed a safeguards Bill, which we will introduce in here, which will plug many of these loopholes. It will be necessary to use this safeguards Bill because even Minister Kerin has been quoted in a newspaper as saying that if our allegations-in fact, they are not allegations at all; they are facts-are correct, and they are correct, the Australian Government will simply have to reassess its safeguards arrangements. This will take place, because it is patently obvious that at this very moment the Australian Government does not know where its uranium is going. So the safeguards must be overhauled.

We also need an attitudinal change. Often in this chamber people who do not understand a problem, or do not wish to face a problem, will denigrate those who try to make the problem apparent to people. If honourable senators wish to influence others to follow their way of thinking, they will have to do a bit more research on the facts and indulge in far less personal abuse. Perhaps then their story-if it is a saleable story about the safety of uranium and nuclear power-would be listened to. However, at the moment they are not making the running for two reasons. One is that they are trying to sell a very poor product-namely, nuclear power-and the other is that the way they are approaching their sale is based on profit, greed and self-interest. I think that this nation's youth can see right through that. The reason this nation's youth do listen to the arguments of those who would scale down the use of nuclear power is that they make sense. An argument based on a quick buck now and the hope of a technological fix to bale us out of the problems we are now creating for ourselves simply does not make sense to this nation's youth and that is why they are not listening to it.

We have canvassed a number of things tonight in the area of nuclear power. Senator Coulter, I think, will take on the economic aspect which certainly needs to be covered. I reiterate my contention that safeguards do not exist for the use of Australian uranium at this time and they must be implemented very soon or more and more Australian uranium will end up in the earth's nuclear warheads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to see Senator Stone in the chamber tonight after my introduction by Senator Sanders and was pleased to see his reaction, which clearly was one of disbelief. I hope that he will stay here and listen to the arguments. I wish to develop principally two arguments. One is to counter the drift of Senator MacGibbon's speech, which was based on an idea of technological determinism that somehow or other-I think that I am quoting him correctly-we cannot unlearn nuclear physics. Nobody suggests that we should unlearn nuclear physics, but the Australian Democrats certainly suggest that we have reached a stage in our technological development where we need to be far more cautious and wise about the application of our knowledge. Certainly, we need to push forward on many fronts. We need to learn a lot more about nuclear physics because there are a number of aspects of nuclear physics which are extremely useful to us.

SPEECH.PARA: But because we can do something no longer means that a wise person will necessarily apply that technology. Quite clearly, there are technologies which are dangerous and which a wise person will not apply. A fairly recent example was a debate that went on in the United States over the development of supersonic transport, which resulted in a decision not to apply that technology. What we are learning now about the damage to the high stratosphere from a number of pollutant gases indicates that that was a very wise decision. As Senator Stone has pointed out, doubtless if he had been advising the British Government he would have been one of those in favour of Concorde and would have said that those who opposed Concorde were Luddites. The English went ahead with Concorde and have produced not only a very uneconomic monster but also one that is causing damage to the high atmosphere in its flights. That is the first point I want to make. It is not Luddite to recognise that some technologies are inherently dangerous and it is not wise to apply them. That is not the same as saying that one should not learn about those things and relate that knowledge to one's understanding of nature rather than to the exploitation of that knowledge for economic gain.

In making my second point I am going slightly against what my colleague Senator Sanders said earlier. It is not economic to develop nuclear energy. Therefore, it is not economic for us to go ahead with developing nuclear mines. I think that there is a very sound argument why investments in other industries in Australia would be far more economic. Let us look at the costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. This rambling discourse around the far reaches of fantasy is one thing, but at not one stage has the senator on his feet given the Senate any indication of the Bill to which he is talking, let alone addressed one clause or element of the Bill. Would you bring him back on a point of reference?

—The Bill before the Senate is the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987. Whilst the debate on the Bill has ranged widely on uranium and nuclear matters, it is still necessary for Senator Coulter to relate his argument to the Bill.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I point out that Senator Stone has contributed as much as anyone else to this debate and he has not been on his feet.
—There is no point of order.

—We are addressing a Bill which relates to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The relevance of what I am saying is that Senator MacGibbon indicated-again, I hope that I am quoting his words correctly-that the Non-Proliferation Treaty was one of the great international agreements. He went on to say that the only way to use nuclear energy safely, or to export uranium from Australia safely, was in conformity with the Non-Proliferation Treaty which required this Bill to bring it into line with certain requirements in relation to the patents legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of my remarks is to stress that there is another way to go, namely, not to export uranium. That is the alternative to the proposal which both Senator MacGibbon and Senator Parer have put up. Both those senators and other senators have been addressing this point, so what I am saying is completely relevant. I think we need to look at the costs of going down the nuclear energy path. We need to establish that there is a legitimate alternative, namely, not to export uranium.

Let us look at the reliability of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the body which is responsible internationally for looking after safety. I point to a paper which appeared about a year before the Chernobyl accident occurred which was written by the head of the safety division of the International Atomic Energy Agency. This nuclear physicist pointed out in his article that to some extent he had been responsible for the design of the RMBK1000 reactor-the type of reactor at Chernobyl which blew its top. (Quorum formed) I thank Senator Panizza for bringing others into the chamber to hear what I have to say. I was saying that the head of the reactor safety division of the International Atomic Energy Agency was the man who was partly responsible for the design of the RMBK1000 reactor at Chernobyl. About a year before the accident at Chernobyl he wrote an article which appeared in the journal of the International Atomic Energy Agency. In it he pointed out the inherent safety of that reactor and that it was physically impossible for that reactor to undergo the melt down that actually occurred. That is one measure of the reliability of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

The Opposition has pointed out repeatedly that we do not have reliable information. It presumably implies that it has eminently reliable information. Mr Tony Benn, who was a Minister for Energy in the former Labour government in Great Britain, has repeatedly pointed out that while he was the Minister he was not given information by the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority regarding the repeated leaks and accidents which were occurring in the reprocessing plant at Windscale. With this in mind, I find it rather remarkable that the Opposition can sit here and claim that it has some enormous prescience in these matters.

I would like to look particularly at the links between the civil and military programs. Honourable senators will remember that not so long ago a worker in the United Kingdom Central Electricity Generating Board was dismissed from his employment because he discovered that the Americans were attempting to buy plutonium from the United Kingdom civilian nuclear program for use in the United States of America military weaponry. Over many years that worker happened to be in favour of civil nuclear energy precisely because he had maintained that there was a distinct separation between the civil and military programs. He was so disgusted when he discovered what was happening in the relationships between the US military program and the United Kingdom civil program that he went public on it. He lost his job, which was rather unwise of the Central Electricity Generating Board because he then took the Board to court for reinstatement and this information came out. Clearly, there are links every day at the practical level between the civilian and the military programs.

We know that the Chernobyl reactor blew its top. What was the actual cost of that occurrence? The Russians themselves, who presumably would want to play down the damage in terms of human ill-health, have estimated that up to 40,000 people in western Russia alone will eventually develop cancer as a consequence of that reactor accident. We saw on our television screens numbers of medium sized towns which are totally deserted because of contamination from that reactor. John Gofman, the Emeritus Professor of Medical Physics in California, has estimated that one million cancers will arise throughout the whole of Western Europe as a result of the Chernobyl reactor accident. We have seen the total destruction of the culture of the indigenous people of Norway and Sweden because of contamination of the lichen and their inability to continue to have a culture based substantially on the reindeer. Those are just some of the costs which are associated with one single nuclear reactor accident.

France has been mentioned as a country which has a substantial proportion of electricity based on nuclear energy. In 1979 two unions associated with the building and the operation of French nuclear reactors disclosed that there were substantial cracks in a critical part of the core of all the light water French nuclear reactors. That was written up in the journal Nature; it was commented on in the journal Science. The Professor of Metallurgy at Oxford University confirmed that the technology was not available to allow them to be repaired. The consequence of that was that the French Government refused to allow any further public disclosure of information in relation to these irreparable faults in their reactors. I predict that the next Chernobyl reactor accident will occur in France. What price our exports to France when that next reactor accident happens?

Sweden was mentioned tonight as one country which has a number of nuclear reactors and which does at the moment derive a high proportion of its electricity from nuclear sources. But Opposition senators have not revealed that several years ago the Swedes decided, as a result of a referendum, to phase out their nuclear reactors. As a consequence of the Chernobyl accident they have decided that that phase-out should occur rather more rapidly.

Senator MacGibbon mentioned that acquaintances of his had gone to the Taj Mahal but had been unable to see it because of the smoke from burning cow dung. He went on to develop the argument that there was some relief for Third World countries from the use of fossil fuels by their going nuclear. As I have pointed out in this place before, if Senator MacGibbon looks at the Sixth Report on Environmental Pollution-the so-called Flowers report from the United Kingdom-he will find that this question was examined quite closely. Its conclusion was that the development of nuclear energy actually increased the use of fossil fuels; it did not decrease it. There are a number of reasons for that. The first is the very high capital cost of nuclear power stations. I am disappointed that Senator Parer is not here because he mentioned the 1973-74 oil price shock. The interesting thing about that was that when the price of oil went up one might have expected-on the arguments that we have heard from the Opposition-that there would have been a demand for more nuclear energy. In fact, in 1973-74 there was a substantial downturn in the demand for nuclear reactors; there was not an upturn at all. The reason for that is that there is not a clear substitution, and I will go into that in a moment. Moreover, the high capital cost at the front end of building nuclear power stations at a time of economic stringency prevented the use of such power stations.

Another reason is that nuclear energy provides electricity only. That gives the lie to the nonsense about Third World countries because by and large the people of those countries do not even have cables to take electricity to their homes.
