There is no way in which the Indian peasant who is burning cow dung to cook the family food at night will somehow hook up an electric stove supplied with power from a nuclear power station. That is simply not on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want them to stay like that forever don't you, so long as you are smug in your isolation? You don't care about anybody else.
—I hope Senator Mac- Gibbon stays here--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 422. Senator Stone has now left us but the continual interjections from his corner of the chamber are downright contemptuous. I ask you to call honourable senators to order.

—Whilst it is disorderly to interject, throughout the debate there have been interjections from many parts of the Senate during a series of speeches. If the level of interjections had been too high I would have intervened. There is no immediate point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. There is certainly no intention to leave the Third World countries in the position they are in now. If I have time I will get onto some of the far more economic alternatives. In fact, what has happened in the Third World countries-and this was mentioned by Senator Vallentine earlier-is that reactors have been substantially subsidised by First World countries. The reactor that went into the Philippines was a good example. Such reactors provide electricity for people who are already extremely well off in those countries; they do not relieve the poverty of people at the bottom of the economic heap.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the cost of waste which is the end product of the nuclear fuel cycle. Those who have extolled the virtues of synroc as a way of storing waste have disparaged the use of glass, arguing that it is an inadequate medium for the long term storage of nuclear waste. Recent suggestions have been made that we might store waste in Australia. I point out that the United States of America Geological Survey-the official United States body that looks at these matters-made a report several years ago in which it stressed very strongly that past geological stability was no guarantee for future geological stability. One cannot predict the future in geology from what has happened in the past.

The claim has been made that there are arid and unpopulated parts of Australia and elsewhere in the world which can be used for waste. When one is contemplating storing the material that will have to be stored for at least one thousand years if the fuel rods are reprocessed-for hundreds of thousands of years if they are unreprocessed-the idea that one can rely on those areas remaining arid and unpopulated is one of the most arrogant pieces of nonsense that I have ever heard. It presupposes that we can make judgments about the future uses of these areas by generations as yet unborn and that we can impose our will on them.

As far as the waste program is concerned, in recent years the US has had a considerable problem trying to find somewhere to put this waste. We are all aware of the `not in my backyard' syndrome. The most recent exercise in the United States has involved the identification of three possible sites, which rapidly came down to one site, to which everybody objected. The estimates by the Department of Energy in the United States suggest a figure of $9 billion to develop that one site. That is the tail end of this nuclear fuel cycle which is supposed to be economic and is supposed to be a solution to the world's energy needs.

Let us look briefly at a step back from that-the reprocessing. Perhaps Opposition senators have not heard about the only substantial civilian reprocessing plant ever to operate in the United States-at West Valley on the outskirts of New York. Throughout the whole of its life, between 1967 and 1971, it had to employ 10 temporary workers for every one permanent worker who went through that reprocessing plant. For economic reasons the company had decided on a close-handling technique. All its workers were exposed up to and above the limit, so it cycled unemployed youth through its reprocessing plant at the rate of 10 temporary workers for every one permanent worker, not for their skill in work in that factory but simply for the ability of their bodies to absorb radiation. They were employed until they had absorbed three months worth of radiation-in the old units five rads divided by four-and they were then fired. Some of those workers worked for as little as three minutes in that factory. Those were the conditions imposed by the economic constraints-the sort of economic criteria that Senator Stone would impose on this industry. That is what has happened to this industry.

What are the alternatives? Perhaps the most dramatic thing I have seen in the last couple of days was a brief newspaper account of the latest nuclear reactor to be opened on the outskirts of New York. The newspaper article was really about the fact that this reactor had been officially opened and two days later had to close down because there had been a fault in a pump supplying the cooling water to the emergency core cooling system. The significant point about this article was that it mentioned the price of this 1,080 megawatt reactor. The price was $US8.6 billion-$8.60 per watt to build a nuclear reactor. I can go out of this chamber tomorrow and buy off the shelf a solar panel at less than $10 per watt. In other words, the cost of solar generated power is now in precisely the same ballpark as that of nuclear energy. It should be remembered that if I buy a solar panel the cost includes the capital cost and the running cost. I do not have to continue to buy nuclear fuel, even with the 3,000 or 30,000 tonnes that Senator Parer was talking about. Technologies can be put into Third World countries which will provide the local needs for power and do it a lot more cheaply than nuclear power. They do not require the enormous front end costs of nuclear power stations-capital that Third World countries do not have, in case Senator MacGibbon has not noticed that. That is one of the things that Third World countries do not have much of. They do not require the installation of very expensive power lines. They do not involve the extensive use of other fuels for the transport of materials in and out. It is notable, and I think Senator Parer made the point, that 26 countries are using nuclear energy. How many countries are there in the world?

TALK.START.PARA: —One hundred and seventy.

—There are 170 countries, and figures were given of the amount of electricity generated by nuclear sources. Electricity is a tiny part of the total energy needs and total energy used by many countries. The amount of energy derived from nuclear sources in the world is actually still less than the amount derived from firewood.

SPEECH.PARA: So the points I am trying to make are that we are in a stage of considerable potential dominance over our environment, leading to very considerable damage if we do not apply our knowledge and our technology very wisely and very carefully. Because we can do something, we do not necessarily any longer have to do it. We should not necessarily do certain things. That is not to say that we turn our backs on knowledge, as Senator MacGibbon has tried to indicate. We learn as much as we can about this world but we wisely apply those technologies. We apply them when there is least damage and when there is most benefit. Nuclear energy is not one of those technologies that produce a particular benefit and it certainly poses considerable hazards. There is abundant evidence now to show that the use of nuclear energy will increase the use of fossil fuel. It will exacerbate the damage from the use of fossil fuel-the greenhouse effect, the pollution over cities, the lung cancers and so on, within cities-and, moreover, there are far more economic ways to develop energy, particularly for the Third World.

Perhaps I could very briefly speak about a piece of research work that was done in Adelaide in relation to synroc, because I do not think it is widely known. That is some work done by a physicist, Ernst Hersch, who now works in the physics department at Adelaide University. He has shown that synroc or glass exposed to moisture and high levels of radiation to which it is necessarily exposed undergoes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in this very important debate on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill largely because of motivation-(Quorum formed) This debate is very significant and I wish to speak in it largely because of comments made earlier in the debate by Senator Lewis with regard to young people. However, can I say that though the Australian Democrats are supporting this legislation we see it largely as window-dressing, while the nation continues, at the behest of this Labor Government, to export uranium and, in particular, to export uranium to France.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is related largely to the question of whether associated technology is possessed or communicated without relevant permit or authority from the Australian Safeguards Office. My colleagues in this debate have already canvassed significantly the value of international safeguards under which this Government has permitted the continuation of the export of uranium. Perhaps I can just repeat that all those arguments have demolished any argument from the Government or the Opposition that there are any safeguards of any significance. I would have to agree very strongly with the Minister when he said in his second reading speech that the Bill is not momentous. It could scarcely be less momentous when this country continues to export uranium, and to export uranium particularly to France.

The Australian Democrats are appalled at a report in the Canberra Times of the twenty-fourth of this month which highlighted the fact that the French have used and exploited the recent Canberra Festival to promote the issue of uranium sales to that country. The Gang Gang column of 24 March highlights the fact that a glossy brochure was put out to promote the spectacular Versailles production in Canberra, France's bicentennial gift to Australia-a full colour yellowcake advertisement shining from the glossy brochure, the column told us. The article went on to say:
Uranium is a touchy subject between the two countries at the moment.

I wish it were just a shade more touchy to the extent that we might see some action by the Government. The article talked about factions within the ALP and splits in Cabinet and so on. The article went on:
. . . the French Minister for Defence has recently said the French don't even need our stuff, and feelings are always high over the nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.
The article suggested:
Maybe the ad should have been kept out of the promotional material for what was a birthday gesture-
our two hundredth birthday-
of friendship and peace, and a breathtakingly beautiful one at that.
The article concluded with this comment:
Still, some Australians felt at a time when we were talking birthday cake we could have done without yellowcake.

I must say that I certainly endorse that sentiment. I use that to underline the fact that I agree with the Minister that this is not a momentous Bill. My colleagues have outlined the very strong scepticism of the Australian Democrats about the value-in fact the absolute lack of value-of international safeguards. As many in the chamber and the public will know, Senator Sanders and his staff-notably Richard Bolt-have been instrumental in recent days in documenting the protestations of this Government that we do not have a problem and that our uranium is not ending up in nuclear weapons. Though the protestations are strong and the Government is always claiming that, that is something that cannot be proved. It is a sleight of hand issue and Australians are concerned about it. The Government's claim has been shot to ribbons by the Australian Democrats.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Vietnam War Veterans: Medals-Carpet in the New Parliament House-Road Funding-Provisional Tax

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate debated the Opposition's Bill to amend the Flags Act, the purpose of which was to protect the flag from change, except by way of a referendum of the Australian people. In thinking about the flag, one automatically thinks of the men and women who fought for this country under that flag. Tonight I want to draw the Senate's attention to a matter which affects some of those veterans and which is in the hands of the Government to remedy.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the members of the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) who served on HMAS Sydney and other ships during the Vietnam War and who are eligible under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to repatriation benefits. These are veterans who are still, after all these years, being refused entitlement to the two medals for Vietnam service-namely, the Australian Vietnam medal and the South Vietnamese Government Campaign medal. These naval veterans are considered by the Navy to have been:
. . . exposed to potential risk through their being in continual danger when in the vicinity of the Vietnamese coast, and particularly during unloading operations off Vung Tau.

This is borne out by Navy Office files and by standing orders for Vietnam deployments. A naval minute of December 1984 to the Assistant Chief of Defence Force Policy from Rear Admiral Knox, then Deputy Chief of Naval Staff, said that the Chiefs of Staff Committee endorsement of the potential risk was evidenced in an October 1967 assessment which stated that:

. . . there is a risk of attack by the Viet Cong during concentration and deployment phases in South Vietnam and during movement through South Vietnamese ports. Underwater attacks on shipping is possible in South Vietnamese ports.

Rear Admiral Knox went on to detail the special precautions taken by the Navy against underwater attacks from 1967 to 1979. He concluded by saying that these precautions indicated that an attack on RAN ships was considered a real possibility and that there was little doubt that this perception was engendered in all personnel involved. This document was obtained under the Freedom of Information Act, and I seek leave to have the annexure A referred to in Admiral Knox's minute incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows:
EXAMPLES OF THE THREAT AT VUNG TAU

1. In formulating HMAS SYDNEY'S programme December 1967-July 1968, the Fleet Commander in a signal to Australian Commonwealth Naval Board on 27 October 1967 stated ``Turn around in Vung Tau has been limited to one day to avoid remaining overnight in hostile anchorage. Bad weather or enemy activity could increase the time.''

2. DNI advice to CNS dated 16 July 1968 regarding Vung Tau stated ``. . . SYDNEY should spend as little time as possible in any port in South Vietnam including Vung Tau''. In his penscript to this advice CNS wrote ``I could not agree that the benefit of SYDNEY remaining off Vung Tau for longer than the minimum time required to complete her prime task justifies the possible risks involved.''
3. The Viet Cong attacked Vung Tau with rockets from Long Song Island in April 1968.
4. In June 1968 an intelligence report stated that an unidentified enemy platoon moved onto Long Song Island to reportedly shell Vung Tau with 122mm rocket and 82mm mortar.
5. A sampan carrying four Viet Cong was ambushed near Vung Tau in March 1969. A further five Viet Cong were killed when their sampan was ambushed in June 1969 north of Long Song Island.
6. Two enemy swimmers/sappers were found in Vung Tau harbour in May 1969. An improvised mine containing 60lbs of explosives and two Russian mines were located.
7. In June 1970, a black plastic bag containing explosives was found slung on a line between the wharf and the USS MEEKER COUNTY, berthed at the De Long pier in Vung Tau harbour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The document is entitled `Examples of the Threat at Vung Tau' and clearly demonstrates the potential risk through there being a continuing danger. These veterans are entitled to the return from active service badge, but are not entitled to the medals. These servicemen marched as veterans with their Army and Air Force colleagues in the welcome home march last year, but were denied the medals they wanted to wear. HMAS Sydney made 22 voyages to Vung Tau between 1965 and 1972 bringing troops and ammunition. Other documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act reveal that the Director of Naval Intelligence considered in 1968 that HMAS Sydney was a tempting target from a propaganda and political point of view; that HMAS Sydney should spend as little time as possible in any port in South Vietnam, including Vung Tau; that allied ships were mined in Vung Tau harbour; that top secret signals relating to a reduction in the escort commitment included one which said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential for the safety of the ship for a continuous escort to be provided from Sydney to Vung Tau.

These medals are not awarded for valour or heroism, but as recognition of operational services to Australia in a time of war. The National Congress of the Returned Servicemen's League last year reaffirmed its stand to have the Vietnam medal issued to all sailors serving in Vietnam.

Last year, the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, refused the application of members of HMAS Sydney and the Vietnam Logistical Support Veterans' Association for eligibility for these medals. Tonight I once again ask the Minister to reconsider this matter. Men who served this country in that hidden war deserve recognition for their service and for their readiness to face whatever danger their country required of them. In the name of compassion and justice, I ask that the Minister reconsider this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night there was a news item that I heard, as did a number of my constituents, as a result of which some have contacted me and other senators who have mentioned the matter to me. The item related to the carpet in the new House of Representatives which apparently is to be removed because of some colour imperfection. Some of the news items indicated that it was likely to be destroyed-as one person put to me, because of the Customs Act. I suggest that probably what happened was that the carpet came in without payment of sales tax or import duty or whatever; and that would make sense.

SPEECH.PARA: What has caused my constituents to be amazed, astonished or angry in turn is the fact that a good carpet is being destroyed when many people feel that it could be used by a number of organisations and could be made available to them. That cannot be done by the owner of the carpet because of the duty question. However, it must surely be possible for the Minister to intervene to ensure that the carpet can be put to good use and not destroyed. Apparently the carpet does not belong to the Parliament House Construction Authority. It still belongs to the person who is supplying it. It would appear to be a gross act of waste, to say the least, if this carpet were to be thrown out, if in fact that is the case. Whatever it is, it has caused a fair amount of interest and anxiety. Perhaps the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) could take up the matter and let us know the true story and what is to happen to the carpet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the adjournment debate tonight on a matter which is causing a great amount of fear, frustration and anger within local governments and the people they serve-that is, the massive cuts in road funding being considered by this Government. Local government across Australia is confronting the most severe threat to road funding in decades as a result of a number of options identified by the Government in its quest to further lower the percentage of the fuel tax spent on roads. The Labor Government's record in road funding is already abysmal, with road funding decreasing by 40 per cent in real terms over the last four years to the lowest level in many years. Of the 28.8c per litre that the Government receives in fuel tax, only 5.355c is actually returned for road funding. To return to 1983-84 levels of road funding, approximately 7c per litre needs to be spent. The Government has chosen to ignore that the increase in upkeep costs will mean greater competition for funds that are remaining for new works. At present about 60 per cent of arterial roads expenditure and up to 90 per cent of local roads expenditure is required for upkeep. Funds provided by Federal road programs are a major source of new construction expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: How is Australia to meet the increased demand for roads and road use in the future? By the year 2000, total travel is expected to grow by 60 per cent and road freight is expected to double. When one considers also that 77 per cent of all domestic freight is moved by road and the importance of reliable domestic transport to the competitiveness of our crucial export sector, it is counterproductive even to suggest a further tightening of road funding restrictions. We hear much from this Government about its commitment to generate employment. Is the Government aware that roads and road transport related activities employ 500,000 people, or about 1 in 13 of the Australian work force? The Australian Roads Outlook report claims that every $1m of road construction expenditure generates about 61 person years of employment. The roads sector has the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors which produce a physical product.

The report goes on rightly to say that road improvements have significantly contributed to the wealth of this country with a road system valued at almost $100 billion. Continued investment will reap further social and economic benefits for the community. On average, each $1 invested in roads returns over $2 in benefits. To preserve this asset the Government must allocate sufficient funds for road upkeep and for the expansion of the road system to cater for future needs. Failure to do so will impose large costs on the community, not only in terms of forfeiting employment and road investment returns but also in terms of soaring industry costs.

It is estimated that, for every $1m reduction in upkeep expenditure, industry's transport costs increase by $3m. However, despite all this, the Government is considering a number of options as a result of the report of the Cameron Independent Committee of Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Road Grants, which will further lower the priority given to Australian roads. Before I detail these options it should be pointed out that, since its release last year, the Cameron report has received considerable scrutiny by Australia's road making authorities. One of the most persistent criticisms that has been levelled at the report has been the methodology used to come up with its recommendations which are so obviously out of place. State road authorities have said that the indicators used are of doubtful relevance.

The report relies heavily on outdated statistics. Arbitrary weights were then applied which resulted in a simple distribution based on traffic volume. As a result, the report is considerably biased towards the more heavily trafficked roads in urban areas to the possible future detriment of roads in rural areas, even though these areas generate the bulk of the country's export wealth. Queensland in particular would be disadvantaged by such a bias if the findings were taken as they currently stand and implemented. Many of the small rural shires' only source of employment is in the councils or railways. If we take away the source of this income through further decreasing road funding we will virtually destroy many small local communities in Queensland and I think that would apply in many other States.

The Cameron report led the Government to consider a number of specific options. I believe that there are departmental committees to make their recommendations on future strategies by the end of the month. The decisions are expected to be announced in the May economic statement-decisions which will probably determine the Commonwealth's road funding commitment for the next three years. It is, therefore, of vital importance that the options being floated by the Government be debated in the public arena so that the Government is made aware of the significant opposition to its proposals as they now stand. These options include holding the total of Commonwealth road funds to $1,245m for the fifth year in succession; cutting total road funding below this level, possibly by dropping funding for local roads which would represent a loss of some $36m to Queensland; and absorbing arterial and local road funding into the united financial assistance grants which State governments receive from the Federal Government. In response to the Government's range of proposals the Australian Local Government Association, which represents Australia's 836 local authorities, has slammed the Government's approach and criticised its credibility for reneging on its road funding commitments over the past three years. It is obvious that current levels of funding are inadequate to support Australia's growing infrastructure. Many provincial and rural local authorities would be crippled if the local roads category were scrapped. Rate increases of between 25 per cent and 50 per cent would be needed to offset such cuts. There would be a fall in employment and yet another increase in our welfare bill.

Senator Reynolds is not in the chamber tonight. I hope that she is receiving as many phone calls and letters as I am from many concerned constituents. As Minister for Local Government she must be very aware that this latest move by her Government amounts to a bitter betrayal of the people whose interests she is supposed to protect, especially in view of her other role-that is, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. The recent report on the survey of women in Australia served to highlight the need for additional Federal expenditure on local roads. Of the women surveyed 69 per cent believed that roads should be a priority service for government funding. I note that roads were placed ahead of health and medical services, better education and training and community welfare services. The message is clear. Rural women want better transport systems and roads. Rural shires will be starved of road funds if the Federal Government moves away from its commitment for direct involvement in local roads. Senator Reynolds should understand that. If she believes in her statement that rural women are finely tuned to the economic mood of their community she should recognise their concern and fight hard for additional road funding. Senator Reynolds will be failing in her responsibilities as a Minister, both for local government and the status of women, if she cannot get a better deal for these communities than that which is presently before the Government. Her credibility would fall to an all-time low.

To illustrate this Government's further neglect of the ordinary men and women of Australia we need only to look at the effect of the cuts in road funding for one small shire. I will not name that shire in case it causes it some embarrassment. Since 1985 its local road funding has been cut in real terms by 25 per cent. As a consequence, it has lost eight employees and has experienced a rate increase of 22 per cent. The general impact on the local community was further unemployment and a substantial decline in the standard of road conditions which diminished the economic benefits that flow from better roads and decreased road safety standards. If local road funding were cut altogether a further five employees would be lost as a direct result. There would be another rate increase and a negative impact on the community generally.

This is just one small example which would be mirrored throughout Australia if the Federal Government refused to maintain its commitment to Australia's road system. This example is all the more appropriate because it is from a shire already severely hit by the Federal Government in terms of employment, income, economic growth and development. It is located in the World Heritage affected areas of north Queensland. It is no wonder then that the shire is reeling from the effects of what could be described as a double barrelled shotgun held to its head. The Government must take note of the warnings it has received in the recent State by-elections and council elections and get back in touch with ordinary Australians. It must know that it is political suicide to ignore the voters any longer. I hope that the Government will see the light and reconsider these drastic proposals for road funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate for very long tonight. Honourable senators may remember that, at the end of last session or at the beginning of this session-I do not quite remember-I spoke during the adjournment debate about the point at which one pays provisional tax. I pointed out that, if one received $999 of unearned income, made up of interest, dividends, et cetera, one was liable to pay provisional tax. As far as I remember, that level was set in 1981 and it has not been reviewed since. I do not remember what the average weekly wage was in 1981. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is in the chamber, would probably have a better idea about that. However, the figure is probably twice as much now. But the starting point for provisional tax has never been lifted.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pointed out at the time that there was a strong revolt on the part of people who got caught up in provisional tax. I think I mentioned the figure of 350,000 pensioners alone, although I would not like to be held to that figure because it seems rather high. However, I read in a newspaper-the West Australian of yesterday, I think-that the Government is now looking at increasing the limit for pensioners in the May mini-Budget or statement, or whatever it is called. I congratulate the Government on considering the matter-if it does something about it for pensioners. If the Government lifts the limit for pensioners but not anyone else, however, it will be discriminatory because, at the other end of the scale, young people trying to save for a deposit on their first home are finding that provisional tax is being imposed on them. If one gets 12 1/2 per cent interest on one's investment, $8,000 will attract $1,000 interest for the year, which puts one over the limit. Normally, a couple saving for a deposit for their first house would be looking at a little more than that-say, $10,000 to $12,000 each, to give a $25,000 deposit. So, at the other end of the scale they, too, get caught up. I should like the Government to bear that matter in mind in its deliberations leading up to the May mini-Budget or statement.

I mention another matter as regards provisional tax. In Perth, at least, there is a vast amount of trouble with the Australian Taxation Office computer. We have now been on quarterly payments of provisional tax for a couple of years or thereabouts; we are coming to the end of the first full year of provisional tax. For those who pay provisional tax, especially those in business, 31 March is the date on which the Taxation Office is squared off-and that date is just around the corner. I have been lobbied by the accounting profession in Western Australia because there seem to be many assessments coming out now that have not been credited for the provisional tax that has been paid already in the quarterly payments. When one explains this to the Taxation Office, one is told, `Yes, that may be so. We do not know. The computer has broken down and given us trouble'. One then says, `What do we do?' The Taxation Office says, `You had better pay the amount on your assessment as it stands, otherwise there could be penalties. Your money will be refunded'. The money will be refunded no doubt, with no interest, and one does not know when-perhaps 12 months down the track. I should like the Minister to take up that point with his colleagues to see whether it can be sorted out, preferably before 31 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —Four senators have spoken in this adjournment debate-Senators Newman, Reid, Boswell and Panizza. All of them are Opposition senators, and all of them have raised questions which are directed to the Government or relevant Ministers. Obviously I shall draw those questions to the attention of the relevant Ministers and those Ministers will reply as they consider appropriate in due course. However, I should like to comment on some of the speeches that have been delivered. I shall draw Senator Newman's remarks about the veterans's medal for the Vietnam campaign to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and give a side notice of that to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, because obviously the matter is in their domain and they may wish to vary any remarks or reaffirm the remarks they have made in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman referred to the debate in the Senate this afternoon on the Flags Amendment Bill 1987. One of my most striking memories of this type of debate in Australia is of 1984 during the Los Angeles Olympic Games, when I drove down William Street in Perth and saw on kerbside billboards the legend `They're playing our song'. That is all it said. We all knew that it signified that the South Australian cycle team had won a gold medal at the Olympic Games and that Glynis Nunn had won her event at the Olympic Games. All that was necessary was to say `They're playing our song'. We knew that that was not God Save the Queen. We knew that it was Australia's own song, Advance Australia Fair. It is not surprising to me that Australians have come to love and value that as the symbol of Australia in terms of music and lyric, and that that has overtaken and replaced God Save the Queen.

I am one of those who hope that one day a flag will fly from our flagpoles which is uniquely Australian and is not embroidered with the symbol of another country. However, having stated my own view, let me say that it is true that the Government has no intention of changing the flag. It is not planning to do such. This sort of Bill and the sorts of speeches that we have heard are aimed at whipping up an event that is not real and trying to generate some nationalistic fervour based on misconception.

In one of Senator Reid's indefatigable issues from the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), she raised the question of the carpet in the new Parliament House. She did not quite carpet the Government in what she said, but she said that there was anxiety and interest on the part of citizens of the ACT about what might happen to the offcuts from carpet found to be flawed in the new Parliament House. I have nothing to say about that other than what I have read in the Press. I shall refer that matter on in case the relevant Minister wishes to comment on it.

My understanding is that the carpet laid in the new House of Representatives chamber is of a uniquely Australian eucalyptus green shading and is designed especially for the House of Representatives chamber. My understanding is that before the carpet was laid it was not checked by the manufacturer or the agent and that, upon its being laid, flaws were detected in various parts, not the least of which was a section directly in front of where the Prime Minister would sit. I recall cartoons stressing that Bob Hawke would sit there and portraying a frayed piece of carpet in front of him. That was the new Parliament House.
What is reassuring about those cartoons for the Government is that they presumed that Bob Hawke would remain the Prime Minister. That is a presumption that I, too, make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only for a little while.

—I think that that interjection is wrong and that the people of Australia are more sensible than it suggests. But presuming that one day there may be a change and perhaps the Prime Minister may be John Elliott, Andrew Peacock, or Fred Chaney II, or Fred Chaney III or Fred Chaney IV, or maybe Fred Chaney X, I can obviously see the point of Senator Reid's concerns. My understanding is that the section of the carpet that is flawed is to be taken up and that the manufacturer has agreed to take it back and replace it without cost. What then will happen to the offcuts, which are owned by the manufacturer, is up to the manufacturer. I emphasise that that is my understanding. If it is incorrect, obviously it will be corrected.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing much that I want to say about Senator Boswell's contribution, because again, in the tradition of the National Party, he put out his hand for some more money. We are used to that. It is particularly rampant in Queensland. It is not surprising, though, that he omitted to mention a number of matters, such as the tax applied by the Queensland Government on rail freights. In my own portfolio area, all the mining companies in Queensland continually complain about the indirect tax that is screwed out of them by the Queensland Government's overcharging in terms of rail transport, but there seems to be no intent on the part of any Queensland parliamentary representative to suggest to the State Government that it might attend to its road programs by diverting some of those funds. Again tonight Senator Boswell did not do that.

I think it is unnecessary for me to say, but I do put on the record that the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) is performing an excellent job in that role. Any criticism of her is not justified. The Government is sensitive to the need for both rural and metropolitan roads. It is not fair to make the assertions that have been made.

Senator Panizza raised the question of a cap on earnings for provisional tax. I shall draw those remarks to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I do not know, but the business tax review may cover that or, as Senator Panizza mentioned, the May economic statement may cover it. Nonetheless, if the Government has a reply to make on the issues that Senator Panizza raised, it will do so.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.01 p.m.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What studies, if any, have been made by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy or any other Federal Department into the effects that the use of agricultural chemicals on the mainland have had on the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounds.
(2) What have been the major findings of such studies.
(3) What long term effect has the use of pesticides on the mainland had on the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounds.
(4) What long term effect has the use of insecticides on the mainland had on the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounds.
(5) To what extent have trace residues of pesticides been found in the Great Barrier Reef area.
(6) To what extent have trace residues of insecticides been found in the Great Barrier Reef.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has no current studies into the effects that the use of agricultural chemicals on the mainland have had on the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounds however the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA) is funding three studies that relate to the use of agricultural chemicals in the Great Barrier Reef (GBR) Region. The studies are to:-
(a) determine use of agricultural chemicals in the North Queensland (James Cook University);
(b) determine anthropogenic influences, including pollutants in the Cairns area of the Marine Park (University of Melbourne);

(c) determine whether nitrates and phosphates used in agriculture on the mainland are reaching the Barrier Reef and are affecting growth of coral or contributing to outbreaks of Crown of Thorns Starfish (James Cook University).

The GBRMPA sponsored a workshop on `Contaminants in Waters of the Great Barrier Reef' in May 1984. The workshop focussed on a range of contaminants including polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and other organochlorines.

In addition GBRMPA sponsored a workshop in late November 1987 to discuss the impact of nitrates and phosphates in the Marine Park and the need for monitoring (early indicators from study (c) mentioned above were discussed).
The Workshop agreed that this topic should be investigated further at specific sites where considerable human activity impinges on the Marine Park environment.
The Proceedings of the Workshop will be published and should be available during 1988.

(2) The studies listed in the answer to (1) began in early 1987 and will be of one to three years duration. Consequently, the results are not available at this stage. However the Contaminants Workshop found that the measured levels of most chemical contaminants were so low as to be almost undetectable and concluded that sediments and nutrients are likely to be of greater concern.

(3) and (4) The long term effect of the use of pesticides and insecticides is unknown. On the basis of limited sampling, the Contaminants Workshop concluded that at the time the effects of these contaminants were low, however, the use of organochlorine pesticides in farming was identified as an area requiring further attention.

(5) and (6) Traces of pesticides and insecticides have been found in the GBR Region and the results of various studies were summarized at the Contaminants Workshop. PCBs and organochlorines have been detected. In one study (1984) PCBs were detected in the flesh of a wide range of reef organisms, and concentrations were, except for sharks, similar or less than those measured for organisms in non-polluted northern hemisphere environments. The higher concentrations in sharks may be indicative of bioaccumulation in carnivores that are at the top of the food chain. It is hoped that the above new studies will provide further information on this matter.
